Roger Boesche, “Kautilya's Arthashastra on War and Diplomacy in Ancient India,” The Journal of Military History 67, no. 1 (January 2003),9-37.






!!!Dr. John [[Bonin]]
-Writes Joint Doctrine in [[CSL]]; [[Lecture on Command and Control]] for [[TSC 20]]






See all [[Books]]






!!![[Book Eight: Thucydides]]

!!!Alliance Between Sparta and Persia: Revolts Throughout Athenian Empire; Persia buys a Spartan Navy (p. 492-502)

"""	
	• 412 (20th year): Alcibiades, having defected to Sparta, encourages a Spartan alliance with Persia. [492]
	• Athens sails to Chios and defeat them. [494]
	• Fighting on Western coast of Asia Minor.  Athenian forces abandon Miletus under Phrynichus, the Athenian commander. [497]
	• Peloponnesian forces and Persians attack southern Asia minor (Iasus) at the bidding of the Persians. [499]
	• Sparta concludes a new and more equitable treaty with Persia. [501]







!!![[Book Five: Thucydides]]

!!!Cleon, Brasidas in Thrace; Sicily, Pt. 3; Peace of Nicias (p. 301-317)

"""
	· Summer 422: Cleon leads an Athenian expedition into Thrace. [301]
	· Athenians send Phaeax to Sicily to form a coalition against Syracuse, but returns to Athens unsuccessful. [303]
	· Cleon begins a capaign in Macedonia.  Does a recon at Amphipolis.  [305]
	· Cleon is a bit inept.  Brasidas decides to attack Cleon.  Brasidas makes a speech to his men.  Claims to be liberating Hellas from the Athens. [270]  
	· He attacks and both Cleon and Brasidas are killed.  [307]
	→ ''Ironic that the guy who kept the fight going, Cleon, sucks at generalship. ''
	· By winter 422, both sides want peace.  Athens had a moment of victory that kept them wanting to fight, but now had been severely attritted. [309]  The Spartans realized that no amount of devastation to Attica would make Athens fall… Sparta had been plundered, the helots were deserting.  Both sides sue for peace, but the treaty is not signed by all allies. [311]
	· Sparta enters an alliance with Athens when some of Sparta's allies refuse to accept the peace treaty. [314]
	→'' Fucking madness. ''
	· The first war ends. [315]  The peace that follows lasts for seven years, but both sides continue to injure each other until they finally reopen hostilities. [316]
"""

!!!Melian Dialogue (p. 350-357)

"""
	· 416 BCE, ''16th year of the war. [351]
	→ The war has taken on a logic of its own… they've lost sight of why they're fighting.2 
	· The strong do what they will and the weak suffer what they must. [352]
	· Athenians state that they are there to further the interests of their empire. [352]''
	· Melians ask how they will gain from joining the Athenians.  Athenians respond that they won't be massacred.  [352]
	· Melians ask if Athenians will allow them to be neutral.  
	· Melians argue that the Athenians are making enemies where there are no enemies. [353]
	· Athenians: simple equation… you should worry most about self-preservation and not resisting those who are stronger than you. [353]
	· Melians: The fortunes of war is sometimes more impartial than the disproportion of numbers might lead one to suppose.  ''To submit is to give oneself over to despair, while action still preserves us a hope that we may stand erect. [353]
	· Athenians: abandon hope, which deludes men and leads them to their ruin. [353]''
	· Athenians: don't try to be honorable, because you can't afford such concepts. [355]
	· Athenians besieged Melos.  Killed all men and sold the women and children into slavery. [357]
"""

{{Melian Dialogue}}






!!![[Book Four: Thucydides]]

!!!Pylos and Aftermath; Sicily, Part 2 (p. 223-246)

"""	
	· Summer 425: Messana invites occupation by Syracuse and Locris and revolts from Athens. [223]
	· Peloponnesians invade Attica again.  An Athenian fleet sails for Sicily. [223]
	· The Athenian fleet is forced to put into Pylos, Demosthenes wants to fortify, but the generals refuse. [224]
	· Athens occupy Pylos, forcing the Peloponnesians to return to the Peloponnesus. [226]
	· Athens builds a defense in Pylos and the Spartans launch an amphibious assault. [228]
	· ''Demosthenes address to the troops on the beach:
		○ Stand your ground.  The Spartans have as many disadvantages as the Athenians have fewer numbers. [229]''
	· Irony of Athenians defending Spartan ground from the land as Spartans attacked by sea. [230]
	· An Athenian fleet arrives and routes the Spartans, who were taken by surprise. [230]
	· The Spartans sue for an armistice from the Athenians. [231]
	· ''Spartan speech:''
		○ Lets have peace.  Athens can keep what they got during the war. 
		○ Use their success wisely and moderately.  Spartans lost because of bad decisions, not lack of power. [232]
		○ ''The only real peace can arrive through generosity, not through military exploits. [233]
	→ They were offered an honorable way out.  Greed and honor made them reject the offer.'' 
	· Cleon urges the Athenians to not accept the armistice and continue the war. [234]
	· Battle continues at/near Pylos and also the Syracusians attacked the Athenians at Rhegium to take control of the strait. 
	· The Athenians begin to regret not making peace with the Spartans. 
	· Cleon succeeds Nicias as the commander of the Athenian forces. [239]  Cleon chooses Demosthenes as his 2nd in command.
	· Huge battle at Pylos. Demosthenes' tactics work well.  Spartans retreat but eventually are forced to surrender. [243]
	· ''Athenians lay in blockade for 72 days. The Spartans surrender, shocking the Hellenic world. [244]''
	· The Spartans send another plea for an armistice to the war, but the Athenians surrender. [244] 
"""	

!!!Brasidas' Campaign (p. 266-272)

"""	
	· Brasidas marches a Peloponnesian army to Macedonia so fast that the Thessalians can't stop him. [266]
	· Fearing a helot revolt and wanting to bloody the nose of the Athenians, the Spartans send out warlike helots out of Laconia as hoplites under Brasidas.  Given them their freedom. [268]
	· Brasidas kicks ass and his just and moderate conduct induces others to revolt.  [268]
	· Perdiccas joins forces with Brasidas and set out against the Lyncestian Macedonians. 
	· Brasidas speaks to the Acanthians:
		○ He tells the Acanthians that Sparta will respect her independence. [270]
		○ But he will ravage Acanthia if they refuse to join his "Hellenic Liberation." [271]
	· The Acanthians decided to revolt against the Athenians. 
"""






!!!The [[Book Limited War]] by Robert [[Osgood]]

*See also: [[Limited War]]
*Written in 1957
*Part of [[TWS 13]]






!!![[Book One: Thucydides]]

!!!Corcyra (p. 15-33)

"""
	• The absence of romance in my history will, I fear, detract somewhat from its interest; but if [one] desires an exact knowledge of the past as an aid to the understanding of the future… I have written my work, not as an essay which is to win the applause of the moment, but as a possession for all time. [16]
	• ''The growth of the power of Athens, and the alarm which this inspired in Sparta, made war inevitable''. [16]
	• Getting no help from their mother country, Corcyra, the City State of Epidamnus seeks and obtains help from Corinth. [17]  Corinth organizes a large force to colonize and rescue Epidamnus from Corcyra. [19]
	→ ''Escalation due to alliances… danger of alliances is that war can escalate over trifle affairs.'' 
	· Corinth refuses Corcyra's proposals, declares war, and sends a fleet.   It is defeated and Epidamnus surrenders. [20]
	· The war escalates… Corcyrians reinforce their holdings on the Ionian Sea and the Corinthians raise another fleet  and army. 
	· Corcyra sends envoys to Athens to ask for help.  Corinth sends envoys to Athens to present their case.  [22]  Corcyrian Argument to Athens:
		○  Corcyra argue that since they have the 2nd biggest navy in Greece, they are offering Athens with a great opportunity, since war with Sparta is likely to start
		○  The enemy of my enemy is my friend. [22]. 
	· ''The Corinthian Argument to Athens: ''
		○ The Corcyrian policy of isolation enabled them to use their geographic position to abuse the many ships forced to put into Corcyra [24].  They are like a pirate nation, that didn't until previously want to be held account of their crimes by others.
		○ The Corcyrians only offered arbitration only after Corinth mobilized… it was fear that motivates their alliance with Athens. [25]
		○ The Corinthians supported Athens when Athens' colony of Samos revolted. [26]
	· The Athenians side with the Corcyrians… they knew the Peloponnesian War was on its way, better to strengthen their navy than have it fall to the Corinthians. [28]
	· Battle of Sybotta Isles: 
		○ Both fleets lined up, the left wings of both fleets had success.  The Athenians initiated an attack but were defeated.  The Corinthians massacre the survivors.  An Athenian reinforcement force arrived, but the Corinthians fled. [30-31]  Both sides claimed victory [33]
		○ Corinthians and Athenians communicate by envoys.  Corinthians warn Athens that they broke the treaty.  Athenians responded that they will take action against anyone that threatens their ally Corcyra. [32]
"""

!!!Speech of Archidamus (p. 37-49)

"""
	• Athens and allies lay siege to Potidaea in Macedonia.  [37]
	• Athens claimed that one of their tribute cities was inspired by the Peloponnesians to revolt.  Corinthians argued that the Corinthian and Peloponnesian citizens within Potidaea were being besieged. [37]
	• Sparta convenes an alliance conference.  Many cities denounce Athens.  
	• ''Corinth makes a speech:''
		○ Accuses Athens of wronging them, but also accuses Sparta of doing nothing until after fighting occurred. 
		○ Spartan inaction has permitted Athens to grow at the expense of the Hellenes, and that Athens perception of Sparta's acquiescence encourages Athens to commit further aggression.  Now because of this inaction, Athens is strong and threatens all the Hellenes. [39]
		→ ''With great power comes great responsibility.  Sparta failed in her responsibility to take action at Athenian expansion.  Lack of action on the part of Sparta inspired more egregious behavior on the part of Athens.'' 
		○ Argues that Athens is wildly different in culture to the Spartans… they are adventurous, innovative, swift. [40]
		○ Peace stays longest with those who are not more careful to use their power justly than to show their determination not to submit to injustice. [40]
		→ Several logical fallacies… playing on Spartan sense of honor. Appeal to emotion, appeal to ridicule.  
	• Athenian Response to the Corinthian speech:
		○ Don't make a rash decision based on the passion of your allies. [41]
		○ With reason, the Spartans will see that Athens has a legitimate claim to Corcyra and Potidaea. 
		○ Remember the grand alliance during the Persian Wars. 
		○ Athens acquired their empire peacefully, and by default of Sparta.  It cannot be faulted for pursuing its own interests. 
		○ The three of the strongest motivations: fear, honor, and interest. [43]
	• ''Archidamus's Speech (King of Sparta)… appeal to reason. ''
		○ Admits that Spartan power is limited.  Athens is far away, they have ships, horses, hoplites, boats, a large population, and lots of money. [45]
		○ Sparta cannot win without a navy.  Their landpower is strong, but victory will require a navy. [45]
		○ Recommends that Sparta speak with Athens, don't provoke war, but use the time to build the resources, allies, and navy necessary to win against Athens. [46]
		○ War is a matter not so much of arms as money, which makes arms of use [46]
		○ Sparta should show patience, move slowly and deliberately 
		○ One should not proceed against a party who offers arbitration as one would against a wrongdoer. [47]
	• ''The Ephor Sthenelaidas demands Sparta go to war for honor's sake… basically calls Archidamus a pussy.''  [48]
"""

!!!Speech of Corinthians (p. 65-70)

"""
	• Corinth applauds Spartan vote for war and encourages all allies to join un in their mutual interest. [66]
	• Encourages the building of sea power to match Athens
	• They can also encourage Athenian colonies and allies to revolt and they can fortify Attica. [67]
	• Athens will become a tyrant state over all Hellas if they don't work together to defeat them. [67]
	• Corinthians call for a vote. [68] The vote is approved to go to war, but they need a year to prepare. [69]
	• Pericles opposed concessions to the Spartans. [70]
	• Spartans demand that the Athenians end the siege of Potidea, restore independence to Aegina, and rescind the Megarian Decree. Ultimatum to let the Hellenes be independent. [79]
"""

''Spartan Emissaries, Pericles Speech (p. 79-85)''

"""
	• No concessions to the Spartans…they never made an offer for arbitration as the treaty demands. [80]
	• Concessions will lead to slavery.
	• The Spartans are inexperienced at sea.  They cant afford to be away too long from home. They are farmers and have no money. They have parity with any force on land but cannot contend with a force that has power different from their own. [81]
	→ ''Don't fight them in a way that enables them to maximize their asymmetrical landpower. [81]
	· If we march against our country, we will sail against theirs. 
	· The superiority of seapower… primacy of seapower. '' 
	· The war is inevitable… wait until the Peloponnesians start hostilities.  Appeal to the glory of Athens. [83]
	· The Athenians vote for war. 








!!![[Book Seven: Thucydides]]

!!!Sicily, pt. VIII: Athens' Defeat (P. 455-472)
	
"""
	• 413 (19th year): Demosthenes urges a complete withdrawal from Sicily citing greater needs at home. [455]
	• Nicias disagrees knowing that he'll be killed back in Athens, also having received intel that the Syracusians were running out of cash. [455]
	• Syracusians decisively win a naval battle in the harbor.  Eurymedon is killed. [458]
	• The will and fighting spirit of the Syracusians dispirit the Athenians who have never been matched as well. [459]
	• Both forces are poised for major battle. Syracusians under Gylippus and Athens under Nicias. [467]
	• Athens is routed. [467]
	• 40,000 Athenians march out, encouraged by Nicias. [472]  They run low on provisions and are constantly harassed by the Syracusians. 
	• Syracusians overtake Demosthenes column. The remaining forces are routed, and Nicias surrenders to Gylippus. [477]
	• Both Demosthenes and Nicias were executed by the Syracusians.
"""

*Strategic miscalculation: 
** Bad Intel
** Bad assumptions & failure to challenge their assumptions 
** Honor… Young guys want to get their war on








!!![[Book Six: Thucydides]]

!!!Sicily, Pt. IV: Athens Debates an Expedition (p. 361, 365-379)

"""
	• Winter 416 (16th year): The Athenians are still stuck on stupid. Plan and arm a larger expedition to conquer Sicily. [361]
	• Sicily first inhabited by Cyclopes and Laestrygones (cannibals) [361]
	• Egestan envoys seek aid from Athens against Syracuse.  Promise to pay war expenses in Sicily. [365]
	• War continues in Argos and Macedonia.  [365]
	• Summer 415 (17th year): Athens votes to send a fleet to Sicily to aid Egesta.  Nicias put in command of expedition. [366]
		○ Nicias warns that it is imprudent to attack Sicily while affairs nearer home are still precarious. [367]  
		○ Argues that Sicily is too far away and unlikely to attack Athenian interests. [368]
		○ Having just recovered from plague, Athens should use the current peace to recuperate. [368]
		○ Urges the older peers to curb the enthusiasm of the young hotbloods. [369]  
		○ Claims that the expedition will be dangerous and will require significant expenditure of troops and ships. [375]
	→ ''Nicias never wanted command… urges the Athenians to not attack, yet is forced by duty to command a doomed expedition. The war-hawks rule the day.  Alcibiades, who was only out for himself and his personal glory, puts everything at risk for his ego.  What do you do when personal honor and duty conflict?  Quit?  That puts the forces under you in jeopardy.  Fight?  At least you remain in command and can try to salvage the mission. ''
	• Alcibiades argues for expedition to Sicily. [370]  His argument:
		○ He has the right to command the expedition through his magnificence and excellence. 
		○ He formed the recent coalition against Sparta. 
		○ Sicilians are politically weak and can be easily divided; barbarians will assist.  Spartan navy will never get to Sicily. [371]
		○ Athens prestige will increase if they attack Sicily.  They will exercise their force rather than risk atrophy. 
	• Vote passes to fund the expedition with Nicias and Alcibiades in command. [377]
"""

!!!Sicily, Pt. V: Initial Reaction to Athenian Expedition (p. 386-388)

"""
	• 415 (17th year): The Athenian expedition arrives with tons of supplies.  Are not concerned that most Sicilian markets will not serve them. [386]
	• Syracuse learns that the Athenians are at Rhegium and rush to prepare defenses. [386]
	• ''Egesta cannot provide Athens much support.  Rhegium refuses to join Athens. Nicias recommends that they settle the war with Selinus, display their power, and then return home. ''[387] 
"""

!!!Alcibiades Recalled (p. 395-396)

"""	
	• Athenians believe that Alcibiades is a traitor, and recall him to stand trial.  He sails for home, but goes to the Pelopennesus.  He is condemed to death in absentia. [395]
	• The Athenian expedition does little damage against the Sicilians. [396]
"""






!!![[Book Three: Thucydides]]

''The Revolt of the Mytilenes, Part 1 (p. 159-167)''

"""	
	• Summer 428: Peloponnesians invade Attica under the command of Archidamus. [159]
	• Lesbos revolts from the Athenians. [159]
	• Athenians send a fleet to Mytilene. [159]  A small naval engagement occurs, ending in an armistice. [160]  Mytilene sends envoys to Sparta. The Athenians begin a blockade of the island.  
	• The Athenians send another raiding fleet around the Peloponnesus and raided several areas. [161]
	• Mytilenian Envoys speak to the Spartans:
		○ They became allies with the Athenians after Sparta withdrew from the fight against the Persians.  Since then, their alliance was tolerable, as long as Athens was fighting against the Medes.  
		○ All of their allies who tried to be independent were enslaved by the Athenians. Their independence was a sham. [163]
		○ Request that the Spartans accept them as allies. [165]
		○ Lesbos is not far off, but when help is wanted she will be found near enough.  It is not in Attica that the war will be decided, as some imagine, but in the countries by which Attica is supported. [165]
		○ The Mytilenian navy will help the Spartans deny Athens of its allies. [165]  Lesbos was taken into alliance with the Peloponnesians. [166]
	• Sparta sends a fleet of 40 ships to Lesbos. Athens had the largest fleet on the waters with 100 guarding Attica, Euboea, and Salamis.  100 cruising around the Peloponnesus, and 50 guarding Potidaea. [166]
"""

''The Revolt of the Mytilenes, Part 2 (p. 171-184)''

"""
	• Summer 427: Spartans send out a fleet to Mytilene and also invade Attica. [171]
	• Mytilene supplies are running short and were compelled to come to terms with the Athenians.  They surrendered under conditions.   Meanwhile the Spartan fleet was taking it sweet-ass time getting there.  The Spartans learned of the surrender and came up with a COA. [172]
	• Alcidas decides to turn back.  He slaughters some prisoners and is rebuked for doing so. He releases the rest.  They are pursued by the Athenian commander Paches. [175]
	• Paches reconquers Lesbos for the Athenians. [175]
	• Cleon, a bloodthirsty Athenian, addresses the assembly. [176]
		○ ''Democracy is incapable of Empire… this is evident in Athenian decision to spare Mytilene. ''
		○ What the Mytilenes did wasn't revolt, it was deliberate and wanton aggression; an attempt to ruin Athens by siding with Sparta. [177]
		○ Cleon calls for severe punishment. 
	• Diodotus spoke against putting the Mytilenes to death. [179]
		○ ''Two things most opposed to good counsel is haste and passion.  Haste goes hand-in-hand with folly, Passion with coarseness. [179''
		○ As for the argument that speech ought not to be the exponent of action, the man who uses it must be either senseless or personally interested; senseless if he believes it possible to deal with the uncertain future through any other medium; interested if wishing to carry a disgraceful measure and doubting his ability to speak well in a bad cause. He thinks to frighten opponents and hearers by well-aimed calumny. [179]
		○ What's most important is not their guilt, but our interests. [180]
		○ People will transgress regardless of the punishment. [181]
		→ ''Dead people can't pay tribute. 
		→ The greatest of all power is restraint''
		· ''I consider it far more useful for the preservation of our empire to put up with injustice voluntarily, than to put to death, however justly, those whom it is our interest to keep alive… you can't be both just and expedient. [182]''
	• Diodotus's argument wins the vote. [183]
"""		

''Corcyraean Revolt; Sicily, Part 1 (p. 194-202)''

	"""
	• Corcyraean Revolt:
		○ Oligarchs declare Corcyraean neutrality. [195]  The oligarchs attack the people, but are defeated. The revolt goes on for five days, and the Peloponnesians arrive with their fleet. [196]
		○ The Corcyraean fleet rushed out to meet the Peloponnesians.  Along with Athenian ships, they launch a disorganized attack [196]
		○ The Peloponnesian fleet was organized and won the battle, pursuing the Corcyraeans. [198]
		○ The Peloponnesians ravaged the country but did not attack the city.  The sailed for home with their captured ships, begin pursued by a large Athenian fleet. [198]
		○ Civil war and disorder continued. [199]
		○ The Hellenic world was convulsed; struggles being everywhere made by the popular leaders to bring in the Athenians, and by the oligarchs to introduce the Spartans. [199]
		→ ''War morphing into a class struggle across Hellas. ''
		○ Hellenic society became divided into camps in which no man trusted his fellows. [200]
		○ Corcyraean revolution leads to famine and chronic civil strife. [201]
		
	· Winter 427/6: Plague returns to Athens. 
	· Athenians raid the Aeolian Islands. [203]
	· Peloponnesians renew attacks into Attica, but earthquakes prevent further attack. [204]
	· Summer 426, Athenians invade Aetolia, but are routed with heavy losses. 
	· Athenians attack Locris.  Spartans attack Naupactus, but the attack is thwarted. 
	· Athenians purify Delos and celebrate Delian games. 







!!![[Book Two: Thucydides]] from [[TWS 02]]

!!!Sparta's 1st Campaign (p. 93-107)

"""
	· With war on, Sparta sends envoys to barbarians, neutrals, and Italians, Sicilians. [93]
	· Zeal is always at its height at the commencement of an undertaking and on this particular occasion, the Peloponnesus and Athens were both full of young men whose inexperience made them eager to take up arms… excitement all over Hellas. [93]
	→ ''Fighting for honor and glory… living with the stories of their father's wars.  Manhood… they haven't seen the horrors of war yet.  Most of the old vets are probably dead. '' 
	· Most people wanted Sparta to win, so to not be absorbed into Athenian empire or to be free of Athenian rule. 
	→'' Athenians controlled all the choke points and controlled the entire rim of the Aegean Sea.  Interior lines. Going by sea is a straight line. ''
	· Sparta and allies assemble forces at the Isthmus of Corinth
	· Archidamus's Speech:
		○ Appeal to honor… lets not do less than what our fathers did. The hopes of all Hellas are with us. 
	· Peloponnesians attack into Attica, summer 431 BCE. [97] 
	· Pericles urges leveraging DIME. [98]
	· Athenians fortify into the city, while also building a fleet to invade the Peloponnesus. [100-101]
	· Spartans raze the farms, Athens rallies out against Pericles orders.  Athens raise the fleet to invade Sparta.  [104]
"""

!!!Pericles Funeral Oration (p. 110-118)

"""
	· Reminder of their fathers. 
	· Our way, our democracy is something new and unique in the world. [112]
	· Equality before the law. [112]
	· Athens is a beacon to the world, throwing its doors open to foreigners. [113]
	· Athens is a model society, building wealth and giving to the world freely its ideas and way of life. They are the school of Hellas. They are worthy to lead Hellas.  They are worthy of the men who died to build their nation. [114]
	· Comforts the parents of the dead, acknowledges their grief. They died with honor. [117]
"""
	
!!!Sparta's 2nd Campaign, Athens' Plague, Pericles Death (p. 122-128)
	· Peloponnesians ravage Attica [122]
	· Pericles leads an expedition to Epidaurus and nearby cities [122]
	· Plague strikes… mostly the fortified Delian League [123]
	· Delian League sues for peace, but Pericles gives a speech.
		○ Athenian naval supremacy enables freedom of maneuver
		○ Loss of farms and homes is trivial. 
		○ They still have better resources. [125]
		○ Stop parlaying with the Spartans and redouble war efforts. [126]
	· ''Had the Athenians did what Pericles recommended they would have won.  
		○ Pay attention to sea power, wait quietly, attempt no new conquests, don't expose Athens to hazards. [127]''

COL Warren: We need to make sure we're reflecting the multinational side of this. Are we accounting for our allies and partners that are going to participate?

COL Warren: I don't know. I never see him.
[[Todd]]: He's off conducting boomerang recertification.

!!![[Brett on Anchoring]]
"""
[[Eric]]: We are scheduled for two hours. I think this might take about 50 minutes, but I don't want to anchor your too badly.
[[Brett]]: I was thinking about 17, but 50 is fine.






!!![[Brett on Power vs Strength]] from [[NSPS 07]]

>I didn't like the way [[Hastedt]] talked about strength in the Presidency. It's probably hard to know how strong of a leader he is unless you are in the inner cirlce. He seemed to be focussed on the power of the President. But that is different. You can have a powerful leader who is still weak because it depends on how they use the power.






!!![[Brett on the F-18]]

>The F-18 is easy to fly. It is difficult to employ.
-[[Brett]] in [[SL 03]]






!!![[Brett on the Pirate's Code]] from [[NSPS 15]]

"""
Brett: The fourth bullet down says a new administration has 150 days to submit a new [[National Security Strategy|NSS]]. But that hasn't happened. So what does that mean if the current administration hasn't written one yet?
Frank: It took the Obama Administration almost two years. It took the Bush Administration almost two years. This isn't new.
Brett: I guess ''it's like the Pirate's Code: just a guideline.''






!!![[Brett vs Bob vs Scott]] from [[DM 12-13]]
"""
[[Scott]]: You know this room loves nuts.
[[Bob]]: Speak for yourself, Scott.
[[Scott]]: Everyone has had their hands in the nuts. Look at Brett.
[[Brett]]: Bob's always putting his hands in the nuts.






!!![[Brett vs Dave]] on [[Domains]]
"""
[[Dave]]: In the beginning there was land.
[[Brett]]: Wait! I thought the water came first?!?
[[Dave]]: See, we already have friction.






!!![[Brett vs Dave II]] from [[TSC 16]]
"""

[[Dave]]: Ok. Todd: Focus.

"""
[[Dave]]: I was flying a plane that was built in 1961. Think about that: Nine. Teen. Sixty. One.
[[Brett]]: I flew a Superhornet with 25 hours. Had that new car smell.

Brett: [makes a self evidentiary statement]
Frank: Well that's a tautology.
Brett: It could be! But I don't know what that means.

Frank: By Thursday afternoon, I'm sure I'll be looking at less.

!!!Lecture on Bernard [[Brodie]], 1910-1978, by [[Frank]]

>The strategic thinking since [[Clausewitz]] has been hazy.

There are three aspects that set the context.

# The technilogical change that had been happening
# He is a product of his environment. So he's trying to explain what can be observed in the security environment from 1946-1978.
# The dialog going on in the U.S. and the world between these thinkers, the Pentagon, the government, and the newspapers around the world.

He comes from the school of [[Realism]].

* There are values to international treaties and such, but they are limited.
* He thinks the deterrence value of these weapons will bring a better peace. [[Liddell Hart]]
* Will the suspicion between the great powers
* He's more concerned about [[Misperception]] lead to [[Miscalculation]]. And that can lead to a mass destruction event.
* This leads....

>Thus far the chief purpose of our military establishment has been to win wars. From now on its chief purpose....

The essence of deterrence is twofold:

#The existnece of a nuclear arsenal (and doctrines)
#The capacity to retaliate after a nuclear attack ("secure second-strike capability")

*Nuclear weapons promote stability in the international system; Nuclear war is the failure of strategy.

[[Brodie's Questions]]

---
Influence on Neorealist Thinking

*Primary causal determination of state behavior...
**Bipolar World
**The Nuke order prom
**General pattern of stability
**something....
---
Legacy and Relevance Today

[[Frank]]: still as relevant today as he was 40 years ago

*Maintenance of the US nuclear capability and protection of retaliatory capability are essential
**NATO and others under the "nuclear umbrella": ....
**
*Arems control treaties an be useful
*Mobilization concept suspect, "go-as-you-are warefare"
*Proliferation will occur because of the secuirty dilemma (competitive arms building)
*Doctrines are necessary to conduct effective offensive and defensive operations






From [[Frank]]'s Lecture on [[Brodie]]...

#What are the changing physical conditions....






!!![[Brodie's Tenets]]

*The Problem of Credibility (cannot deter "madmen")
*Uncertainty of Capability (Averversary)
*Psychological of deterrence (unpredictability of emotions in a crisis)
*Deterrence does not equal Winning wars Strategies
**Sliding scale of deterrence
*The Criticality of Retaliation
**Technological advancement
**Target seclection
*Offensive-Defensive Relationship (Deterrers vs. Warfighters)
**Limited War
**Escalation
*Choice of Weapons- high vs low yield
*Civil Defense and Vulnerability






The ability of a state to achieve its ends--to get what it wants--by the use of sheer strength and power. Simply put, taking what you want by force.

{{20th Maine}}






!!![[Change is harder with tree huggers]]
-[[MG Ferrari]]

>Change is hard. Change is harder with tree huggers. You know these people to chain themselves to a tree to stop the equipment from coming. There are those who chain themselves to their databases rather than give up the data.






!!![[Changing Minds in the Army]]

Why it's so difficult:

*Frames of Reference
*Openness
*Career Imprints
*Brain hard-wiring
*Individual Egocentrism
*Organizational culture

What the Army can do about it:

*Enhance self awareness
*Embrace continuous assesssment
*Require broadening assignments
*Interact with different people and diverse ideas






!!![[Changing Trends]] from [[TWS 16]]

*Multi-domain
*Inter-dependency
*[[Gray Zones]]
*Artificial Intelligence

See also: [[Enduring Trends]];  included in [[Nature vs Character of War]]






!!![[Character]], one of [[Three Ethical Lenses]] from [[SL 05]]

*Character (Virtue Ethics): What is acceptable and exceptional to live a good life? The actor’s being is morally decisive. Virtue ethics aims at developing the moral character of individuals as the community trains them and models virtue to build trust. This is the basis for the Army Ethic in [[ADRP-1]].
*Main Point: The community forms virtue / character; “I must be virtuous and    empower virtue in others...”  Not concerned with the result of actions themselves, but with the character that forms why the individual acted. For Aristotle, it was important to choose to live well and cultivate the right character traits through experience and the action in itself.
*Example: A leader’s personal example shapes their organization, the more senior the rank the more vital it is to internalize service virtues and lead by personal example.
*Caution: The main challenge to centering the Army Ethic on character is that virtue ethics is focused on what kind of person one should be not on what one should do or not do. Virtue ethics assumes that the community has a common moral foundation and that its virtues can be taught to “stick’ through training. These assumptions must always be challenged and proven valid. It is questionable how much of virtue ethics can be taught or is it “caught” through example or experience? How does one evaluate character and ethics? There is currently no model in DOD to evaluate a unit’s ethical environment. Personal evaluations state they assess the values of an individual but how is that assessment conducted and by what metrics? How does one teach character to formed adults that will face extreme circumstances? 






!![[China]]

<<list-links [tag[China]]>>






!!![[China vs America]]: Managing the Next Clash of Civilizations, by Graham [[Allison]], //Foreign Affairs//, Sep-Oct 2017

*Presentation by [[Phil]] during [[NSPS 06]]
*Thesis: Countries values, traditions, and philosophies will complex the system when China, the rising power, threatens to displace the United States, the established power.







!!![[China's Advance in Latin America]], [[Paul]]'s presentation in [[NSPS 16]]

*Article by Evan [[Ellis]]
*"The Strategic Context of China's Advance in Latin America: An Update", Aug 23, 2017






!!![[China's Century?]] Why America's Edge Will Endure, by Michael [[Beckley]]

*Presentation by [[Brett]] during [[NSPS 05]]
*Thesis: By comparing the US and China across a large set of economic, technological, and military indicators over the past twenty years, the US has not declined; in fact, it is now wealthier, more innovative, and more military powerful compared to China than it was in 1991.

[[Frank]]: Comments on [[World Orders]], context of unipolar vs hegemony.






!!![[China's Military Strategy]] presented in [[TWS 16]]

*Was this Jim's China Hawk presentation?

[[Frank]] highlight from last bullet in Section III: Strategic Guideline of Active Defense (pg 11):

>To actively expand military and security cooperation, deepen military relations with major powers, neighboring countries and other developing countries, and promote the establishment of a regional framework for security and cooperation.







!!![[Chinese on Desert Storm]]
-from [[Vice CJCS Lecture]]

*6 years after Desert Storm the Chinese wrote their first text giving their evaluation of what the US did in Desert Storm. They studied it more than you have. They said that we had employed information in a way that had never been done before.

!!![[Civil-Military Relations]], focus of [[NSPS 08]]

>"The interaction between the armed force of a state as an institution, and the other sectors of the society in which armed force is embedded." Fundamentally, "civil-military relations describe the interactions among the people of a state, the institutions of that state, and the military of the state."
-Marybeth [[Ulrich]] reading, pg 1

*One of the [[Enduring Trends]] from [[TWS 16]]
*See also [[TSC 06]]: [[Rapp Takeaway]], [[Providing Best Military Advice]]

!!Karl von Clausewitz

*Author of [[On War]]
*[[Clausewitz Quotes]]
*Need Vanya's lecture slide
*[[Clausewitz on Small Wars]]







!!![[Clausewitz Definition of Military Genius]]

>...the quick recognition of a truth that the mind would ordinarily miss or would perceive only after long study and reflection.
-[[Clausewitz]], [[On War Book One]] pg 102; reflecting on Coup d'oeil, inner eye, and commander's ability which must apply at the strategic as well as the tactical level







!!![[Clausewitz Definitions of War]]

Definition from [[On War Book One]]

p75

>War is nothing but a duel on a larger scale.
---
>War is thus an act of force to compel our enemy to do our will.
---
>Force...is thus the means of war, to impose our will on the enemy is the object.
---
pg 87 para 24:

>We see, therefore, that war is not merely an act of policy but a true political instrument, a continuation of political intercourse, carries on with other means.

Vanya says there is a mistake in the translation of the title. It reads "by other means", but he uses "mit" which makes it "with other means."

[[Vanya]]: Why does he use the two metaphors of "duel on a larger scale" and, in an origianl draft, poker?
One answer: They are both interactive.

---
---






!!![[Clausewitz Lecture]] by [[Vanya]] for [[TWS 06]]

[img[https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/ZjNIZUguIg7yt_41oLkTpA_NdKGtAQHcINtdlO87uT-IeDNo0uQpKvSYleq2Ri0b5toz00ddTT-sv4dzITsoPXjtnfIaY68kACeQcu8H18pgEUuC8a9-RzMt_dXhZOUWxhMqILiJbcQ]]

''Who was Clausewitz''
"""
• [[Clausewitz]] was the the youngest of four siblings to join the Prussian Army at age 11 (lied about being 12)
• Had to first serve as an NCO 
• Marched west to war against France
• Understood how it is to be a young man seeing combat for the first time. 
• Came of age during the French Revolution
• The French Revolution gave the middle class a chance to become officers.  This generations of guys were very audacious… They wanted to prove themselves. 
• The French Revolutionary army had a ton of people, and a lot of Elon. 
• Clausewitz studied warfare with Gerhard Von Scharnhorst.  He spotted Clausewitz's talent and sponsored him, mentored him. 
• Clausewitz ended up graduating at the top of his class. 
• After making MAJ, Napoleon invades into Prussia enroute to Russia.  
• Clausewitz and other officers opposed this policy, and he goes to fight with the Russians.
• 1813- Everyone allies to fight against Napoleon.  Clausewitz was a LTC at the time. 
• Clausewitz worked under many generals and he understood what it took to be a great commander.
• Clausewitz didn't fight in Waterloo.  He was up north fighting a force twice the size of his 3rd Army Corps.  They lost, but succeeded in delaying this force from reinforcing Napoleon at Waterloo.
"""

''Marie Von Clausewitz:''

"""
	• Came from the highest tier of society
	• Marie understood grand strategy.  She saw the societal reforms impacting the state. 
	• When Clausewitz defects to Russia, he left poor Marie at home to face the music. 
	• Marie had carried the On War manuscripts wherever she traveled. She published this as they were last bound. 
	• Marie was aware of the inconsistencies of the text.  She was cautious of over-editing. 
	• She understood that the work would be subject to criticism and misinterpretation.  These discussions are good things… Forces the reader to discover the truth themselves 
"""

''Napoleonic Wars:''

"""
*The Prussians lost terribly.  Yenna-Auershtadt was a debacle.  Clausewitz's unit fought bravely, but was captured.  This disaster ushered long needed political reforms, in turn military reforms, which eventually led to Prussia defeating Napoleon. 
*The Prussians were forced politically and militarily to reform.
*Nationalism for the state was encouraged and sparked. 
*Reforms:
**Landweier created
**Promotions by merit
**Corporal punishment abandoned.
**Scharnhorst made CoS of the Army
*After the Napoleonic Wars there was a backlash by the elite.  Reformers like Clausewitz became marginalized.  Therefore, he and others spent time writing. 
"""

''[[Theory]]''

"""
*German only has one word for policy and politics… Politik 
*Clausewitz never believed that politics should be rational.  He understood the irrationality of politics.  He meant both politics and policy. 
*German Romanticism deeply influenced Clausewitz.  He was a result of German enlightenment. 
**There is ambiguity in the world
**People are complex and irrational
**Everything is uncertain. 
**This is why Clausewitz doesn't like formulas or doctrine.
*Clausewitz wants to teach us how to think about war.
*Insights from his analyses of many campaigns throughout history were put into On War. 
*Began to think of ideals of war in a philosophical sense.  It's very hard to follow his thought. 
*[[Jomini]]'s "Cook Books"
*This book is a dialogue.  







!!![[Clausewitz Lecture: Echevarria]]
-by [[Echevarria]] for [[TWS 06]]

{{Clausewitz NTL Slides}}

BACKGROUND:
"""

	• Who was Clausewitz?
		○ Began soldiering at age 12
		○ Attended the German General Staff College
		○ Been to war several times, served in Austrian Army, fought against Napoleon
		○ Tried to reform the Prussian Army
		○ Early 19th century speech writer
		○ Leaves the Prussian Army and joins the Russian Army against Napoleon
		○ Restored to the Prussian Army and was the CoS of 3rd Corps
		○ Writes a lot of campaign analyses
		
	• What was his core theory?
		○ Clausewitz arch enemy for war theory is Adam Bulow.  His geometric principles were at odds with Clausewitz's
		○ Jomini's theories are also at odds with Clausewitz
		○ The spirit of modern war
			§ Hostility: use of violence to achieve political ends
			§ Warlike passions unleashed
			§ Captured, leveraged in a national or people's army 
			§ A people's army enables military commanders to be more creative and daring
			§ Political leaders pursue conquest
		○ Greater military efficiency by building a nationalistic, standing state military (in the French style)
		○ Moves away a bit from a model of Napoleonic War

THE TRINITY

	• Wondrous Trinity
		○ Chance- Military 
		○ Passion- Populace (enmity, hostility)
		○ Purpose- Government
	• Requires answering three questions
		○ What's the nature of the civil societies involved?
		○ What's the nature of the opposing militaries?
		○ What's the nature of the opposing political organizations and their aims?
	• Significance of Trinity
		○ It represents the main forces and institutions that shape war's conduct







!!![[Clausewitz Moral Factors]]

>Another reason for not placing moral factors beyond the scope of theory is their relation to all other so-called rules. The effects of physical and psychological factors form an organic whole which, unlike a metal alloy, is inseparable by chemical process. ... Hence most of the matters dealt with in this book are composed in equal parts of physical and of moral causes and effects. One might say that the physical seem little more than the wooden hilt, while the moral factors are the precious metal, the real weapon, the finally honed blade.

-[[On War Book Three]] Chapter 3, pg 184.

-Class commentary that 'moral' could be better read as "morale" to understand the point.






!!![[Clausewitz NTL Slides]], From [[Clausewitz Lecture: Echevarria]], [[TWS 06]]

<iframe src="https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/e/2PACX-1vQFoXE0bExxbxzeasRhZ5yCCDhSJmnbFVgxN2o7QLEiMt2yn-SIIPevZkjzs8dM_1RFMIBu-fKk4kka/embed?start=false&loop=false&delayms=3000" frameborder="0" width="960" height="449" allowfullscreen="true" mozallowfullscreen="true" webkitallowfullscreen="true"></iframe>






!!![[Clausewitz on Small Wars]]

Book Six from Ch 26 of [[On War]]

!!!When can insurgencies succeed? (pg 480)

*Fought in the interior of the country
*Not decided by a single stroke
*"Fairly large" theater of operations
*"National character" suited to insurgency
*Rough and inaccessible terrain

{{Clausewitz's Advice for People's War}}

What's not in these lists? [[Leadership]]

*[[Clausewitz]] taught a course on "Small War" 1810-1812. (//Der kliene Krieg//)
**First course in the curriculum because even at the height of Napoleon study, he wanted to challenge the assumption that large decisive battles are the default form of warfare
*Based on [[Johann von Ewald]]. Fought in the American Revolution on the British side. (Hessian). He accused the British of alienating the population. He was later revered by the Americans and was brought to West Point (??) to give lecturers.

{{Clausewitz's Two Small War Methods}}







!!![[Clausewitz on Theory]]

>The primary purpose of theory is to clarify concepts and ideas that have become, as it were, confused and tangled.  Not until terms and concepts have been defined can one hope to make progress in examining the question clearly and simply and expect the reader to share one’s views.”
- [[Clausewitz]], On War, 132






!![[Clausewitz Quotes]]

<$list filter="[tag[Clausewitz]tag[Quote]]">
<$transclude mode="block"/>
</$list>






!!![[Clausewitz Theory Insight]]

>Theory cannot equip the mind with formulas for solving problems, nor can it mark the narrow path on which the sole solution is supposed to lie by planting a hedge of principles on either side.  But it can give the mind insight into the great mass of phenomena and of their relationships, then leave it free to rise into the higher realms of action.
- [[Clausewitz]], [[On War]], 578






[[Clausewitz vs Joint Pubs]] from [[TWS 05]]

>[[Clausewitz]] always give great context. Historical context. I'd rather read Clausewitz than Joint Pubs.
-[[Todd]]






!!![[Clausewitz vs Jomini]]
"""
[[Scott]]: I was surprised at how much [[Jomini]] talked about the importance of the population and political outcomes. Everyone seems to indicating that Jomini would be so different than [[Clausewitz]], but that isn't true.
[[Ed]]: Jomini and Clausewitz were mostly looking at two different systems. Jomini was attempting to best explain the military system. Clausewitz is more interested in describing the poltical-military system. It's two different things, but they aren't necessarily : 
[[Jim]]: Since both of these guys talked about the population, and so did [[Thucydides]], and so did [[Kautilya]], and that happened over huge chunks of time and very different cultures, then I think we can identify this as an [[Enduring Theme|Enduring Trends]].






!!![[Clausewitz vs. Brodie Trinities]]






!!![[Clausewitz's Advice for People's War]]

*Disperse
*Attack opponent's lines of communication
*Avoid enemy's main units
*Mass only when you can win
*Attack small units
*Support from regular units necessary






!!![[Clausewitz's Trinity]] from [[On War Book One]], [[TWS 06]]

* PASSION/Enimity/Hostility (Populace)
* CHANCE & PROBABILITY (Military)
* REASON (Government)

//Why does he not orient this only on Population, Military, and Government? Because this isn't always the case. For instance, in a popular uprising the people are the military force.//

* What is the nature of the civil societies involved?
* What is the nature of the opposing militaries?
* What is the nature of the opposing political organizations and their aims?

//Clausewitz compared the Prussians vs French in terms of Populace, Military, and Government during the Napoleonic era and determined the French were superior in all three.//






!!![[Clausewitz's Two Small War Methods]]

*Outposts--small units closely supporting regular army
*Detachment War--deep into the enemy's territory

(From [[TWS 14]])






!!![[Climate]]: Beliefs, values and norms translated into daily habits across the workplace. (See [[Culture vs. Climate]])








!!![[Climate defined by Jones]]

>Climate  is  a  complex  construct  composed  of  perceptions  about  organizational  structure, communications, allocation of responsibilities, rewards, risk-taking, warmth and support, performance standards,  acknowledgement  of  conflicts,  and  identification, 17demonstrating  a  strong  correlation with job satisfaction (r=.61)
-[[Jones]] reading, pg 3, from [[SL 14]]

See also [[Culture]] and [[Culture vs. Climate]]






!!![[COA]]: Course of Action, see [[JPP]]






!!![[COA Validity]] from [[TSC 24]], See also [[SAF-R]]

*Adequate: accomplishes the mission within the commander's guidance (ENDS focus)
*Acceptable: balances cost and [[Risk]] with the advantage gained (WAYS focus)
*Feasible: within the allotted time, space, and resource limitations (MEANS focus)
*Distinguishable: is sufficiently different from the other COAs
*Complete: answers who, what, where, when, how, and why?






!!![[Coalition]] from [[TSC 18]], [[JP 1-02]]

>An ad hoc arrangement between two or more nations for common action.
-example: [[Desert Storm]]; see also [[Alliance]]






!!Coerce: Cause an adversary to change his potential or actual course of action.

Two sub-components according to [[Troxell]]: [[Deter]] and [[Compel]]






!!![[Coercive Airpower]]
The Need for Analysis and Intelligence

*What is the sturcture of the adversary's society? Government/Leadership? War-fighting force?
*What is the will of the leadership--and the people--to endure punishment and coercive pressure via air power
*Can the adversary's government (or leadership) suppress dissent? By which mechanisms?
*Can the adversary's government (or leadership) displace coercive pain on to the population? How?
*Can enemy warfighters find refuge in terrain? In cities? How might they thwart your advantages, inc. precision and aerial dominance?
*Which resources do enemy warfighters rely upon? How quickly do they burn those resources?

!!![[Cold War Chapter 2: Containment]]

<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/7vdXLkWUjrU" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen style="width:100%;height:350px;"/>






!!![[Colonels Do Three Things]]
-[[MG Ferrari]] during [[Lecture on Army Budget]]

#Colonels drive change. If you are running things day to day, the organzation will not change. You have to choose how you spend your time and 
#The second things leaders do is grow other leaders. If you are not spending time with leaders in your organization or other organizations you are doing something  wrong. What I've found is when things get busy leader development falls by the wayside.
#Leaders spend time communicating outward and upward. You organization is but a small cog in a bigger machine. As the leader, your success in that machine is based on how well you play with other leaders. If you have trained your subordinates to run that organization, then you wil have time to communicate.






!!![[Combined]] from [[TSC 18]], [[JP 1-02]]

>Two or more forces or agencies of two or more [[Aliies|Alliance]]

1: COCOM Cdr "take a fresh look at the current theater campaign strategy"

Documents, Factors, and Information

*Documents:

1- Look at campaign documents
2- Look at guidance docs
3- Look at current plans
4- Enemy plans and objectives
5- External influencers and players (Congress, etc.; informal guidance; think tanks)

*Intel Factors
**Existing national intelligence estimate
**Latest regional intel estimates

*Formal Guidance
** NSS, NDS, NMS

*Presidential and National Guidance
**NSS talks about Africa objectives, but other indicators is this isn't a big focus
**DoS in the AOR

*Means/Resources
**High use of SOF, but there is high demand everywhere ==> Need to understand the apportionment plan globally
**Resources and funding have to be balanced against global demands
**China is also providing resourcing impacts in the AOR

Conclusion: what we told you.






Compare and contrast released [[NDS]]. How does this tie in national interests, purpose, and [[International Order]]. (Mark, Phil, John)

*Outline of NDS itself.
*Risks
**It anchors the reader into a [[Realism]] perspective.
**Holding partners accountable: How will partners look at this guidance. (Stakeholders)
**Expensive. Resource intensive. What are the tradeoffs
*What are the vehicles available?
**The Interagency
**Development of partners and allies
*How does it align with the future security environment?
**Chairman: Joint Operating Environment 2035 reflects the NDS. 2+2+1. [[Complex]] security environment.
**Chairman's Risk Assessment: Goes through each of the 5 threats and considers what the risks are.
**End of the American post war dominance.
**[[Great Power Competition]]

!!!How and for what purpose do you believe future warfare will be conducted given international norms, the variety of institutions in the strategic environment and the theory you studied? What factors influence attaining a nation's national security objectives in the conflict? Lastly, how will a nation know that it has attained "victory" in the contemporary security environment. 

Frank strategy comment: Make the links that you want to link. There are lots of threads. Find the ones you want to weave together. Also, take this from an environment perspective. Start with [[Thucydides]] or [[Clausewitz]] and build from that. So "chunking" is not as effective on this one, because then you're fishing for linkages between the chunks. So start with the concrete and then build out.

Frank's Options for starting:

*[[IR Theory]] schools. He'd do [[Liberalism]]. You could start with [[Realism]].
*You could start with vital [[Levels of Interest]]

*[[Policy Formulation Model]]
*[[Geopolitical Factors]]
*Difference between victory, [[Conflict Termination]], and [[Conflict Resolution]]

!!![[Competition in Shaping Policy]] from [[NSPS 15]]
>According to the second view, however, governments do no decide on the basis of such a grand calculus. Instead, various agencies and individuals in each nation compete in shaping policy, while pursuing their own interests and relying on their divergent estimates of friendly and enemy strengths.
-pg 14 of [[Every War Must End]] by [[Ikle]]

*Open boundaries
*Large number of agents or resources
*Diverse agents and behaviors, or resources 
*Dense network structure

!!![[Congress Roles in Foreign Policy]] from [[NSPP 07]], from [[Hastedt]]

*Competitive: both active and assertive
*Disengaged: neither active nor assertive, follows president's lead
*Supportive: active but not assertive, cooperates without challenging president
*Strategic: not active but asserts its perrogatives on specific issues.

[[Frank]]: The problem here is that this assumes Congress is a unitary body. They are not. They different members will be all over the map.






!!![[Congressional Budget Office]]
-[[2017 Long-Term Budget Outlook]] for [[DM 03]]






!!![[Congressional Powers and Tools]] from [[NSPP 07]]

Powers:

* Advice and consent
*Confirmation of presidential appointments
*War powers
*Power to regulated commerce

Tools:

*Legislative powers
*Bdgetary power
*Oversight






!!![[Consequences]], one of [[Three Ethical Lenses]] from [[SL 05]]

*Consequences (teleology): The most popular form of consequential ethics is called Utilitarianism. Per its name, the system calls actors to choose what is useful or brings the greatest amount of utility to the majority of those influenced by the decision? As the focus of utilitarianism is on the consequences over and above how one reaches those consequences, this is the system that gives birth to the phrase “the ends justify the means.” Utilitarianism has two primary forms:
**“Act Utilitarianism:” A particular act, not the consequences of an act, is right only if it results in as much good as any viable alternative.
**"Rule Utilitarianism:” An act is right if it is required by a rule whose acceptance would lead to greater utility for society alternative. The “rule” is based on the probability a good end will be reached, as opposed to a principle.
*Main Point: Develop consensus among stakeholders to acquire the most fitting means available to benefit the most people possible. Actions by themselves have no moral value, only the outcome.
*Example: In prosecuting WWII, the Allies chose to purposely resource Europe over the Pacific to support the coalition and grow its base while acknowledging that sacrifices would be made in the Pacific theatre.
*Caution: Utilitarianism fails to capture the moral cost and moral injury done to individuals and to society when we violate binding morals rules; it does not rule out any type of action and can have serious second and third order effects.  












!!![[Constructivism]] as part of [[IR Theory]]

*States act based on their culture, their history, their geography
*Better accounts for changes over time and space
*More difficult to anticipate results
*A North Korean nuke is a threat to the US; a British nuke is not. This is primarily because the US reads the British and North Koreans through different cultural and historical lenses

{{Constructivism Video}}

!!Martin L. [[Cook]] from [[TWS 08]]

Martin L. Cook, "Ethical Issues in War: An Overview,” in J. Boone Bartholomees, Jr., ed. U.S. Army War College Guide to National Security Issues, 5th ed., vol. II: National Security Policy and Strategy (Carlisle Barracks, PA: Strategic Studies Institute, U.S. Army War College, July 2012), 






!!Julian S. [[Corbett]] (1854-1922)

*Wrote [[Principles of Maritime Strategy, 1911]].
*Influences British adn U.S. naval doctrine
*Clausewitzian in approach: political objective, limited war, influence events on land
*Maritime strategy, with focus on [[Joint Operations]]
*Sea //contro//, not //command// of the sea
---
*British naval historian and analyst
*Trained as a barrister; novelist and journalist (not a military guy)
**Training as a lawyer explains why his writing is very precise with specific use of language
*Lecturer at British Naval War College
*Unofficial advisor to the Admiralty and secretary of the Cabinet Historical Office
*Close friend and supporter to Adm Sir Jackie Fisher
*Wrote the official history of British naval operations in WWI

[[The Longest Purse]]

[[Frank]]'s question: Compare and contrast [[Mahan]] and [[Corbett]]. Mahan talks about "seafaring cultures." What is Corbett saying? A: We are looking at the nature of economies. ... This goes back to [[Howard]] and [[Just War Theory]]. Corbett was writing from a point in time in history. It is an island nation with enemies on the Continent. So they think of the sea as both a buffer zone and a necessary way of supporting your allies.
---
(Confirm?): Corbett said something to the effect that the only way to find out how well prepared the military forces are is if they go head to head.
---
What are the [[Problem's with Corbett's Theory]]?

<<list-links [tag[Course]]>>






!!![[Crafting National Interests]] by [[Stolberg]] in [[NSPS 01]]

Interests are essential to establishing the objectives or ends that serve as the goals for policy and strategy. “Interests are the foundation and starting point for policy prescriptions.” They help answer questions concerning why a policy is important. National interests also help to determine the types and amounts of national power employed as the means to implement a designated policy or strategy. [13] 

Interests: that which is deemed by a particular state (actor) to be a . . . desirable goal.” The attainment of this goal is something the identifying state believes will have a positive impact on itself. Realization of the interest could enhance the political, economic, security, environmental, and/or moral well-being of a populace and the associated state (actor) or national enterprise. [14] 

Interests serve as the foundation and guiding direction for the formulation of policy. For a nation-state, there is more often than not a direct correlation between the nation’s interests and foreign policy. [15] 

Morgenthau indicated that the key concept of interest is not to be defined “with a meaning that is fixed once and for all.” He believed the generic concept of interest was unchanging in terms of its importance to the international system. [15] 

For purposes of 21st-century America, these three core interests may be elaborated as follows: 

Security: “Protection of the people (both home and abroad), territory, and institutions of the United States against potential foreign dangers. [16] 

Economic Well-Being: “Promotion of [American] international trade and investment, including protection of United States private economic interests in foreign countries. [16] 

Democratic Values: Until the 20th century, this core interest was confined to ensuring that the domestic democratic process and associated values framed the traditional American tenets of “life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness. [16] 

Stable and Secure World Order: A favorable world order based on the “establishment of a peaceful international environment in which disputes between nations can be resolved without resort to war and in which collective security rather than unilateral action is employed to deter or cope with aggression. [16] 

''4 Categories of Interests:''

Survival: These represent the single most important interests for any actor. This is the very essence of the actor’s existence—the protection of its citizens and their institutions from attack by enemies, both foreign and domestic. [17] 

Vital: A vital interest exists when an issue is so important to an actor’s well-being that its leadership can compromise only up to a certain point. Beyond that point, compromise is no longer possible because the potential harm to the actor would no longer be tolerable. [19] 

Important: These interests would be significant but not crucial to the actor’s well-being. Damage to them could cause serious concern and harm to the actor’s overseas interests, and even though the result may be somewhat painful, would much more likely be resolved with compromise and negotiation, rather than confrontation. 

Peripheral: These interests involve neither a threat to the actor’s security nor to the well-being of its populace.  

These criteria must be addressed during the course of the process of crafting interests: [21] 

Interests should be designed to tell the policymaker why and how much he should care about an issue. Part of this is framed by the determination of where realism and morality fit in the process. 

They must help determine what kind and how much attention should be given to challenges or threats, as well as opportunities. 

They must assist the policymaker in identifying key questions to address during the policy formulation process.

!!![[Critical Capability]], see also [[Center of Gravity]]

>A means that is considered a crucial enabler for a [[COG]] to function as such, and is essential to the accomplishment of the specified or assumed objectives(s)
-[[JP 5-0]]






!!![[Critical Requirement]], See also [[Center of Gravity]]

>An essential condition, resource, and means for a critical capability to be fully operational.
-[[JP 5-0]]






!!![[Critical Thinking]]

>Critical thinking is the use of those cognitive skills or strategies that increase the probability of a desirable outcome. It is used to describe thinking that is purposeful, reasoned, and goal oriented.
-Diane Halpern, as quoted on page C-3 in [[Gerras]]'s [[article on Critical Thinking|https://drive.google.com/open?id=0Bx33V4OXisHbVGxRc25pRUVILW8]] 






!!![[Critical Vulnerability]], see also [[Center of Gravity]], [[TSC 04]]

>An aspect of a [[Critical Requirement]] which is defiecient or vulnerable to direct or indirect attack that will create decisive or significant effects.
-[[JP 5-0]]

!!![[Culture]]: The link between individual performance and the atmosphere of the organization that shapes the quality, and effectiveness of the individual, and the organization’s processes and outcomes. (See [[Culture vs. Climate]])






!!![[Culture vs. Climate]]

{{Culture||slider}}

{{Climate||slider}}

[[Eric]]: A platoon leader is not going to change the culture of a platoon. He may change the climate. He may put a few things in motion. But the culture is captured within the culture of the Army.

[[Scott]]: A [[Climate]] can change almost immediately with new leader actions. [[Culture]] cannot change immediately because it is underlying beliefs. For example, customs and curtesies may be understood to be important. But the climate could be good or bad depending on how it's enforced.  If there is an aggressive enforcement mechanism then it may be a terrible climate, or that could be reversed, but it's the same culture.






!!![[CYBERCOM Commander's Vision]] from [[Cyberspace Lecture]]

*It's important that cyber is seen as one means to achieve an effect out of many means available
*Mission: Ensure DoD mission assurance => deter or defeat strategic threats => Achieve JF Cdr objectives
*Imperatives: ... => Operationalize the cyber mission set
**Because tech moves so fast, there is a focus on training concepts and not just "stuff".
*Enablers

*National roles and responsibilities
**DoD: lead for National Defense. When called on by POTUS, they can respond to foreign threats. Attribution is critical to this role.
**DHS: Lead for Protections
**DoJ/FBI: Lead for Investigative enforcement

{{CYBERCOM Commander's Vision}}
---
Organizational Structure Notes
[[USSTRATCOM]] => [[USCYBERCOM]]
*JFHQ-DODIN: Joing Force Headquarters-DOD Information Networks (DISA), the .mil domain
*Five service cyber commands

And:

*Three types of forces: frames the capabilities that the services/personnel are tasked to provide
**National Mission Forces. Oour Offense vs. Their Offense. 21 teams.
**Combat Mission Forces. Focused on COCOM Requirements. 44 teams.
**Cyber Protection Forces.. Defend and Secure DoD Infrastructure + Suport for Protecting DoD networks. 68 teams.
*133 teams; 6,000 people; FOC by 30 Sep 2018

>When I think about National Security, I think about the [[Nature vs Character of War]]. It is changing constantly. There are some fundamentals. But there a lot of important details that are changing.






[[Deb]] ,,(see DebPic),,

[img[https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/-8YD4KmOd0Kc97-DXKz6-rD04VmCW2U0r78j19wpjKVPZkcMBfWn65SjbdiaIU3qToO0gCrI02sbzwgc5g7T8BOWe6VUsNEt_b-B9gxXf5VRusg7eHxKOIREUktmCr-kFR5qAc_IFAY=w2400]]






!!![[Decision-Making Models]] from [[NSPS 05]], based on [[Houghton]] in [[The Decision Point]]

|''Model''|''Homoeconomicus''|''Homobeaurocraticus''|
|''Unit of Analysis''|State(personification|Organization|
|''Assumptions''|States are raional, unitary actors; Orderly decision process with perfect information|Competing actors pursuing different objectives and priorities; Policy making is not entirely rational|
|''Major Concepts''|Cost-benefit; update analysis with new information|Organizations operate under their own logic and culture; Decisions are the result of organizational routines or power|
|''Dominant Inferrence Pattern (How resolved)''|Decision makers collectively select alternative which delivers greatest neefit relative to cost (Rational Actor Model)|Consensus/Compromise and Bargains; Lowest Common Denominator (hopefully highest common multiple|

|''Model''|''Homosociological''|''Homopsychologicus''|
|''Unit of Analysis''|Group|Individual|
|''Assumptions''|Decisions are made in groups; Social pressures toward conformity (groupthink)|Leaders matter, peronalities and emotions; People use [[Heuristics]] to make decisions|
|''Major Concepts''|Group decision-making lends legitimacy; Group-think is protected by self-censorship and mind-guarding|Hisotrical references fram decisions; Contrary info causes cognitive dissonance and is rejected|
|''Dominant Inferrence Pattern (How resolved)''|Standards and norms set by leader for group decision to allow dissent; Diversity in groups|Leader and subordinates need to be aware fo how leader makes decision and processes info|

!!![[Definitions for Ethical Reasoning]] from [[SL 05]]

1.  Ethic: a system of moral principles or values, rules, or standards of conduct governing members of a particular context and community, i.e., profession (decisions/actions/inactions); practical application.

2.  Ethics: the intellectual discipline that studies right and wrong, good and bad; examines how people make moral judgments and they are justified in particular contexts and communities.

3.  Ethical: Conforming to accepted principles of right and wrong that govern the members of a particular class of human actions or a particular group or culture, i.e., profession; used in the particular sense.

4.  The Army Ethic: the evolving set of laws, values, and beliefs embedded within the Army culture of trust that motivates and guides the conduct of Army professionals bound together in common moral purpose.

5.  Ethos: character, disposition, or basic values peculiar to a specific people, culture, or movement.

6.  Morals: principles, authoritative beliefs, practices, and habits of conduct concerning right and wrong/good and bad; the character and conduct of people in actual life situations (also called conscience by some); used in the broadest sense.

7.  Morality: the foundation and objective of ethical systems, codes, norms, and expectations for conduct within particular communities or organizations.  

8.  Immoral: contrary to accepted moral principles.

9.  Laws: binding rules and policies for a community that often functions as a baseline through prohibition or punishment; the minimum accepted standards. 10. Values: the principles, standards, behavior or qualities deemed worthwhile or desirable; what is important in life; what provides purpose and or motivation; forms the principles of a defined ethic and the foundation of character.

11. Character: the combination of emotional, intellectual, and moral qualities distinguishing one person or group from another; moral or ethical strength i.e., integrity.

12. Virtue: moral excellence and righteousness i.e., goodness; example of moral excellence or righteousness i.e., virtue of generosity.

13. Virtuous: moral choices arising from conscience; the sense of right and wrong as in moral duty.

14. Moral Exemplars: people who display personal courage by standing up for and acting upon honorable values.

15. Integrity: firm adherence to a code or standard of values.

>The Chairman's role is as the dash. And that dash is the hypen beween "civil" and "military"
-Bob's recollection of the quote from Dempsey

*See also [[Providing Best Military Advice]]

<iframe src="https://www.stripes.com/dempsey-lays-out-military-options-for-us-in-syria-1.231651" frameborder="0" width="960" height="675" allowfullscreen="true" mozallowfullscreen="true" webkitallowfullscreen="true"></iframe>






!!![[Design]] from [[TSC]]






Book by Graham [[Allison]]






!!!Deter: Avert deleterious actions on the part of an adversary.

Component, along with [[Compel]], of [[Coerce]]






!!![[Deterrence]]

*''Deterrence: Persuade an opponent not to do something''
**Involves both calculation and fear
**What is the role of strategic ambiguity? Of clear declarations?

vs:

---
{{Compellence}}
---

*Is deterrence easier than compellence? If so, why?
*Is reputation critical to deterrence? Why?
*What are the risks/costs associated with maintaining or losing a reputation?

See also: [[Mattis on Nukes]]

See also snark: [[Discussing Trident]], [[Acceptable Civilian Casualties]], and [[Strangelove's Definition of Deterrence]]

!!![[Dex & Nicole]]

[img[https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/axIdl9gvP_o0QiF7l1wLdgsqNRUo8r_zQ4Bpms3MFH8FjGE3MNcZHWB6cXGfTFKMxpQBAnJ_VYSKqH3ufKMSi687XlT96JzfCo5r0qEmMx3fbRa2TPfo4Csf3XeZoQYcJeplYBVAZRI=w2400]]






!!![[Dex on Human Rights Discussions]] from [[NSPS 16]]

>...so when the U.S. State Department goes in to some of these countries and says, 'Hey! You're human rights situation isn't all that great....' ''...and blah blah blah...''
-[[Dex]] "Blah Blah Blah" Nunnally






!!![[Dex on Leader Creativity]] from [[SL 02]]

>I don't think we should see Creativity by senior leaders the same way we think of artists being Creative, like Michael Jackson or Prince. ...There was a lot in the reading about creative thinking, but not as much on [[Critical Thinking]].
-[[Dex]] from Discussion: Leaders that pick through a bunch of partial solutions and providing direction on how to fit the options together is still a form of creativity.






!!![[Dex on not-Phase-Zero]]
-From [[DM 07]] (and again in [[DM 09]])

"""
[[Dex]]: I think part of what's happening with this breaking apart of TRADOC is that (per [[Eric]]'s refrain that the organization is no longer in alignment with its new environment) is that [[Great Power Competition]] is no longer about Phasing. There is no Phase 0. We're in an era of [[Adversarial Competition]]. We need to see ourselves differently.
[[Todd]]: Good point. The institution likes to see itself as either in war or in an interwar period. This is technically an interwar period. But we're still always competing below the level of war.






!!![[Dex on Parts Flow]] from [[TSC 05]]
"""
[[Todd]]: So think about a contested cyber environment in regard to parts flow. So one group is looking at some system, //think// they've sent the parts, but they weren't. And the group that ordered them is looking and also thinking the parts are on the way.
[[Dex]]: Yeah, but that's routine! It's always like that!






!!![[Dex on Private Company Cyberspace Norming]] from [[TSC 13]]
-Comment from [[Scott]]'s presentation on [[North Korea's Cybervandalism]]

Q: "If Amazon decides to launch their own cyber offensive--and they have the resources--who is going to norm that system so that private organizations aren't screwing up the entire system?

[[Dex]]: The thing about private companies is that if they overplay their hand, and their actions extend beyond their target possibly all over the world, they will suffer all kinds of consequences for that. So they will have to norm themselves to avoid the liabilties and economic consequences.






!!![[Dex vs MacArthur]]

>I cannot for the life of me figure out how we have a leadership award named after MacArthur given what he did at the end of his career. Some people say, 'Well it doesn't negate all the other things he did up until that point.' Well, yeah. But after all that, he basically told the President to go **** himself.






!!![[Dex's G6 Network Concern]] from [[TSC 13]]

>My concern as a G6 was not whether the Chinese are trying to get into the network so much as that you aren't //helping// the Chinese to get into the network.
-[[Dex]]






!!![[Dex's USAF Freudian Slip]]

>I've worked at NORTHCOM. And it's interesting to see how the Air Force interacts with their Airmen compared to us in the military.
-[[Dex]] in response to an article where an Air Force Major suggested getting rid of rank






[[Dex]] ,,(see DexPic),,

[img[https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/bCr29mIULVwpecXo2jcQeKWgV6v8iyPW6sAq6to3uFDkYEI-QEHyFol-BW-LuObzSiHKxqNigFWxuOxcfUnSKRoVlGwV4IEoZrA2AxMt-fk1pbSwfQLzhAIi5tKm9ySRpQdeXJ7cpfQ=w2400]]












!!![[Difficulty vs Doubt]]

>When in difficulty, delegate. When in doubt, mumble.
-[[LtGen Sanders]]






{{Instuments of National Power}}






!!![[Disciplined Initiative]], part of [[Mission Command]] in [[SL 11]]
"""
[[Jim]] It's a two way street. Leaders need to empower subordinates to exercise initiative where they are able. Subordinates have to have the discipline and understand the intent and not get so far out that they screw up the mission with their initiative.
[[Todd]]: I am exercising disciplined initiative because I also understand my commander's risk tolerance.
[[Eric]]: Disciplined initiative is seizing opportunity within your authority.

!!!Dissuasion: Persuading others not to take actions harmful to oneself
See: [[Troxell]], pg 9

!!![[DM 03 Readings]], [[DM 03]]

Required Readings.
(1) Douglas E. [[Waters]], “[[National-level Challenges Affecting Defense]],” in Defense
Management Primer (In Press), ed. Thomas P. Galvin (Carlisle Barracks, PA:
Department of Command, Leadership and Management, n.d.). (Read 25-31; Scan
rest) [Blackboard]

(2) Harold W. [[Lord]], “[[Authorization or Appropriation]],” Faculty Paper (Carlisle
Barracks, PA: U.S. Army War College, April 16, 2012). (Read pp. 1-11) [Blackboard]

(3) [[Congressional Budget Office]], The [[2017 Long-Term Budget Outlook]]
(Washington, DC: U.S. Government Printing Office, March 2017), 1-7,
https://www.cbo.gov/system/files/115th-congress-2017-2018/reports/52480-ltbo.pdf
(accessed November 8, 2017). [Blackboard] [Online]

(4) Donald B. [[Marron]], “[[America in the Red]],” National Affairs, no. 3 (Spring 2010):
http://www.nationalaffairs.com/publications/detail/america-in-the-red (accessed
December 5, 2016). (Read ONLY 6-19) [Online]

(5) Drew Desilver, “The Polarized Congress of Today Has its Roots in the 1970s,”
June 2, 2014, http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2014/06/12/polarized-politics-in-
congress-began-in-the-1970s-and-has-been-getting-worse-ever-since/ (accessed November 8, 2017). [Online]

(6) Scott Maucione, "Vice Chairman of Joint Chiefs Selva Tells Congress off over CR issues," Federal News Radio, April 14, 2017, https://federalnewsradio.com/defense-
news/2017/04/vice-chairman-joint-chiefs-selva-tells-congress-off-cr-issues/ (accessed November 13, 2017). [Online]

(7) [[Peter G. Peterson Foundation]], “Strength at Home and Abroad: [[Ensuring America’s Fiscal and National Security]]: A New Statement from the Coalition for Fiscal and National Security,” May 10, 2016, https://www.pgpf.org/finding-solutions/national-security/ (accessed November 9, 2017). [Online]

c. Focused Reading.
(1) Carroll Doherty, “Key Takeaways on Americans’ Growing Partisan Divide over Political Values,” October 5, 2017, http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-
tank/2017/10/05/takeaways-on-americans-growing-partisan-divide-over-political-values/ (accessed November 8, 2017). [Online]

(2) [[Peter G. Peterson Foundation]], The Solutions Initiative III (New York: Peter G.
Peterson Foundation, May 2015), 1-9,
http://www.pgpf.org/sites/default/files/05122015_solutionsinitiative3_fullreport.pdf
(accessed November 8, 2017). [Online]

''Required Readings''

(1) Fred Gellert, “Defense Management,” July 28, 2016, BrightCove, video file,

125091953001 (accessed November 9, 2017). (View the video from minute mark 31:00
to 45:30) [Online] [Blackboard]

(2) U.S. Army Force Management School, Department Of Defense Planning,
Programming, Budgeting, And Execution (PPBE) Process/ Army Planning,
Programming, Budgeting, And Execution (PPBE) Process —An Executive Primer (Fort
Belvoir, VA: U.S. Army Force Management School, December 2017). (Read)
[Blackboard]

(3) Department of Command, Leadership, and Management, How the Army Runs:
A Senior Leader Reference Handbook, 2015 - 2016 (HTAR) (Carlisle Barracks, PA:
U.S. Army War College, 2015),
http://www.carlisle.army.mil/orgs/SSL/dclm/pubs/HTAR.pdf (accessed November 9,
2017). (Read Pages 8-1 to 8-8 and 8-30 to 8-39) [Online] [Student Issue]

(4) Department of Defense, Defense Budget Overview: United States Department
of Defense Fiscal Year 2018 Budget Request (Washington, DC: Department of
Defense, May 2017),
http://comptroller.defense.gov/Portals/45/Documents/defbudget/fy2018/FY2018_Budget
_Request_Overview_Book.pdf (accessed November 9, 2017). (Read Chapters 1 and
2; Scan remainder) [Blackboard] [Online]

Programming, Budgeting, and Execution,” 29 July 2015, linked from War on the Rocks

Home Page, https://warontherocks.com/2015/07/making-defense-reform-sane-again-
planning-programming-budgeting-and-execution-2/ (accessed October 25, 2017).

(Read article and scan replies) [Online]

Command, Leadership and Management, n.d.), 51-64. [Blackboard]

2007,
https://www.thefreelibrary.com/Combatant+command+resourcing+United+States+Centr
al+Command...-a0183552258 (accessed November 16, 2017). [Online]

2015),
http://www.jcs.mil/Portals/36/Documents/Library/Instructions/3170_01a.pdf?ver=2016-
02-05-175022-720 (accessed November 17, 2017). (Read “Capability Gap
Assessment”: p A-10). [Blackboard] [Online]

on the Involvement of the Combatant Commands in the Development of Joint

16, 2017). [Online]

!!![[DM 07 Readings]], [[DM 07]]
