''Required Readings''

(1)  U.S. Army Force Management School, How the Army Runs Primer - Updated (Fort Belvoir, VA: U.S. Army Force Management School, 2017).  (Read pp. 1-7).  [Blackboard]

(2)  Mark Gunzinger et al., [[Force Planning for the Era of Great Power Competition]] (Washington, DC: CSBA, October 2, 2017), http://csbaonline.org/research/publications/force-planning-for-the-era-of-great-powercompetition/publication (accessed November 15, 2017).  (Read ONLY the Introduction/Executive Summary, pages i-xvii).  [Online]

(3)  Dr. James A. Russell et al., Navy Strategy Development: Strategy in the 21st Century, Project Number: FY14-N3/N5-0001 (Monterey, CA: Naval Postgraduate School: Naval Research Program, June 2015), https://www.hsdl.org/?view&did=768350 (accessed November 15, 2017).  (Read: pp. 14-23)  [Online]

and Recent Efforts to Reform the Process (Washington, DC: U.S. Library of Congress,
Congressional Research Service, May 23, 2014),
http://digital.library.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metadc306454/m1/1/high_res_d/RL34026_2014
May23.pdf (accessed November 22, 2017). (Read pp. 1-18) [Blackboard] [Online]

(2) Lou [[Yuengert]] and Tom [[Galvin]], [[Acquisition and the Defense Acquisition System]], Faculty Paper (Carlisle, PA: Department of Command, Leadership, and
Management, n.d.). (Read pp. 9-12) [Blackboard]

(3) Laura Baldwin and Cynthia Cook, “[[Lessons from a Long History of Acquisition Reform]],” July 17, 2015, [[RAND]] http://www.rand.org/blog/2015/07/lessons-from-a-long-history-
of-acquisition-reform.html (accessed November 22, 2017). [Online]

April 18, 2014, YouTube, video file, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M1oHhsyDXws
(accessed November 22, 2017). [Online]

Force Quarterly Online, no. 77 (April 1, 2015):
http://ndupress.ndu.edu/Media/News/NewsArticleView/tabid/7849/Article/581867/jfq-77-
the-defense-innovation-initiative-the-importance-of-capability-prototypi.aspx (accessed
November 22, 2017). [Online]

(Washington, DC: OUSD (AT&L), January 2017), 2-17,
https://www.acq.osd.mil/dsb/reports/2010s/Defense_Research_Enterprise_Assessment
.pdf (accessed November 22, 2017). [Blackboard] [Online]

the Defense Advanced Research Project Agency Home Page,
https://www.darpa.mil/our-research?PP=0 (accessed November 22, 2017). (Browse 1-
28) [Online]

!!![[DM 11 Readings]]; [[DM 11]]

''Required Readings''

(1)  Edward J. Filiberti, Generating Military Capabilities (Carlisle Barracks, PA: U.S. Army War College, 2017).  [Blackboard]

(2)  James M. Cunningham, “Readiness Tacker, Volume 2: On an Unsustainable Path, AEI, May 4, 2016 http://www.aei.org/publication/readiness-tracker-volume-2-unsustainable-path/ (accessed November 15, 2017).  (Read 1-5)  [Online]

(3)  Mackenzie Eaglen, Shrinking Bureaucracy, Overhead, and Infrastructure: Why This Defense Drawdown Must Be Different For the Pentagon (Washington, DC: American Enterprise Institute, March 2013), http://www.aei.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/-shrinking-bureaucracy-report-v2_143022914571.pdf (accessed November 15, 2017).  (Read Executive Summary (p. iii), ‘Eliminating Excess Infrastructure While Realizing Savings’ section (13-17) and Scan rest)  [Online]

(4)  Carter Ham, “A US-Based Army Can’t Get to the Fight Fast Enough,” Defense One, March 3, 2017, http://www.defenseone.com/ideas/2017/03/us-based-army-cant-get-fight-fast-enough/135872/ (accessed November 15, 2017). (Read 1-3)  [Online]

''Focused Readings.''

(1)  Army and Civilian Students Courtney McBride, “Abrams: Army ‘Making Huge Progress’ on Readiness, But Needs Time,” Inside Defense, October 12, 2016, https://insidedefense.com/daily-
news/abrams-army-making-huge-progress-readiness-needs-time (accessed November 15, 2017).  (Read 1-3)  [Online]

(2)  Marine Corps Students:  Kevin F. Murray, “Marine Aviation Readiness,” Marine Corps Gazette, October 2016, https://www.mca-marines.org/gazette/2016/10/marine-aviation-readiness (accessed November 15, 2017).  (Read 1-4)  [Online]

(3)  Navy and Coast Guard Students:

(a)  Megan Eckstein, “U.S. Fleet Forces: New Deployment Plan Designed to Create Sustainable Naval Force,” U.S. Naval Institute News, January 19, 2016, https://news.usni.org/2016/01/19/u-s-fleet-forces-new-deployment-plan-designed-to-create-sustainable-naval-force (accessed November 9, 2016).  (Read 1-6)  [Blackboard]  [Online]

(b)  U.S. Government Accountability Office, Navy Readiness: Actions Needed to Address persistent Maintenance, Training, and Other Challenges Affecting the Fleet, GAO-17-809T (Washington, DC: Government Accountability Office, September 19, 2017), https://www.gao.gov/assets/690/686995.pdf (accessed November 15, 2017).  (Read Summary and scan rest)  [Blackboard]  [Online]

(4)  Air Force Students

(a)  Jennifer Griffin and Lucas Tomlinson, “’Wiped Out’: Air Force Losing Pilots and Planes to Cuts, Scrounging for Spare Parts,” FoxNews.com, May 14, 2016, http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2016/05/14/wiped-out-air-force-losing-pilots-and-planes-to-cuts-scrounging-for-spare-parts.html (accessed November 9, 2016).  (Read 1-3)  [Online] 

(b) David Deptula, “U.S. Air Force: A Return to Full Spectrum Readiness,” The Cipher Brief, January 1, 2017, https://www.thecipherbrief.com/u-s-air-force-a-return-to-full-spectrum-readiness (accessed November 15, 2017).  (Read 1-6)  [Online]

!!![[DM Acronym Bingo Board]], [[DM 01]]

Acronym BINGO board


Joint Capabilities Integration and Development System – JCIDS

Joint Strategic Capabilities Plan – JSCP

Joint Combat Capabilities Assessment – JCCA

Joint Strategic Planning System – JSPS

Joint Requirements Oversight Council - JROC

Chairman’s Program Assessment - CPA

Joint Urgent Operational Need - JUON

Chairman’s Risk Assessment - CRS

Joint Forces Readiness Review - JFRR

Planning, Programing, Budgeting and Execution - PPBE

Defense Planning Guidance - DPG

Program Objective Memorandum - POM

Integrated Priority List - IPL

Acquisition Category - ACAT

Future Years Defense Program – FYDP: database that captures and summarizes forces, resources, and programs associated with all Department of Defense (DoD) operations approved by the Secretary of Defense (SECDEF)

Defense Readiness Reporting System - DRRS

Technology Readiness Level – TRL: method of estimating technology maturity of Critical Technology Elements (CTE) of a program during the acquisition process

Program Evaluation Group - PEG

Capstone Concept for Joint Operations - CCJO

Doctrine, Organization, Training, Material, Leadership and education, Personnel, Facilities, and Policy – DOTMLPF-P

Joint Capabilities Board – JCB

Functional Capabilities Board - FCB


ARMY Only

Total Army Analysis - TAA

The Army Plan - TAP

Army Structure Memo - ARSTRUC

Army Campaign Plan - ACP

!!!Doug [[Douds]]

*Host for [[Gettysburg Staff Ride]].
*[[What I need you to do is...]]
*[[Douds on Values vs Interests]]

[img[https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/4BSWRIteWw7k_o3U5IykdgfvfWZ0SwWAsUsKzygdynGNmCR13slRhsrGRK8kVpm-jNGiIiVs1C7z80tamGyiljWbI9u1x3od3FI5kf3PualHRl0Q8nIzkF3VmNe7UmOSgQ0z7M_6lfY]]

[img[https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/nd5RQO3rDQ5B1Hshm4eat35HalMz98nJ3jm7qWaF0VgFZB_VT4t2QO6F1JPAqughLFWCGcs_o8Q_eLtx8Cwd7czLDoUJIRpl_YcVz6bsm1cqJ92AY4N4T0jSNPjAdiNy6d-Zy9DRQaw]]

Colonel Douds, of Stroudsburg, PA, is a faculty member at the U.S. Army War College teaching the Carlisle Scholars Program seminar.  He has served as a strategist and senior speechwriter in the Chairman's Action Group on the Joint Chiefs of Staff. He commanded a Marine fighter attack squadron in Iraq prior to earning his master's degree in strategic studies from the U.S. Army War College in June 2010. As an F/A-18 pilot, he has deployed multiple times, including two carrier deployments to the Mediterranean Sea and Persian Gulf and a western Pacific deployment. He has completed the Marine Aviation Weapons and Tactics Instructor's course, the Navy Fighter Weapons School (Top Gun), was the top honor graduate from the Amphibious Warfare School, and received two bachelor of arts degrees, in political science and history, from Wake Forest University. Doug is an avid historian and enjoys hosting educational tours of Gettysburg, PA, where he resides.

{{Agent 47}}






!!![[Douds on Values vs Interests]]

[[Jim]] asked this again (during [[SL 05]]) at Doug [[Douds]]'s brief to us prior to [[Gettysburg|Gettysburg Staff Ride]]: "What is the difference between values and interests?"

>At the top of the hierarchy are our the values. Then our interests are derived from our values.
-Doug

Also answers a question [[Brett]] had during [[TWS]]: Can a national value be considered an interest?

-[[Liberalism and World Politics]] from [[TWS 07]]

*National Defense Strategy
*Chairmen's Risk Assessment

*CJCS on risk
*Daft and Wieck: proactive or reative, analyzable or not

!!![[Defense Support to Civil Authorities]], from [[TSC 15]]






!!![[Dual Status Commander]]from [[TSC 10]]

*A Dual Status Commander reports to both the [[TAG]] and Northcom commander and controls both the Title 10  and National Guard Forces that are placed into action for [[DSCA]]






!!!Dr. Mark [[Duckenfield]]

*Lecuturer for [[The Global Economic Order]]






!!![[Dunford on Centers of Gravity]]

*When we laid out the Strategy a couple years ago, we did a [[Center of Gravity]] analysis. And with apologies to the doctrine writers, we think there are two:
**At the strategic level, it's our network of allies and partners developed since [[World War II]]
**At the operational level, it's our ability to project for anywhere in the world






!!![[Dunford on Climate Change]], [[GEN Dunford]], see also 

>....needless to say, I've been asked this question before.

*What I'll say is we have to be prepared to ''deal with the consequences'' of any natural disaster.

>Regarding the policy, we don't have a military position on the source and nature of climate change. And we shouldn't.






>In World War I, the Netherlands was neutral. In World War II we.... wanted to be neutral.

- [[Ed]]






Hans [[Morgenthau]]: The duty of the statesman is to pursue the interests of the state






!!!Early Assumptions of Bombing

From [[TWS 12]]

*Populations (esp those in cities) will be highly vulnerable and easily disrupted. Why?
*Air war will be so terrible that it will end swiftly, thus making wars shorter. This will head off a repeat of 1914-1918. Why?
*Offensive capabilities will overwhelm defensive capabilities. Why?
*The bomber will get through since the air realm is vast. Why?






!!![[Eating the Chinese Lunch]]

>We are eating the [[Chinese'|China]] Lunch! They made the lunch. And we're getting ready to eat it!
-[[Jim]]

!!![[Econ and National Security]]

*Since 1950, US population has doubled. Financial regulation per capita has risen 1400%.

{{Four Types of Derivatives}}






!!!__[[Economic Stabilizer]]__, as briefed by Mark [[Duckenfield]] on [[The Global Economic Order]]

*Market for distressed goods
*Provider of an international reserve currency
*International lender of last resort
*Long-term counter-cyclical lending
*Political leadership in the provision of international public goods

!!![[Ed vs Bob]] from [[TSC 22]]
"""
[[Bob]]: When the Libya thing was ramping up, I was surprised that our British and French allies were really missing the ability to project forces. They really wanted to get Gaddafi, more than us. But they weren't going to get there alone.
[[Ed]]: The thing about not being able to project force is you have longer to consider your other [[Instruments of National Power]].
[[Bob]]: Yeah, Americans aren't really good at that.






!!![[Ed's Army Leader Breakout Observations]]

-[[Ed]] talking about the Army Chief of Engineers for [[Army Leader Day]]

>I did not think that he was the best leader. However, I have only seen three general officers today. So perhaps he is the third best general here today.






!!!![[Ed]] ,,(see EdPic),,

[img[https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/X2Dgp_TNepT2N9BC5B-Y3y39mh4w6GYPtyTc_anWTDhB7ISs38ojzmUDwJmO6PIjc6zoRK0NTDWj_itP435Ft2gmbeitW-a7H6IuUNsrsOVlEd98UMrMUBFwNzwxfoois0GBRzZB0_c=w2400]]






!!![[Effect of Sequestration on Vendors]]
-From [[Measuring the Impact of Sequestration and the Defense Drawdown on the Industrial base]] from [[DM 09]]

>The empirical data presented above show that the effect of the defense drawdown on industry was substantial; and that while defense contract obligations fell across all platform portfolios, the impact of the drawdown on the different sectors of the defense industrial base varied widely. Some sectors saw continual declines in contract obligations, while others experienced a whipsaw effect, swinging rapidly from growth to decline. In general, small and Top 5 vendors’ market share remained steady, while medium and large vendors’ shares were more volatile. Over the course of the drawdown, the Top 5’s contract portfolio shifted toward products and services, and away from R&D.

---

>As noted above, over the course of the drawdown, the total number of first tier prime vendors declined by approximately 17,000 vendors, or roughly 20 percent.






!!!Eisenhower Program

-Mark, Brett; need your stuff

{{Ten and Two}}






!!![[Elements of Operational Design]] from [[TSC 04]]

*Termination
*Military End State
*Objectives
*Effects
*[[Centers of Gravity|Center of Gravity]]
*[[Decisive Points]]
*Lines of Operation / Lines of 
*Direct and Indirect Approach
*Anticipation
*Operational Reach
*Culmination
*Arranging operations
*Forces and Functions






!!!Adam [[Elkus]]

*[[50 Shades of Gray: Why the Gray War Concept Makes No Sense]] for [[TWS 16]]







!!![[Shaping and Reinforcing Mechanisms]] from [[SL 10]], Organizational Culture
-Presented by Edgar [[Schein]]

[[Embedding Mechanisms]]

*Attention, Measurement, Control
*React to critical incidents
*Allocate Resources
*Role model/coach
*Reward criteria
*Selection/Recruitment criteria

[[Reinforcing Mechanisms]]

*Organizational design and structure
*Need....






!!![[Embedding Mechanisms]] from [[SL 10]]

>Structure, policy (must do); leads to compliance

See also [[Reinforcing Mechanisms]]






!!![[Enduring Trends]] of War from [[TWS 16]]

*Human endeavor
*Political nature
*[[Civil-Military Relations]]
*The enemy gets a vote
*Interests vs. values; modified to interests ''and'' values
*Operational success vs strategic success
*Complicated coalitions
*[[Risk]]

See Also: [[Changing Trends]]; included in [[Nature vs Character of War]]






!!![[Ensuring America’s Fiscal and National Security]]
-by [[Peter G. Peterson Foundation]] for [[DM 03]]

https://www.pgpf.org/finding-solutions/national-security/

<iframe src="www.drudgereport.com" frameborder="0" width="960" height="675" allowfullscreen="true" mozallowfullscreen="true" webkitallowfullscreen="true"></iframe>








!!![[Epilogue: Thucydides]]

!!!Athens's Defeat; Persian Ascendancy; Philip of Macedon (p. 549-554)

"""	
	• Sparta wins after the naval defeat of the Athenian fleet at Aegospotami in 406. [549]
	• War concludes in 404, but Persia is the winner overall. [549]
	• Fighting resumed with Athens against Persia in 387, but Athens lost and abandoned their dreams of empire within Persia. [550]
	• Sparta's victory overall was short lived. [550]
	• King of Persia, Cyrus the Younger, gained the most from the war, with the destruction of the Athenian empire he recovered his territory in Asia Minor, and was able to hold onto this territory by playing off the disunited Greek polis against each other. [552]
	• Spartan ambitions were dealt a final blow when Thebian hoplites won at Luecrtra, and Spartan army's reputation was forever stained. [553]
	• All of this set the stage for Phillip of Macedon and his son, Alexander the Great. [554]

	→ All of this goes back to ''[[Liddell-Hart]]'':
		○ Victory in the true sense implies that the state of peace and of one's people, is better after the war than before. [357]
		○ It is wiser to run risks of war for the sake of preserving peace than to run risks of exhaustion in war for the sake of finishing with victory. [357]  Perseverance in war is only justifiable if there is a good chance of a good end- the prospect of a peace that will balance the sum of human misery incurred in the struggle. [358]







!!![[Epistemology]] from [[SL 03]]

>The branch of philosophy concerned with the theory of knowledge.

[[See wikipedia|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistemology]]

!!![[Ethical Fading]]: It's not really an ethical issue
-From Lennie [[Wong]]'s [[Lecture on Professional Ethics]]

*Step 1: Don't use the word Lie
*Step 2: Numb us to death. Be sure to make us certify everything so much that we no longer put any value on initials or a signature.
*Step 3: Give me some distance to that lie.
**Let me use my CAC instead of a signature
**Let me use red/amber/green instead of precise numbers

!!![[Fear, Honor, and Interest]]

>It follows that it was not a very wonderful action, or contrary to the common practice of mankind, if we did accept an empire that was offered to us, and refused to give it up under the pressure of three of the strongest motives, ''fear, honor, and interest''. And it was not we who set the example, for it has always been the law that the weaker should be subject to the stronger. Besides, we believed ourselves to be worthy of our position, and so you thought us till now, when calculations of interest have made you take up the cry of justice—a consideration which no one ever yet brought forward to hinder his ambition when he had a chance of gaining anything by might.

- [[Thucydides]] in [[The Peloponnesian War]], Book 1, Chapter 76.2.
-http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0200%3Abook%3D1%3Achapter%3D76%3Asection%3D2

!!![[FISA]]: Foreign Intelligense Security Act by [[Todd]] in [[TSC 23]]

*If the collection that intelligence officials anticipate collecting against foriegners, but they are talking to an American, eg Dex, then that is illegal by itself
*But there is a process involving a judge in a fully classified setting to approve the collection of information that includes conversation by 'Dex' 
*You (for example, the FBI) have to show there is a reason to collect the information
*[[FISA Court on Wikipedia|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Foreign_Intelligence_Surveillance_Court]]

!!![[Foco Theory of Revolutionary Export]] from [[Americas 09]]

*Foco, or "focus", of the revolution is not the ideas but the heroism of the guerillas'that would insprie people to join the revolution.






!!![[Force Integration]] from [[DM 10]], Slide 2 of [[DM 10 Slides]]

*Structuring-what should the MTOE look like?
*Manning-policies that keep units fully manned?
*Equipping-new, recap, reset; timing of distro
*Training-CTCs, funding for ranges, training ammo allocations, flying hours
*Sustaining-access to sources of supply
*Deploying-power projection, facilities, deployable equipment
*Stationing-forward stationing, Army prepo stocks
*Funding-sufficient funding for parts, ammo, fuel






!!![[Force Management]]: (See [[DM 07]]) Army Force Management is the capstone process for the development and fielding of a trained and ready force.  The Army’s use of the term “Force Management (FM)” subsumes the two enabling Army sub-processes of “Force Development (FD)” and “Force Integration (FI)” associated with developing and fielding a balanced and affordable force.  Army FM differs from the joint usage of the terms within “Global Force Management (GFM).”  The GFM is part of a joint sourcing system for the assignment, allocation, and apportionment of forces through a predictive, streamlined, and integrated process.

*need slide from DM 07






!!![[Force Planning for the Era of Great Power Competition]] for [[DM 07]]

Force Planning for the Era of Great Power Competition

<iframe src="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Ju9BpBQG8fj7QcWJ6HWyITy5MKgexoDO/preview" width="840" height="680"></iframe>







!!![[Foreign Policy Defined]] from [[NSPS 01]]

>The policies of a nation that encompass all official relations with other countries.
-[[Sarkesian]], 2






[[Forms of Liberalism]] IAW [[Nye and Welch]], [[TWS 05]]

*Economic Liberalism: Trade is important because it leads states to define their interests in a way that makes war less important to them. [58]
*Social Liberalism: Person-to-person contacts reduce conflict by promoting understanding. [58]
*Neoliberalism: Emphasizes the role of institutions. [59]  Institutions:
**provide a sense of continuity
**Provide an opportunity for reciprocity
**provide a flow of information
**Provide ways to resolve conflicts. [60]







!!![[Formulating National Security Strategy]] from [[NSPS 15]]

<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/GbYwgVYK8mo" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen style="width:100%;height:420px;"/>






!!![[Four Maxims of Systems Thinking]]

*Learn the system's rules
**Two major challenges:
***Credit Assignment Problem (you probably can't isolate the problem)
***Rule Discovery Problem (timelines can be too short to figure them out)
*Think in terms of multiple types of causation
*Choose your metaphors and models carefully
**[[Epidemiologicl vs. Medical]] (see Malcolm [[Gladwell]] quote)
**Gardens or Games "I like to think of the international system more like a garden than a game."
**Sitcoms or Movies. Sitcoms never end
*Everything you know about the systems....






!!![[Four Perspectives in IR Theory]]

<iframe src="https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/e/2PACX-1vTZQOtPiRuFO2JvDORv-BAmdmd71JeSF93cgtT3fQc6VvSftVIh9uogonTo0oqqFYOOYFkegoeH9vh-/embed?start=false&loop=false&delayms=3000" frameborder="0" width="980" height="349" allowfullscreen="true" mozallowfullscreen="true" webkitallowfullscreen="true"></iframe>






!!!Four Good Questions on Data Gathering
-from a 25 Sep lecture before [[SL 04]]

#To what extent do statistics indicate a change?
#Has our definition or classification of the phenomenon changed?
#Have those involved in the phenomenon (sujbects, objects, observers) changed other behaiviors that may affect observations?
#Has the approach to gathering data changed?

Also see defintions for:

*[[Social Construct]]
*[[Priming]]
*[[Observer Effects]]






!!![[Four Schools of Airpower]]

According to Beatrice [[Heuser]] in Ch13 of [[The Evolution of Strategy]]

*Strategic Bombing School
*Military Targets School
*Leadership Targeting School, depends on precision munitions
*Political Signaling School

[[Jim]]: I don't like calling these 'schools' or the [[Five Schools of Space]]. It's really more like types of applications. Each one of these things isn't monolithic, so not really a school.






[[Four Types of Derivatives]] from [[NSPP]] class [[Econ and National Security]]

#Forward Contract
#Future Contract
#Swaps
#Options






*War by counsel = diplomacy
**Sublte act of war
**Treaties are to be broken... allies

[[Frank on Bias]] from [[NSPS 01]]

>I don't care who you are. You have a viewpoint. You are not uninformed. This will be more of an issue when we get to the oral presentations. Everyone has a bias. It's important that you know what that bias is.
-[[Frank]]






!!![[Frank on Bush II Strategies]] from [[NSPS 15]]

>The second Bush administration never met a strategy it didn't want to write.






!!![[Frank on Ikle]] from [[NSPS 15]]
>It's unfortunate that we don't read all of [[Ikle]]'s book. It's only about one hundred pages.
-[[Frank]]






!!![[Frank on Mahan]]

[[Frank]]: [[Mahan]] is very much a [[Constructionist|Constructivism]] in [[IR Theory]]: National character, "sea-faring people", views of the nature of global shipping

Also Frank: You can only understand Mahan when you understand his [[geopolitical|Geopolitics]] orientation: size of the ocean, controlling shipping lanes, etc.







!!![[Frank on McMaster]] from [[NSPS 16]]

>[[McMaster]] is trying to remind everyone that [[Geopolitics]] is still very much relevant to how the world works. Read your [[Mackinder]].






!!![[Frank on One Belt One Road]] from [[Deb]]'s Presentation on [[One Belt One Road]], [[NSPS 08]]

>I've never seen such unbridled optimism! Let me offer you a realist perspective. If you look at this in isolation, then this looks like an opportunity to let China faciliate global trade. But read your [[Mackinder]]. But they are opening up their access to the EU, which is the largest trading block for the United States. [other explanations] It looks to me like a multifaceted strategy to undermine the US economy.
-[[Frank]], #[[Realism]]






>In the words of that famous singer, 'What's policy got to do with it?'






!!![[Frank on Power]]

>This is where students get tripped up in [[Oral Comps|OralComp]]. [[Dave]] Krebs is going to give you a wonderful definition of [[Landpower]]. And they's ask you and you'll spit that out. But why does Landpower matter!?! I don't have it just to have it, or just to use it. It only matters if it can be part of a [[Strategy]] to pursue [[National Interests|US National Interests]].






!!![[Frank on Qi]] from [[TWS 09]]
>[[Sun Tzu]] sees everything as a constant flow of energy amongst the tactical, operational, and strategic levels. In the Western thought, we like to decompose everything and make it into a formula.
-[[Frank]]






!!![[Frank on Scott's Philosophy]] from [[NSPS 16]]

>I'm just going to call you a cock-eyed optimist.






!!![[Frank on Sovereignty Disputes]] as part of [[Scott]]'s presentation on the [[Senkaku Islands]] in [[NSPS 11]]

>When there are territorial disputes over sovereignty, and you're telling me that international courts or international law is not going to resolve it, then there's only two ways to resolve it. a) Military conflict, or b) some type of outside arbitration hosted by an element that is agreed to by both parties. This happened in [[Peru]], right [[Paul]]? They had significant border issues. And they were resolved with other international players. Which is better than conflict.






!!![[Frank on the Value of Strategic Documents]] from [[NSPS 15]]

>A strategy gives you an idea of where you're going. ... Strategists don't think about endstates. Because the moment you achieve the endstates, you have a different dynamic. Plus you don't have the resources to actually accomplish solving all the problems. [[Deb]] is doing a report that [[China]] is investing $1 trillion dollars in the [[One Belt One Road]] strategy. $1 trillion!!! Those are the required resources. But if you tried to do that in our country with public funds the American people would say, "What the heck? Why don't we spend that on our own infrastructure?" ''Strategies don't solve problems.''

[[Frank]]: No, but I can shoot pistols with both hands.
[[Bob]]: Well that might be even better.

!!!Nathan [[Freier]], for [[DM 01]]

>From Homer to Homer [Simpson], the reason why we're not very good at [[Systems Thinking]] is becuase we like stories.
-Andrew [[Hill]], lecture on [[Complex Adaptive Systems]] for [[SL 04]]






!!![[Fulfillment of Urgent Operational Needs]]
-For [[DM 05]]

<iframe src="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1-iAyQX188F_bxjbrdeRbtSorC2MOXAZV/preview" width="840" height="680"></iframe>

https://drive.google.com/open?id=1-iAyQX188F_bxjbrdeRbtSorC2MOXAZV






!!![[Fundamentals of Strategy and Grand Strategy]] by [[Liddell Hart]] for [[TWS 01]]
-from [[Strategy (Book)]]

The Theory of Strategy (p. 319-323)

"""
	• Clausewitz definition of strategy: "The Art of the employment of battles as a means to gain the object of war." [319]  Two defects in this  definition
		○ It intrudes on the sphere of policy, or the higher conduct of war, which must be the responsibility of the government and not the military.  
		○ It narrows the meaning of strategy to pure utilization of battle, conveying that battle is the only means to the strategic end. [319]
	• Policy should not be subservient to the conduct of operations, nor should it allow statesmen to overstep with military leaders' employment of forces.  [320]
	• Von Moltke definition of strategy: "The practical adaptation of the means placed at a general's disposal to the attainment of the object in view." [320]
		○ Fixes the responsibility of a military commander to the government by which he is employed… apply the force to the best advantage to achieve political goals. 
		○ Strategy is not simply seeking to overthrow the enemy's military power. [320]
	• Strategy of limited aim: awaiting a change in the balance of force to give your side maximum advantage. [321]
	• BH Liddell Hart definition of strategy: "the art of distributing and applying military means to fulfill ends of policy. [321]
		○ Strategy is not only concerned with the movement of forces, but with the effect. 
	• Tactics: When the application of the military instrument merges into actual fighting; the dispositions for and control of such direct action. The application of strategy on a lower plane. [321]
	• Grand Strategy: guides the conduct of war, as distinct from the more fundamental policy which should govern its object.  "policy in execution".  The role of grand strategy is to coordinate and direct all resources of a nation or band of nations towards the attainment of the political object of the war- the goal defined by fundamental policy. [323]
		1. Calculate and develop the economic resources and man-power of nations in order to sustain the fighting services and moral resources (people's will and spirit)
		2. Regulate the distribution of power to weaken the opponent's will (Hard and Soft Power) [323]
	· Strategy depends for success on a sound calculation and coordination of the end and the means. [322]  The end must be proportional to the total means, and the means used in gaining each intermediate end must be proportioned to the value and needs of that intermediate end.  Establishing a perfect economy of force.

National Object and Military Aim (p. 338-339)

	· The military objective should be governed by the political objective. Therefore any study of the problem ought to begin and end with the question of policy. [338]
	· Objective is a misleading term.  Better to use "the object" when dealing with the purpose of policy, and "the military aim" when dealing with the way that forces are directed in the service of policy. [338]
	· Gaining military victory is not in itself equivalent of gaining the object of policy. [338]
	→ Why do we get this wrong so often?
		○ Losing sight of the proper relationship between the object and the military aim-between policy and strategy- the military aim becomes distorted and oversimplified. [339]
			§ Use of force disconnected to policy, as and end unto itself… i.e. flexing muscle to send a message.  
		○ Failure to see the long game at the policy level… democratic governments are fickle, hard to get everyone to agree on the long game and sustain it over time [decades]
		○ Use of power simply because you have it
		○ Solving the wrong problems or solving something that isn't a problem. 
		○ Over concentrate on victory without thought to what happens next or what state you'll be in when you win. [353]  Failing to achieve a peace that was better than the one before the war [357]
		○ Persevering in war even when victory won't balance the sum on human misery. [368] Vietnam, WWI

Grand Strategy (p. 353-360)

	· Grand strategy = war policy [353]
	· The object of war is to attain a better peace, even if only from your own point of view. [353]  You must conduct war with the constant regard for the peace you desire. 
	· Coalition warfare makes this harder.  When there is no longer the counterbalance of an opposing force to control the appetites of the victors, there is no check on the conflict of views and interest between the parties to the alliance.  This divergence is then apt to become so acute as to urn the comradeship of common danger into the hostility of mutual dissatisfaction- so that the ally of one war becomes the enemy in the next. [353]
	· Acquisitive state: needs to expand; Conservative state: wants to maintain the status quo. [355]
	· Challenge of the acquisitive state: to gain your object without self-exhaustion. [355]
	· Challenge of the conservative state is to find the type of strategy that is suited to fulfil its inherently more limited object in the most strength conserving way. [355]
	· Applying reason to grand strategy: [357]
		1. The better your strategy, the easier you will gain the upper hand. 
		2. The more strength you waste the more you increase the risk of failure, and even if you win, you will have less strength to profit from in peace. 
		3. The more brutal your methods, the more bitter you will make your opponents. 
		4. The more intent you appear to impose a peace entirely of your own choosing, the stiffer the obstacle you will raise in your path. 
		5. When you win, the more you ask of the defeated side, the more cause you will provide for them to reverse the settlement achieved in war. [WWI]
	· Victory in the true sense implies that the state of peace and of one's people, is better after the war than before. [357]
	· It is wiser to run risks of war for the sake of preserving peace than to run risks of exhaustion in war for the sake of finishing with victory. [357]  Perseverance in war is only justifiable if there is a good chance of a good end- the prospect of a peace that will balance the sum of human misery incurred in the struggle. [358]







!!![[G8's Lecture on Acquisition]]
-Lecture by [[LTG Murray]]

>...so then I have to take that requirement to my wife. So in this example my wife is the Chief of Staff of the Army.
-Narrative of buying cell phone for his kids.
---
''[[World Order|World Orders]]''

*Sec [[Mattis]] pretty much wrote the [[NDS]] himself. The bottom line is the new strategy is about preparing for war between the great powers.
*[[NorthKorea]]
**"I believe the Olympics is just a pausex." Regarding North Korea missile tests.
*[[Russia]]
**They have built a strategy and developed a capabiliy around [[A2AD]].
**Russia will probably be similiar until about 2030-32 before the elements of decline start to catch up with them. Then the question is will they be more or less dangerous
*[[China]]
**Their stealth capabilities are on path to meet and exceed our own
**They have a national training center will real critique and AAR process to make their units better
---
*About 850 programs of record in the Army
*"Everything in the Army has a proponent. Even things that are not programs of record have a proponent."
---
''The Three Buckets''

*You'll see comments (Army Times, etc.) say that the Army is stingy on pay. But people are expensive.
*Are you willing to accept [[Tiered Readiness]]? And the answer is always a resounding 'No.'
*So: modernization it is.
---
''Operational Environment according the CoS''

*We will fight in megacities. So we have to optimize the force to fight there.
*The fight will be more lethal than ever: precision, autonomous, AI
*We will have to fight in snall and dispersed units. ("I don't necessarily agree with him, but he believes this so I believe it.") They'll come together briefly if they need to, and then disperse back out just to survive. The challenge will be how to support logistics in that step.
---
''Acquisition reform and priorities''

*Some of the problems are within the Army itself
*Prototype the [[NGCV]] by 2019
*Future Vertical Lift
*Future small arms. [Croft: well informed on chamber pressure increase + aim augmentation (+polymer cases to reduce ammo weight); not as informed about caliber (mid-cal solution)]
---
''Futures Command''

*Chief's assessment is TRADOC's span of control is too wide.
*There is no signle neck to choke.

GEN Marshall Quote

>Years ago we had all the time to prepare and no resources. Now we have all the resources and no time.
-LTG Murray's assessment is we're at a temporary moment when we have both with new funding

[img[https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/eS-krnZRRUxzM0h0VTq35-t8UdAWUuHLWNz-v2G_TVZ-eW3RnL4huO0x6v0zlaNCgXoN1__iH-7HaLZKr6URO7EFiBOclxOO6dI096eDv751vzbJXyCFUA-OlFsMZZgRAAwiUhDxO84]]

*People
**Shortage of pilots
*OPTEMPO
**"Iny my traning formative years, we trained to standard not to time. ... By the time you got to collective training you were 'brillant at the basics.' .... But now it's train to time because there is only a finite amount of time before the next deployment come."
**Regarding the McCain, Fitzgerald, etc: The amount of time that was afforded to leaders to train their elements was probably too short to get
*Equipment
**We have delayed modernization. ... We have equipment challenges that aren't necessarily manifesting on deployments, but they do manifst at home

>I believe we have the ability to protect our homeland and our way of life. .... We have a oompetitive advantage over any adversary that we might face.
-Mostly concerned about our competitive advantage. It has eroded over time.

>This is the most volatile and complext time in history since World War II.
-paraphrase of Henry Kissenger ("I don't have anything my experience to tell him he is wrong.")

*The 4+1 is a way to organize and prioritize our capability development.

*If we build the capabilities and capacities to handle those challanges today, we will be best prepared to handle any challenge that is 

>By no means am I offering the 4+1 as a predictive model. 

>We are not seeking regime change. ... We are not seeking to move forces north of the DMZ.
-That is a policy shift that we are not seeking reunification 

>China's support in the UN is unprecedented.
-They supported sanctions aganst North Korea in ways we haven't seen.

*Our purpose is to support the Secretary of State's economic and diplomatic pressure campaign.
*The President does want us to generate options so that he knows what can be done and wietgh whether is can be done.

>It isn't our job to decide whether to go to war. It's our job to lay out the military options.

>Everything we do, and I mean EVERYTHING we do, is in conjuction with the Secretary of State.

>I've been to Turkey twelve times in this job, and maybe twenty phone calls or video teleconferences. ... There are some problems in the relationship.
-Response to how serious the US is to developing that partnership

*Question from Larry [[Goodsen]]:
*Is [[Adversial Competition]] inconpatible with democracy since our ...?
*What do we need to do to maintain our democracy while engaging in [[Adversarial Competition]]?
**OK- so we're never going to lie in the infromation space, because that is not compatible. So we are giving somehthing up there.
**But it starts with good solid foundation on policy.

>When I talk about "Command and Control" at this level, I'm talking about facilitating the ability of the Secretary [of Defense] to make decisions.

*The thing that has changed more than anything else is the pace of change. When I was a lieutenant in the 70s. you could have beamed in a LT from WWII and he would have rapidly been comfortaable with what we were doing. That's all changed.

!!![[GEN Perna]]

*Leadership
*Balance
*Character
*Competence
*Commitment

[[GEN Perna]]
-CG, AMC; [[Lecture on Army Materiel Command]]

[[Clausewitz’ Two Categories of War]]
“....the activities charateristic of war may be split ino two main categories: those that are merely preparations for war, and war proper.”
-Clausewitz

“In war, the difference between being Ready & Reacting will be measured by the number of lives lost.”

[[Perna on Risk]]
>We are in a risk business.
-[[GEN Perna]], [[Lecture on Army Materiel Command]]

[[Googling Your Next Job]]
>I was the J4 in Iraq. GEN Dunwoody was over and told me I was going to go command Joint Munitions Command. Actually she just said ‘AMC.’ So I said, ‘Roger that, ma’am.’ I put her in the car, went back inside, and googled ‘JMC.’ I had not idea what it was. You get a lot of funny things when you just type in those letters. Don’t do that.
-[[GEN Perna]], [[Lecture on Army Materiel Command]]

>That could be a whole other discussion on decision making. Do you throw out the solution before you understand the problem?
-[[GEN Perna]] on [[Futures Command]]

*Preposition Stocks Do Two Things
**It mitigates operational distance.
**It creates “angles” (dilemmas) for the enemy, because they know that stuff is out there and they have to account for that.

Perna’s three knobs of money: Personnel, Readiness, Modernization.

Book recommendation:

“Freedom’s Forge”
-[[GEN Perna]]: We were working on the requirements for facilitization, etc., as early as 1930
>I know you’ve already got your hands full with books, and most of you don’t give a crap about the Log.

>The good news is we had Kuwait. The bad news is if we have to go somewhere else

*They’ve been buiding gun tubes with in Watervliet, NY since 1812.

‘’Leadership Notes’’

*Leadership: Mission Command (Vision, Time, Resources, Risk)

>I think we’ve been doing Mission Command my whole career. But what you need to think about is the difference between Command and Control and Mission Command. Command and Control is the single point of failure. Mission Command is about commander’s intent. … Command and Control will not be successful in the future. … We have gotten bad at Mission Command. It’s happened at all levels all the way up to me.

*If your subordinates don’t get your guidance right, that is ‘’your fault.’’ It’s not their fault.

*Money is not the decision criteria. It’s about the risk. I need you to think about that. … You need to articulate the risk. The decision should turn on the risk, not on the 

>Don’t be a part of stupid. That’s what I’m trying to coach you.

>I am convinced we are not active listeners.

>I want conflict and recommendations. If I start getting the drinking bird, and everyone says “Yes, sir. That’s the greatest thing I ever heard,” I give an immediate redo.

!!![[Don’t Go For Consensus]]

>Everyone has a rice bowl. You’re not going to get consensus. Don’t go for consensus. It’s about the risk.
-[[GEN Perna]], [[Lecture on Army Materiel Command]]

!!![[How the Budget Doesn’t Work]]

>I can’t speak for the other services, but the Army Budget Process doesn’t work with me calling someone up and saying, “I need this much money” and they say, “General, brilliant. Here ya go.”
-[[GEN Perna]] on why relationships matter. You need to know where everyone sits on the issue.

!!![[Know How It Works]]

>There are 30 logistics generals in the Army’s active force. I bring them together to talk about how the Army works. It’s ok to be frustrated with it. It’s not ok to not know how it works. It’s not good enough to say something is stupid. You have to understand it so you can influence it. ... Out of those 30 generals, it’s my opinion that maybe 10 understand how the Army operations.
-[[GEN Perna]], [[Lecture on Army Materiel Command]]

!!![[You are at the inflection point]]

See Pic

*Hero: MG Warrent, “Hero of Little Round Top”

!!![[If You Go Home at Five O’Clock]]

>If you’re going home at five o’clock, you’re not getting promoted. That’s just a fact. Don’t get carried away with what I’m saying.
-[[GEN Perna]] on family-work-health balance, [[Lecture on Army Materiel Command]]

!![[Unforgiving Angles]]

>The [60 degree]] angles between competence, commitment, and character are unforgiving. There are times when we give extra credit to competence and commitement, and we do not pay enough attention to character.

>If you work for me, you do not get extra credit for being competent and committed if you come up short on character.

!!![[How Hal Moore Did It]]

*Someone asked Hal Moore, ‘How did you know what to do?” His response was:

>What am I doing that I should not be doing, and what am I not doing that I should be doing?
-LTG(R) Hal Moore

*Presented by [[GEN Perna]], [[Lecture on Army Materiel Command]]

!!![[Ghost Fleet]]

[[Jim]] was exposed to this while at the Pentagon. "It's kind of a silly book." The premise is that there is a massive deception operation, a la [[Sun Tzu]], with cyber, etc. And that sets up a conventional war.

What is significant is that senior U.S. leaders, in circulating the book, are trying to draw attention to the way the Chinese may approach conflict.






!!![[Give em Crayons]] regarding [[UCP]] [[AOR]]s from [[TSC 01]]

>Give a bunch a Flag Officers some crayons, and they're gonna color.
-[[Dave]]






!!![[Give The Building Hope]]

>As a PM walking into [[The Building]], you have to give The Building hope. When you stop giving The Building hope, your program dies.
-Dave [[Rohall]]

{{The Three A's for GEF}}






!!![[Global Loser]]

>Slavery is a global loser at this point, and you're the chief spokesman.
-Doug [[Douds]] on the Confederate's "I" [[instrument|Instruments of National Power]] for [[Lee's Strategic Options]].












!!John [[Gooch]]

Reading in [[TWS 11]]: Chapter 2 in his book [[Seapower and Strategy]], "Maritime Command: [[Mahan]] and [[Corbett]]"

{{The Longest Purse}}






!!![[Governments Lose Sight]] from [[NSPS 15]]

>In part, governments tend to lose sight of the ending of wars and the [[nation's interests|US National Interests]] that lie beyond it, precisely because fighting a war is an effort of such vast magnitude. Thus it can happen that military men, while skillfully planning their intricate operations and coordinating complicated maneuvers, remain curiously blind in failing to perceive that it is the outcome of the war, not the outcome of the campaigns within it, that determines how well their plans serve the nation's interests.
-pg 2 of [[Every War Must End]] by [[Ikle]]






!!![[Grand Strategy]]

*Need one from [[Liddel Hart]]
*Citation of Barry Posen by [[Hemmer]] (pg 2) in [[NSPS 04]]: "a state's theory about how it can best 'cause' security for itself."
*The concepts that give meaning and form to the National Interests; the theory or logic that tells us where you want to go and how you might get there. (by Hal [[Brands]] for [[NSPS 17]] lecture on [[Stress Testing Grand Strategy]]






!!![[Grand Strategy and Macroeconomics]]

>Grand strategy ultimately begins and ends with macroeconomics, and perhaps the single most important insight from the Cold War is that geopolitical success is a function of economic vitality. It was, after all, the West's superior economic performance that eventually exerted such a powerful magnetic draw on countries in both the Third and Second Worlds, and allowed Washington and its allies to sustain a protracted global competition that bankrupted Moscow in the end.
-Hal [[Brands]], "Rethinking America's Grand Strategy: Insights from the Cold War", 2016, from the noon time lecture following [[NSPS 02]]






!!!Colin [[Gray]]

*[[In Defense of the Heartland]] from [[TWS 05]]
*[[War—Continuity in Change, and Change in Continuity]] from [[TWS 16]]






!!![[Gray Zones]] and Gray Zone Conflict

*First introduced in [[TWS 16]] (logged as 'need' to fill in)
*Presentation by [[Brett]] in [[TSC 14]]
**Often presents situatins that don't call for military tools
**Requires, instead, more interagency and whole-of-govt approaches
**More involvement of [[SOF]]; although consensus is that there is not enough capacity to be the one-answer solution
**What's next for [[Russia]]: undermining political systems
**What's next for [[China]]: extralegal expansion into the South China Sea
**Gray Zone conflicts are here to stay
*Article by [[Mazarr]] in [[TWS 16]]






!!![[Great Power Competition]]

*Refocus in strategic documents away from COIN and [[VEO]]s
*See also [[Adversarial Competition]]

[img[https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/fXhW_iugz1sZQXV9iWKRjXpRnhkfVW1Pje8C5QMfJvz4rfavkdsF1pl6CkP1dk0GGMQcMA]]






!!![[Hans Morgenthau]]

*[[Realist|Realism]]
*"The fallacy of the single factor."






!!![[Hard Power vs Soft Power]]

*Hard Power: coercing other states to change. Carrots and Sticks.
**Are economic sanctions Hard Power? YES!!!
*Soft Power: Getting others to want what you want, also called attractive power.

Who is the father of soft power?: Joseph S. [[Nye]]






!!![[Has the Navy ever failed?]] from [[TSC 20]]
"""
[[Dave]]: Services accuse each other of this and that. But c'mon, really? Has the Navy ever failed?
[[Brett]]: You said [[we left you at Guadalcanal!|Why Marines Are Paranoid]]
[[Dave]]: ...well, that's true.







!!![[Hastedt]] on the Presidency

*Weak or strong President and the US Constitution
*Foreign affairs
**Executive Agreements
**Signing Statements
**Unofficial Ambassadors
**Undeclared Wars
*Executive orders
*Funding
*Administrative powers
*''Action indispensability vs Actor indispensibility''
*Presidential personality--active/passive, positive/negative
*Presidential managerial style
*[[NSC]]--established by the National Security Act of 1947

{{Congress Roles in Foreign Policy}}






>I hate the military term, End State. End states happen in movies. End states do not happen in [[Complex Adapative Systems]].
-Andrew [[Hill]]






!!![[He or She]]
"""
[[Ed]]: So Lady Liberty. Did you say 'he'?
[[Scott]]: I said 'he'--the artist--is done with 'her'.
[[Rich]]: She's transgender.







!!![[Hedge Fund]] from [[Econ and National Security]]

>An entity that hods a pool of securities and perhaps other assets, whose interest are not sold in a registered public offering, and which is not registered as an investment company under the US Investment Company Act of 1940, as amended.






!!![[Helm Yeah!]]

<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/FlR2JM4U2QY" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen style="width:100%;height:400px;"/>







Book: [[Balance Restored]]






!!!Beatrice [[Heuser]]

Ch 13: The [[Four Schools of Airpower]]






!!!Andrew [[Hill]]

*Lecture on [[Complex Adaptive Systems]] and journal author for [[SL 04]]
*Journal author on [[Systems of Denial]] for [[SL 11]]






>Strategy is principles for decision making under conditions of competitive uncertainty.






>An organization is a social system with a purpose, culture, structure, and resources built around a theory (or theories) of competition.
-Andres [[Hill]] and Stephen [[Gerras]], pg 113 of [[Systems of Denial]] reading for [[SL 11]]






!!![[History vs Heritage]]

>History makes you smarter. Heritage makes you prouder.
-A quote [[GEN Rand]] stole from a chaplain






!!![[Holley Theory Definitions]]

*Visions are ideas not systematically prepared for authentication.
*Illusions are ideas that could not survive systematic preparation for authentication
*Myths are ideas that exempt themselves from any systematic authentication
*Facts are ideas that have already passed the authentication process
*Falsehoods are ideas certain to fail the authentication process






!!![[Homeland Defense]] from [[TSC 15]]

>The protection of United States sovereignty, territory, domestic population and critical defense infrastructure against external threats and aggression or other threats as directed by POTUS.
-from [[TSC 15]]






!!![[Homeland Security]] from [[TSC 15]]

>Homeland secuirty desribes the intersection of evolving theats and hazads with the traditional governmental and civic responsibilities of civil defense, emergency response, law enforcement, customs, border control, and immigration.






!!![[Homo Netherlandus]]

>Those of us in Europe, especially in the Netherlands, are big believers in [[Homo Bureaucraticus]].
- [[Ed]] in response to [[Todd]]'s [[SoD]] on LTG [[McMaster]]






!!![[How DOD Acquires Weapon Systems]]
-by [[Schwartz]] for [[DM 08]]

<iframe src="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1put1jZye_SHRZja1PWYRna0Cz5yBTro0/preview" width="840" height="880"></iframe>






!!![[How does the Chief of Staff Help?]]
-From [[Industry Day Lecture: ASA(ALT)]] by Mr. [[White]]

*Q: "How does going to the Army CoS streamline the process given the extra work involved to get briefs to that level?"
*A: He doesn't have time to keep up with 847 programs. But on the important things, by going to the CoS at the [[Milestone Decision Points]] it prevents requirements creep and ensures we're still aligned with the vision. Usually it keeps things moving quickly because we are right on track. Once in awhile he lets us know very clearly where we have departed.

-by Doug [[Douds]] (see also [[Lincoln]])
<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/qhMsQm0dufU" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen style="width:100%;height:350px;"/>

!!![[How Space Enables Landpower]]

*[[Dex]]'s [[SoD]] presentation for [[TSC 11]], Air Force and Space
*Review of Sir Hugh [[Trenchard]], the air theorist
*Dex: would like to get your notes
*What landpower functions/capabilities does Space enable?
**Functions: All of them
***Maneuver: GPS
***Fires: Precision fires, redundancy with traditional methods, digital fires
***Intel: ISR
***Mission Command: Oh yes
***Sustainment: ....
***Protection






!!![[How the War College Spells Joint]]

[[Dave]]: How does the War College Spell Joint? A. R. .... M. Y.






!!![[How to Start a Movment]] by Derek Sivers from [[SL 09]]

<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/V74AxCqOTvg" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen style="width:100%;height:350px;"/>








!!![[How Wars End]] by Dan [[Reiter]]

*[[The Korean War]] chapter reading for [[TWS 15]]






!!Sir Michael [[Howard]]

*Related to [[Just War Theory]]; War can be controlled
*Renowned British military historian
*Author/co-author/editor of more than 20 books or monographs

Trying to answer four questions:

*Can war be controlled?
*If so, what controls exist?
*Why do the controls exist?
*Will these controls hold?

[[Howard's Objective or War]]
"War is instrumental, not elemental: its only legitimate object is a better peace."
- clearly related to [[Liddel Hart]]

[[Brett]]: Hey, if you guys get an email from Dave, do you mind fowarding it to me? Because I probably didn't get it.
All: Something to do with [[Guadalcanal|Why Marines Are Paranoid]].
[[Dave]]: Yeah, that's twice now. You know, Brett is like Kim. She doens't get hysterical, but she's not afraid to get historical.






!!![[I don't like my kid]] from [[TSC 29-30]]

[[Todd]]: Are any of you interested in a bring-your-kid-to-work day?
[[Dex]]: Why? I don't like my kid.






!!![[I Got Traded]] for [[TSC 06]]

>One time I got traded for an airfield.
-Mark talking [[Theater Security Cooperation]] on being in Ghana who provided use of an airfield in exchange for sending a doctor to their jungle warfare school to teah jungle medicine.






!!![[Ideal vs Total War]]

*See also slide 17 of [[Clausewitz NTL Slides]]

[[Frank]] and [[Vanya]] have issues with the term "Total War."

[[Clausewitz]] points out in [[On War Book One]] that a state will never tap all of its resources. So technically they will never wage total war. But, per Frank, you could consider it an "ideal" in the same way you have an "ideal" for ethics even though you can never achieve it.

Clausewitz stair steps:

*Absolute war
*War with the means readily available
*"Ideal" war as described above






!!![[If someone tells you...]]

>If someone has to tell you how great this job is... it's not.
-[[Todd]]

!!![[In Groups Out Groups]] from [[SL 14]]

From discussion on [[Leader-Member Exchange]]

*In-group relationships: more information, influence, communication, beter performance
*Out-group relationships: more turnover, less commitment, reduced promotions

Getting everyone in the in-group

*Is it a good idea and how do you do it?
*How does this relationship develop?
*How does it effect strategic thinking?

>If you're in the room, you're in the game.
-[[Frank]]






!!![[India-China DMZ]] from [[TSC 05]]

>So India and China do have a [[DMZ]]. It's called Nepal.
-Dave






!!![[Industrial Fabric Theory]]

*Lord Tiverton and the RAF
*William C. Sherman
*Bomber advocates at ACTS

>Industry consists... of a complex system of interlocking factories, each of which makes only its allotted part of the whole. .... Accordingly, in the majority of industries it is necessary to destroy certain elements of the industry only, in order to cripple the whole. ... On the declaration of war, these key plants should be made the object of a systematic....






!!![[Industry Day Lecture: ASA(ALT)]]
-Mr. Jeff [[White]]

*ASA(ALT) manages 847 Programs of Record

!!![[Industry Day Lecture: Boeing]]
-by Leanne [[Caret]], [[Boeing]]

[img[https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/KneUzgwHZ5hNApn1EA9fq4tRxTI-y4ST8UFDL4Y1M1Q9LzzhXsyfNzF925-4hBhOqY2HVPE_uKLIzK7Y3lsvgkPS2k4-KwwL7B_UZUJ5jpS43gXNgTiXCAOea6tt2jvoVhdOwsAeSIM=w2400]]

>The integrity of our products is only as strong as the weakest link. So our integrity is based on the integrity of our people.
---
>The only thing that interupts an employee is a customer.
---
*We've spent a lot of time trying to break down the chain of command so that the information will move where it needs to go.
*So the subordinate that reaches out/up must have a lot of courage (and wisdom) to know that someone beyond his/her chain needs to know something. It also takes courage for the person receiving the "phone call" to take it seriously and not push it down on the chain of command.
---
>Success is never final... (Churchill)

{{Be Who You Are}}
---
*Q: Can you tell us what Boeing is doing about the competitive [[Space]] Environment?
*A: "No. You guys no what's classified." ... Side note that there are currently no Rules of Engagement in Space. And we are going to need that.
---
>We are not as risk averse as people think. The key is to be able to fail fast.
---
*It took $26,000,000,000 to build the first 787. So when a customer wants tech data about how technology is designed and how it works, the answer is probably not. "If we can't recoup most of that $26B then there won't be another $26B coming behind to develop the next plane."






!!![[Industry Day Lecture: Know Your Market]]
-CEO of Synexxus, Small Biz for [[DM 09]]

''Message: What's in your market?''

*You don't understand the world if you don't understand what's in the market.
*The strength of our market is the industrial base. What's in your market is what your industrial base has to work with.
*[The following is "largest" by market cap....]
*Lagest retailer, Amazon, owns no products (well, they bought Whole Foods)
*Largest car hire, Uber, owns no cars
*Largest hotel provider, AirB&B, owns no hotels
*Largest car company, Tesla, only produced 17k cars last year and has no profits

>The cost of gathering information determines the size of the organization.
-Ron [[Coase]]






!!![[Ineligible to Serve]]

>71 percent of young Americans between 17 and 24 are ineligible to serve in the military—that is 24 million of the 34 million people of that age group. 
-[[The Heritage Foundation]], from [[Mark]]'s presentation on [[Young Americans Unable to Serve]]

*Part of [[Theory of War and Strategy]] and [[National Security Policy and Strategy]]

*[[Nye and Welch: Four Dominant Paradigms]] also includes Marxism

!!![[Iran's Major Export]]

>The major export from Iran is malign influence. Across the region and around the world.
-[[GEN Dunford]]












!!![[Irregular Warfare]]

>A violent struggle among state and non-state actors for legitimacy and influence over the relevant populations.
- [[JP 1-02]] (but no definition of regular warfare)

!!![[Jim & Susannah]]

[img[https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/cEiikmf4KB2GcjzlD5ec5488EKxzr8oaUzYxBs6NUTLaxvH3Gjv9kDF0DUwvQQsSoOqaW4q9stLoUPwbBjhCB8SYePE6xtyOPNrUk_q-x8NY2r229ozpHvQuU1xDPfXHtJeMEWurJ88=w2400]]






*On the one hand, "Thank you for your service" is complimentary. On the other hand, it could be seen as patronizing. "Thank you for doing what you do so that me and my kids don't have to."






!!![[Jim on Hegemonic Atmosphere]] regarding [[Scott]]'s presentation on [[Senkaku Islands]]

>The way [[China]] plays this situation has implications for the atmosphere in the region. They want to dominate the region. But if they do this wrong, then other regional participants will seek to undermine them.






!!![[Jim on Sun Tzu]] from [[TWS 09]]

>I think what [[Sun Tzu]] was really advocating was DIME. Capital "D". Capital "I". Lowercase "m". Capital "E".
-[[Jim]]






!!![[Jim on Weaponizing E]] from oral [[presentation|Presentations]] in [[NSPS 13]] on [[Russia]]

>If you weaponize the Economic Instrument, then that cuts both ways.






!!![[Jim's Hierarchy of Security Concerns]] from [[NSPS 01]]

>Think of it like Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs. The lowest levels are the most existential. The guy in the inner city of Chicago is worried about gang violence and violence from police. Those in the rural midwest who don't have those concerns. So they can afford to consider issues like illegal immigration and so forth.
-See [[Levels and Domains of National Security]]






!!![[Jim's Note on Stories]] for [[SL 16]] Strategic Communication

>Andrew [[Hill]] talked about the importantace of stories in his presentation on [[Systems Thinking]] because it's how humans think and relate. That is relevant to strategic communication because leaders need to develop narratives. If they don't, they will need to work even harder with their other strategies and still probably be less effective.

#Having a plan for whatever the conflict is
#What decisions are the strategic level leaders making?
#Grand Strategy and Theory per [[Liddell Hart]]

!!Jomini

*[[Clausewitz]] did not say that there are no principles. He acknowledged that at the tactical levels there were certainly principles. But (per [[Vanya]]), 

Jomini Sought To:

*Clarify the nature of war by explaining the nau

Key Beliefs

*War and the task fo the commanding general is an intellectual exercise
*"That strategy is the key to warfare."
*All strategy is controlled by invariable scientific principles
*These general rules apply to all wars
*"That these principles prescribe ''offensive'' action to ''mass forces'' against weaker enemy forces at some ''decisive point'' if strategy is to lead to victory."






!!!Steven M. [[Jones]]

*Author of "Improving Accountabiltiy for Effective Command Climate: A Strategic Imperative"

!!![[JSTARS Requirement]]

Q: What about JSTARS recap

>The JSTARS requirement was basic

*The assumption was made was that the platform would be surviable and would be available. And it has been for the last 30 years. 
*Both the Chinese and the Russians have an anti-radiation missle that can reach out a couple of hundred miles and target that asset.
*Our questions were:
**Is it survivable out into the late 20's? Probably.
**Will we
*We didn't ask if there was a 
*The only requirement we added was ''if'' it's going to go on an airplane it has to be survivable. That's going to drive us to a different solution






!!![[Just One Naval Officer]] from [[DM 10]]
"""
[[Eric]]: Maybe we want to have 10 man squads. But then Brett says, 'No, we can go with one man squads. We just need one naval officer.'
[[Bob]]: ...with a heads up display.
[[Brett]]: That's all we need.






!![[Just War Theory]] from [[TWS 08]]

* Reading: Martin L. [[Cook]]
* Reading: Sir Michael [[Howard]]

Jus Ad Bellum (Justice of War): I

*Just cause: A decision for war must vindicate justice itself in response to some serious evil, such as aggressive attack.
*Just intent. The ends sought in a decision for war must include the restoration of peac with justice and must not seek self-aggrandizement or the total devastation of another nation.
*Last resort: The Just War
*Legitimate authority: A decision for war may be made and declared only by proplery constituted government authoritiy.

video: [[Michael Walzer on Just War Theory]]






!!!John L [[Kallerson]] from [[SL 05]]
*Wrote about the [[Three Ethical Lenses]]






!!!Paul [[Kan]]

*Lecture on [[Sun Tzu]], [[TWS 09]]
*Also an expert on [[drug trade, cartels, and gangs|https://www.armywarcollege.edu/news/article/1074]]

>You have Sun Tzu saying, ‘This is kind of the environment in which we live. It’s bloodier; it’s more warlike, so you probably can’t be more peaceful. You probably can’t re-establish the old order. So maybe we can just make warfare less bloody and have it end more quickly.
- Paul Kan in [[War Room Podcast|https://warroom.armywarcollege.edu/special-series/great-strategists/sun-tzu-art-war-great-strategists-episode-2/]]






*What is war?
**War is for conquest..."and after having conquered the world... the conqueror shall enjoy it..."
*Why should war be fought?
**Conquer or be conquered
*How should war be fought?
**Defense of the realm is necessary, but not sufficient
**[[Four Types of War]]
*How are wars won?
**Depends on type and purpose of war
**Conquest brings victory, but it also changes the equation of states

[[Mandala Model]]






From the [[Boesche]] reading:

>In another way, moral considerations did enter into Kautilya's calculations. Whereas it is best to wage war against an unjust king who has no public support, it is wise to avoid war with a righteous king whose subjects will fight energetically on his behalf. Kautilya noted that if one has a choice about where to attack , it is always best to attack an unjust kingdom, because "The subjects help the king who is justly behaved."
-pg 21






!!![[Kautilyan War Ethics]] from [[TWS 09]]

[[Frank]]: [[Kautilya]] is not for the sake of peace, but for the good of the empire. He is making a case based on the importance of [[Dharma]]

[[Boesche]]:

>Beyond protecting the kingdom, the king who uses Kautilya's science can bring himself and his subjects the three goods of life--"material gain, spiritual good and pleasures."
-pg 16

**Ajax fleet: general purpose armored vehicle
**MIV: Mechanized Infantry Vehicle
**New medium cal lethality platform
*Upgrade to the Leopard II

>Equipment is not going to win wars.












!!!Victor [[Klemperer]]

He wrote a famous memoir as a Jew in WWII Germany. He was married to a non-Jew, so he was protected as long as he stayed married. He anticipated he was finally going to be rounded up on April 14th. But on the night of the 13th, Dresden was destroyed. And that's where the records were. So he, and others, threw their stars away and started working as a refugee.

!!![[La Siete Partidas]]

[[Wikipedia Entry|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siete_Partidas]]

The Siete Partidas (Spanish pronunciation: [ˈsjete parˈtiðas], "Seven-Part Code") or simply Partidas was a Castilian statutory code first compiled during the reign of Alfonso X of Castile (1252–1284), with the intent of establishing a uniform body of normative rules for the kingdom. The codified and compiled text was originally called the Libro de las Leyes (Old Spanish: Livro de las legies) (Book of Laws).[citation needed] It was not until the 14th century that it was given its present name, referring to the number of sections into which it is divided.

The Partidas had great significance in Latin America as well, where it was followed for centuries, up to the 19th century. Although the code concentrates on legislative issues, it has also been described as a "humanist encyclopedia," as it addresses philosophical, moral and theological topics as well, including the Greco-Roman, Judeo-Christian and Islamic viewpoints.






!![[Landpower]]

From [[Greg]]: Landpower is the ability—by threat, force, or occupation—to gain, sustain, and exploit control over land, resources, and people

Doctrinal Definitions (JP 1-02)

*No definition of land (or air or sea) power
*Land Control Operations: "The employment of land forces, supported by naval and air forces (as appropriate) to control vital areas of the land domain."
*Similar for sea control operations
*No equivalent for air/aerospace control operations
---
*Army ADP 1, //The Army// (2012) "Landpower is the ability--by threat, force, or occupation--to gain, sustain, and exploit control over land, resources, and people."
*[[Johnson]] pg 9, The ability in peace, crisis, and war to exert prompt and sustained influence on or from land.

{{Landpower vs Land Forces}}






!!![[Landpower vs Land Forces]]
"""
[[Jim]]: The Army measures [[Landpower]] in terms of capacity, capabilty, and readiness.
[[Vanya]]: I think that's more a description of land forces vs landpower.
See also: [[Frank on Power]]






Under Lao Szu's Daoism, there is a natural harmony to things. And power comes as part of a mandate from heaven. pg 64 of [[Art of War]]:

>When one treats people with benevolence, justice, and righteousness, and reposes confidence in them, the army will be united in mind and all will be happy to serve their leaders. The Book of Changes [I Ching] says: 'In happiness at overcoming difficulties, people forget the danger of death.'

This certainly shows elements of the [[Trinity]].

!!![[Leaders Role in Culture]]
