!!![[Lecture by Mike Morell]]

''4 Questions on Enhanced Interrogation''

*Was it necessary?
*Was it effective?
*Was it legal? (Holder's office later came down with a different judgement.)
*Is is moral?

Context:

*Largest attack on the nation
*Credible evidence that there were more attacks to come
*Wanted WMD
*Had one (turned out not to be true) that they had one
*Had captives who weren't talking

The moral question: How can the US do such a thing?

The other moral question: What is the morality of deciding not to do it?

>I don't believe anyone knows what decision they would have actually made if they had been in President Bush's shoes. People make it sound like it would be an easy decision. I don't think it was.

Title 10 vs Title 50.

>I don't think it's a good thing for the nations top intelligence agency to be involved in the things (paramilitary) that you guys are responsible for. It is:
--a distractor for the CIA leadership
--a distractor for the national leadership
--

Why did he resign his senior fellowship at the Kennedy School? It was not that Chelsea Manning was invited to come speak. It was the bestowing of the honor of a fellowship on someone who has

>The thing that really scares me is the inability of our politicians to come together and compromise to make the decisions to move the economy forward. ... If we don't fix this, we are going to become weaker and weaker as a nation.

What are the differences between Presidents Bush and Obama?

>I say that strategic intelligence has never been more important than it is today.


>We did dishes together, becuse 


>President Obama didn't really like people. People accused him of not going to the Hill


>President Bush was an intuitive thinker.


>Condi Rice would say, 'Mr. President we need to have a principles meeting on that.' And he would say, 'Why? I just made the decision.'


>Very different people, very different leadership styles, very different decision making styles. But when it comes down the national security Policy, there was maybe 15 degrees difference between them. Because the nature of the job and American interests in the world push you in a certain direction.


>Cyber crime now generates more money than the illicit drug trade.


>The third option is there a Snowden like character or group of people that think they are smarter than the entire US government and the legislative branch.

>Cyber gives someone the ability to move first. Imagine in football if the offensive line had the ability to move a second before the defensive line. That's cyber.

>When I was the deputy director, I visited your country more than any other country in the world. The director of the ISI was a good friend of mine. I saw him more than

Pakistan is our best counterterrorism partner. They have taken more terrorists off the battlefield than all other countries put together.

On the other hand, Pakistan supports some terrorist groups that act against India. So your country plays both sides.

>India is not an existential threat to Pakistan. Used to be. Not anymore. The existential threat to Pakistan is the economy and extremism.

On confidence intervals

*Everyone was wrong on the topic of WMD in Iraq. 
**He had chemical weapons
**He was developing a biological weapons
**He was reconstitution his nuclear weapons capability
**He had the ballistic missle capability to deliver it all.

They didn't seriously asked themselves what is their confidence levels in their judgements.

They didn't get the judgement wrong. They got their confidence in the judgement wrong.

Intelligence is always an uncertain thing. It is like looking at 250 pieces of a 1000 piece puzzle.

On sharing

*Before 9/11 it was need to know. "I get to decide if you need to know what I have." Afterwards it became a "obligation to provide." Then everyone was decideing they needed to know everything.

Three phases of cooperating with foreign countries:

*Sit down and talk about analytic views.
*Sharing data. We show you things, orally and in writing, and you show us things. There are 50-60 countries that we're in that relation with.
*We are conducting operations together.

*All intelligence relationships are bilateral. You can't 


>China will not allow a unified Korea on their border. They will intervene.

>Russian is a declining power. Rapidly declining. Economy, demographics. Putin is playing an extremely weak hand very well. Everything he does is to 

>Why is Russia supporting the Taliban in Afghanistan? One reason and one reason only: To make our life hard in Afghanistan.


Iran: there is a ... Iran conducts terrorist activities as a matter of statecraft. ... It is the Iranian policy for

Google: Supreme Leader Israel  9 point plan

What the rest of the region needs to understand is that even if Iran [behaved properly], they would still be an extremely important influence in the region because of their economy and their culture.

>I don't see China as a threat. I don't talk about it as a threat. I talk about it as a challenge.

>The relationship going forward between the United States and China

Two in the right direction:

*Both the United States and China have a significant interest in a successful Chinese economy.  We shouldn't be afraid.
*I've talked to Chinese intelligence officers. We have more overlapping interests than not.

Two in the wrong direction:

*We have the two largest militaries in the world. That means you have to plan to fight a war against each other, you have to buy equipment to plan to use against each other, and
*Graham [[Allison]]. Because they are the rising power: they want more say.

>There is an opportunity here (see [[Liberalism]]) if China decides to play by the rules of the international community. So we were wrong not to support them in developing a regional aid bank. No one followed us on that, including the Brits. That was in accordance with international norms. And we have not done enough to stop what they are doing with the [islands in the South China Sea]. That is not in accord with the international community's norms.

Recommendation to see the documentary: The Gatekeepers






!!![[Lecture from The IG]] by LTG David [[Quantock]]

Problems we have with command climate:

*We talk about [[Mission Command]] but we don't practice it in application
*There are a lot of buttheads out there. Leaders are not open to feedback. They think they've learned everything they need to learn.

{{Why People Talk to You}}

{{Requirement for Exemplary Conduct}}

{{Servant Leadership}}

''NOTE: You cannot use the IG for adverse actions''

* When you see an IG stamped adverse action 15-6, we just pused it over to the command channels. THEY do the 15-6 and then it just comes back through us.

The Consequences of "Bad" Advice

Examples:

*"This is not a serious sexual assault ... therefore you can direct an AR 15-6 Investigation. 
**WRONG. All Sexual Assault must be referred to CID for action. The Commander has NO discretion in this matter
*"As long as there is no cost to the Governmet (unlimited miles/no reimbursement for gas) you can usue a rental car, paid for with a Government Travel Card, for personal business"
**WRONG. IW the JFTF a Govt funrished rental car cannot be used for personal business
*"No one is going to see this AR 15-6 Investigation but you, Sir"
**WRONG. All 15-6 Investigations with Adverse Findings and Subjets in the rank of Major and above are now retained and are subject to review / presentation to DA Promotion Boards

ASSISTANCE: ~45,000 Issues brought to the IG annually; 39% are "I just have a question" like what happened to my bonus

Regarding adverse actions in a command: Before you, the commander, decide to Do Nothing, be sure to Do Something. Otherwise you become the investigating officer (you made a decision, yes), and if there's nothing documented then you can be substantiated for Failing to Take Action.

*IG's AND Commanders must report allegations of impropriety against senior officeials (COL(P), GO, and SES) to DAIG's INvestigations Division (SAID-IN) ''within 2 working days'' of receipt of the complaint.

*2849 Reported Senior Officer Allegations
**"What Soldiers think is wrong"
*775 Credible SO Allegations
**"What is Actually Investigated"
*163 Substantiated SO Allegations
**"What is Really Wrong"

Amongst Senior (O7+) and Non-Senior, substantiation rates for Statuatory Reprisal is about 5% of the allegations

{{Whistleblower Reprisal Conditions}}






!!Lecture on Airpower
Given by Tami [[Biddle]] for [[TWS 12]]

* Recon and Commo
* Defense and penetration of Air Space
* Artillery Spotting
* Contact Patrol
* Ground Attack
* Sea Attack
* Battlefield Interdiction bombing
* Long range bombardment forinterdiction and coercion (denial and punishment}
* Can the latter succeed independently? Win wars alone?

This is what [[Trenchard]] and Billy [[Mitchell]] are talking about: very aggressive, offensive oriented, going directly to the enemy's center.

---
!!!The Value of Airspace: Battle of Britain, 1940

*Massive coalition in action, keeping the island available as an unsinkable battleship
*And it worked. Throughout the battle, the allies continued to use it to mobilize for the longer war

---
!!!Strategic Bombardment

*Coming back to [[Trenchard]] and [[Douhet]], they assumed:
**Airplanes would continue to advance in capability, therefore they would always be able to stay ahead of any countermeasures
**...and this was a false assumption
**By 1917-18, the Brits had a pretty complex aerial defense system in order to protect troops from this new threat
***Yes, Virginia. 

---

{{The Smuts Report of 1917}}

---

{{Trenchard}}

---

!!!The Legacy of World War I

*Everyone is interested in long range bombardment. This was true for all WWI participants, although manifested in different ways.
*Part of Churchill's argument for staying in the war must be supported by the development of a more robust bombing capability. Especially after they were pushed off the continent at Dunkirk.
*Lord Tiberton: starts to lay down a theory about looking for critical vulnerabilities in the enemy's infrastructure.
*US adopted the Tiberton theory become the [[Industrial Fabric Theory]]

---
*Pre-service, the air component began an insurgency at Maxwell.

---

{{Industrial Fabric Theory}}

---
!!!B-17 "Flying Fortress" built to intercept ships at sea

*In 1943, the U.S. should up with the norden bomb site and attempts to go after the ball bearing supply in Schweinfurt (twice) with high level self-defending bombers.
*The enemy will continue to adapt.
*Defenses against/responses to [[long range bombing]]as
**comunications: radar spotting sensing FLAK Fighters
**Dispersal of industry, substitution, concealment
**Deversion of attacking forces (decoy fires, decoy factories); distraction (search lights)
*October 1943:
**291 bombers dispatched
**60 shot down
**138 damaged
**598 Americans lost.
--The death knell of unescorted daylight bombing.

---







!!![[Lecture on Army Budget]]
-by [[MG Ferrari]] for [[DM 04]]
-(Not just about the budget, but that's the name I put on it. Deal with it.)

{{We are horrific at saving lives}}

{{Not a ringing endorsement}}

*You need to chage your mindset that your allegiance is to the wider institution. That's difficult for some people to understand.
*Every drawdown starts the same. "The money's gone. Have a nice day."
*Usually we hold on to all the experience. Out of loyalty maybe. Out of a sense that we need people to hang onto knowledge during the low point in the cycle. But guess what? It's never worked.
*GEN Odierno made a couple of decisions:
**That we wouldn't just slash people out of the force.
**We did get rid as many older folks as we can. If you hold onto the older folks, and promotion rates plummet, then the mid-tier folks just leave. Then you won't have them later. 
**Normally we hold on to as many flags as possible. Makes sense, right? Once you fold a flag it's hard to stand back up. But we have to get rid of people. So, by definition, you end up with hollowed out units.
**The new idea was to get rid of structure faster than we got rid of people. Get rid of structure at 20k a year and get rid of people at 15k a year.
*It wasn't until FY16 that we saved one dollar for the $30B that we had to. So it had to come from somewhere else.
**Our CTCs had turned into deployment readiness centers. So we put those 
*So we didn't save on personnel and didn't save on readiness.
**So we slashed and burned installation. It was a huge bill payer.

>Soldiers didn't die at Kasserine Pass because we didn't pad the buildings at home station.

*We also cut back on sustainment
*So we went to modernization. Three parts:
**Science and Technology. GEN O didn't add to S&T, but he didn't cut it. Because otherwise "three chiefs from now" there will be nothing.
**New development. It takes ten years. And since 1986 we have not had one successful new development after spending tens of billions of dollars. Lots of reason for that, but the empirical return on investmet is zero.
**Incremental improvement. "We are really reallly really good at that." So we used portfolio theory in essence.
**So I told the Chief: let's start at the top of the list and kill the top three new start priorities.
**"Let me ask you this Chief: Do you think we'll fight on the left side of 2020 or right side of 2020."
**"I think we'll be at war before the end of the decade."
**"Ok, so if we keep all our new starts, we might have new equipment by 2025, years after you need it. But the Soldiers will go to war with what
*The defense budget is a sine wave. What we miss every time is we miss going up, and we miss going down. The Cheif said, "The next inflection point may be in 2016 with a Presidential  election. If that happens, I want to be prepared to spend the money." 
**We called it "The Chia Pet Strategy." We kept the mid-grade officers and NCOs. It takes 5-10 years to build those guys. When the budget comes back, we'll have them to grow.

{{What role does the second Chief play?}}

*Three assumptions:
**You'll be out of Iraq and Afghanistant by the end of 2017.
**Europe is a lillypad. You're not going to fight there, but you'll need to deploy from there.
**Prepare the Army to fight a regional competitor. Like Korea. Not a peer competitor. There are no peer competitors out there.
*So we created SFABs so we can stay in the middle east without consuming combat units.
*And the new leadership said:
**Great Power competition is bad. i.e. The Army better be able to fight the Russians.
**You also have to be able to fight tonight in Korea.
*So for the first time we had strategy driving resources instead of resources driving stucture.
**We are now ready to grow personnel into the structure.
**And we couldn't afford to grow new ABCTs. So we're changing the force mix by telling Infantry BCTs that they are going to be Armor BCTs.
*We're at risk of going 
*We have sometthing that we didn't have in the 80s. We have:
#a v3 Abrams tank. Ready to go.
#a v4 Bradley. Ready to go.
#a new howitzer, PIM. Ready to go.
#the JLTV to replace the HMMWV. Ready to go.
#The AMP-V to replace the Vietnam era M113. Ready to go.
*Those are the five big systems. All ready for the next war.

{{Colonels Do Three Things}}

{{Congress noticed before we did}}

{{Change is harder with tree huggers}}






!!![[Lecture on Command and Control]] by Dr. John [[Bonin]] for [[TSC 20]]

*Quote from Martin van Creavald "From PLATO to NATO...
*[[Command and Control]]: The exercise of aughority and direction by a properly designated commander over assigned and attached forces in the accomplishment of a mission.
*C2 Philosophy, Concepts, and Relationships
**What should C2 do?
**What must C2 do?
**Command and Control are separate, but interrelated.
*Command resides with commanders. It consists of authority, decision making, and leadership.
*Command is mostly art, but some science.
**Control is how commanders execute command. It is mostly science, but no art.
**Distinction between unity of command and unity of effort.
*C2 Theory
**C2 is the exercise of authority and direction over forces to accoplish a mission
**C2 is about what are we commanding and controlling, not who we are commanding and controlling
**Consider "span of control" (5-7) vs "span of complexity" (2-5)
*Joint C2 Doctrine. JFCs exercise command by:
**establishing support relationships (support is a relationship in Joint, not in Army)
**Distributing and prioritizing allocation of forces
**Committing reserves
**Staying attuned to the needs of subordinates against seniors and allies/partners
**Guiding and motivating the organization toward the military end state (more indirect than direct, but still essential)
*NDU: Lessons Encountered- Learning from the Long War
**Unity of command is a key tenet in Joint Operations and remains relevant... unity of command seems to have been bypassed in the development of disjointed Command and Control structures in the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.
**Colaition efforts lend legitimacy and ease manpower and material requirements. Coalitions also confound unity of command [and require large coalition stafffs] and may hurt unity of effort.

__Bottom Line__

*Traditional decorinal focus on Unity of Command
*Mostly about Command Relationships and Organizations
*Forces are normally provided OPCON to a lower Joint Force Commander, but that remains the perogative of the Combatant Commander
*Common definitions, but subject to interpretation and adaption to the circoumstnaces
*Joint doctrine is authoritative (Joint trumps Service) but is a product of a consensus authorship

__Assorted__

*A [[JFC]] can only have one Service Component Command per Service but can have as many Functional Components as required. Usually Land, Air, Maritime, SOF, but you could have one e.g. medical






!!![[Lecture on Country Teams]] Panel

*Panel: [[AMB Shields]]; [[Ms. Fitzgerald]] Deputy Chief of Mission; [[McCannell]], USAID; FSO [[Greene]]
*McCannell: US Gov provides about $20B in assistance thru [[USAID]],  US Citizens provide another $22B. One additional role of USAID
*FSO Greene

!!![[Lecture on Cross Functional Teams]]

''Question: What is the problem that we're trying to solve?''

*1-Put everything under one roof? Streamline the process?
**"In the near term it doesn't feel like we've streamlined anything at all. We may have just added another layer."

*2-This could be see as an attempt by the Army CoS to take acquisition control away from the Secretariat and move them under a four star. Ok, but currently that is against the law.
**There are 72 legislative change proposals stapled to the back of the plan for Futures Command.

*3-This could be a way of combining the "Big A" acquisition circles to make institutional decisions and get resources aligned.
**Well, it combines requirements and acquisition circles, but that still leaves the PPBE out.

Regarding the idea that Elon Musk could produce an electric drive tank in a year:

>The more you know about a domain, the less likely you are to  innovate because you tend to narrowlly define the problem. But the less you know about a domain the better the chance that all your ideas are stupid.

Are Millenials:

*Self-absorbed? No, not as much as the baby boomers
*Skeptical? No, not as much as Gen Xers
*Skeptical of Authority? Well, they live with their parents more than ever even as unemployment continues to improve
*Neglected? Well, they don't feel as compelled to get drivers licenses and help

!!![[Lecture on Professional Ethics]]

*Given by Leonard [[Wong]] for [[SL 06]]
---
*Analysis of annual mandatory training requirements showed that there were 297 days of mandatory training even there were only 256 available training days.
*That led Wong to conclude there were multiple problems
*[[Ethical Fading]]: (definition) It's not really an ethical issue
*Consequence: Individuals get to define right and wrong
*Conequence: All things become suspect
*Consequence: Hides careerism. You can't tell the difference between lying for the 'right reason' and due to self promotion.
*Consequences: It teaches hypocrisy. And it starts ''before''' the Army at the MEPS station when they ask "Have you ever smoked marijuana?"

>We're creating an environment where everything is too rosy because everyone is afraid to paint the true picture. You just wonder where it will break, when it will fall apart.

*Consequence: If the professon doesn't fix it, someone else will.

What next?

*Acknowledge the problem:
**Admit that we lie.
**Admist that we don't like to lie.
**We force other people to lie by passing requirements down and telling subordinates to prioritize.
**The systems forces everyone to lie.
*Exercise restraint
*Lead truthfully.

The Reaction

Phase I: Denial

* Reports all over the media saying the lying is commonplace in the Army.

>The timing on this coule be better." ... "When is a good time to publish a studying saying that we lie?"

*Below O6: "You just described the world we live in." Above O6: "What are you talking about?"
*Reaction in Doctrine Man comments: "In other news, water is wet."

Reaction Phase II: The Bureaucracy Bends. Suddenly leaders and organizations are trying to wrestle with the problem.

Reaction Phase III: Is anything is going to change? Below O6: "We continue to live this." Above O6: "We're continuing to work it."

How did we get here? We would rather look at a checklist than trust people.






!!![[Lecture on Thucydides]]
-by [[Craig Nation]]

{{Marshall on Thucydides}}

"""
WHO WAS THUCYDIDES?
 
	•  "Of all manifestations of power, restraint impresses the most."
	• Thucydides biography: From Trace.  High social status, family had money.  Served as an Athenian general.  Exiled from Athens due to military failure. Lived through the Peloponnesian War. 
		○ Contemporary of Socrates, Sophocles, Alcibiedies
		○ High motivation to tell the story he's telling.  Influenced by the Periclean democratic ideal. He believes in the cause of Athens.  
		○ The war ends in the defeat and destruction of Athens… He has a moral imperative to tell the story. 
	• 29 when war breaks out.  55 when it ends.
	

WHAT WAS THE WAR ABOUT?

	• Timeline of events before the war:
		○ 490-497: Persian Wars
		○ 479: Founding of the Delian League
		○ 445: The Thirty Years Peace
		○ 431: Peloponnesian War begins
	• Competitive bipolarity… Two powers exist.  Contending alliances, Delian League (Athens), Peloponnesian League (Sparta)
	• 3 Phases of the War:
		a. The Archidamian War (431-421)
		b. The Peace of Nicias and the Sicilian Expedition (421-413)
			i. War begins a logic of its own. 
			ii. Alcibiedies leads Athenians in two great failures
		c. The Ionian War (413-404)
			i. Sparta wins, Athens falls
	• Nature of the war: Hoplite warfare


WHAT IS THE RELEVANCE OF THIS STORY?

	• The big questions:
		○ What is the nature war?  
		○ What are the causes of war?  What are the sources of great power warfare?
		○ How are wars fought?
		○ How are wars terminated?
	
	• Structural causation:
		○ The growth of Athenian power and the fear it provoked in Sparta
		○ States are inevitably going to act to reinforce their power or to gain power. 
		
	• Complex causation:
		○ Fear, interest, and honor… Multiple causes, chance and contingency (complex causality)

	• Why did the war occur?
		○ Culture matters… Culture gap between Athens and Sparta, contrasting strategic cultures
		
	• How are wars fought?
		○ Strategy is comprehensive- multiple variables affect outcomes
			§ Reputation matters, alliance stability matters, technology matters, geo-strategy matters, leadership matters.  
			§ In grand strategy everything matters
		○ Strategy is dynamic: strategy must be constantly adapted and recast
			§ Constant strategic adaptations
		○ Unpredictability: war becomes an affair of chance

	• Conflict termination: How do wars end?

	• Who wins the war, anyway?

	• Ethical and moral context
		○ Power decides outcomes… Message of the Melian Dialogue.  The strong do what they will and the weak suffer what they must
		
	• Thucydides is a reflection on the use and abuse of power
		







!!![[Lecture on TRANSCOM]], 30 Jan 2018

{{GEN McDew}}

---
*90% of taking troops to war is commercial
*40% of the cargo capacity is commercial
---
{{Countries in the AOR}}
---
*Value programming. The types of values to take on become the way you see the world. And you may not be able to change that proramming. But you need to reconcile what that programming is.
*But adult value programming is also possible.
**In [[Desert Storm]] our programming was the [[Powell Doctrine]]. Sept 11th changed some of that.
*2+2+1 construct: 2 big adversaries, and "that was starting to shackle our minds."

>The study of histroy is important. It allows you to understand how things can happen. But it can also ''shackle your mind'' to what happened. One is healthy. One is not.

*"So I question what is programming young captains today." We have taken for granted our uncontested access.

*On leadership: You will have more and more autonomy. But as Llyod Austin told me: remember that you still have a boss. Don't focus on all the things you have the autonomy to do.
**Know who is spending your money and why. I've walked in to organizations, looked at a list of who is spending money, and cut it in half. Arbitrarily. Wait for the screaming to start and then you can work it out.

>Diversity means bringing the best people you can around the table snd not worry about what they look like. You need to have diversity of thought. It's impossible to measure. But if you have a qualified woman or qualified person of color around the table, you're increasing the diversity of thought. We're value programmed differently.

>I didn't know what a cloud was. I didn't know what big data was. Now I'm confident we're on a path to incorporate AI enabled by big data hosted in the cloud.

>One of my priorities is readiness. I have to have that one. Or else I'll be drummed out of the four-star club.

__Four priorities__

#Today's readiness for tomorrow's ....
#Cyber Domain
#Evolving the Command for tomorrow
#Building a more talented and diverse work force

*When I was young I thought it was our big sophisticated military that was why other countries did our bidding. No. It's our economic power. And now that our coutry is indebted to some of those other great powers it's going to cause problems. There is not a significant port in the world that China is not investing in. And that is eventually going to cause us access problems. For some reason the folks in the interagency don't think this is a problem. They say it's just an economic issue. But it's more than that.







!!![[Lecture on Vietnam Escalation]], July 1965; by [[Frank]], for [[NSPS 10]]

*Security Environment: Cold War
**Fall of China, 1949
**Korean War, 1950-1953
**Truman authorizes military aid to France to support its war in Indochina, May 1950
**Over 400 advisors working with the French in Vietnam, 1952 (keep France in NATO)
***French surrender at Dien Bien Phu, May 1954
**The Geneva Accords, July 1954
**SEATO Treaty, Sept 1954
**Ngo Dinh Diem becomespresident, Republic of Vietnam, 1955
**NV Communists issue Resolution 15 authorizing "armed stuggle" in South Vietnam, 1959
**Coup in South Vietnam; Assassination of President Kennedy
*US Domestic Political Environment
**1964
***Civil Rights Act of 1964
***Urban Mass Transportation Act
***Economic Opportunity Act
***Wilderness Preservation Act
**1965
***Medicare, etc. etc.
**Public polling suggests holding the line, but not going north (LL Korea)
*US Policy Constraints
**Limite US role
**Break the will of the North
**Keep the geography of the conflict contained to SE Asia
*Strategic Setting: Late 1964 and early 1965
**US Policy Objective: Preservation of a free independent and non-communist South Vietnam
***Situation: US Government fear the impending collapse of the South Vietnamese government
**North Vietnam Plan for 1965: plan to attack across the central highlands and move toward the South China Sea
**DRV Objective: Reunification of the two Vietnams under a Communist regime
*The Decision Process for "Americanizing" the War
*Development and Refinement of US Policy Options
*The July 1965 Presidential Decision
**America's "national honor is at stake" per [[Thucydides]]
*The Johnson Administration Advisory System

Final Thoughts

*Cognitive empathy: "The capacity to understand another's perspective or mental state."
*Perspective-taking: "The act of perceiving a situation or understanding a concept from an alternative poin-of-view, such as that of another individual."

!!![[Levels and Domains of National Security]] from [[NSPS 01]]

Question: Who is ''affected'' by a particular threat and who is ''responsible'' for dealing with these different levels?

[[Sarkesian]]: National interests can be categorized in order of priorities as follows:  

First Order: vital interests. This requires protection of the homeland and areas and issues directly affecting this interest. [6] 

Second Order: critical interests. These are areas and issues that do not directly affect the survival of the United States or pose a threat to the home-land but in the long run have a high propensity for becoming First Order priorities. [7] 

Third Order: serious interests. These are issues that do not critically affect First and Second Order interests yet cast some shadow over them. [7] 

Discussion of: Federal/State/Local, Cyber/Space/Air/Land/Sea

{{Jim's Hierarchy of Security Concerns}}






!!![[Levels of Causation of War]]
-By Kenneth Waltz aspresented in [[Understanding Global Conflict and Cooperation]]

*The Individual Level: individuals and their actions matter.[49]
*The State Level: what happens in world politics is affected by domestic politics, society, and the machinery of government. [51]
*The International System Level







!!![[Levels of Interest]]

''Survival'': cannot be compromised; will often bring catastrophic cost if not attained. (Frank: The survival of the state.) (Snark: We're going to nuke it.)

''Vital'': can be compromised only to a certain point, beyond which harm to the state becomes intolerable; severe but not catastrophic costs if not attained. (Frank: The interests are of such consequences, that I'm willing to expend resources to maintain my position in the world.) (Snark: We're going to die for it.)

''Important'': significant but not crucial to a state's well-being; damage causes harm to overseas interests but can often be resolved through negotiation. (Frank: We're willing to support it, but not necessarily major resources or put lives at risk.) (Snark: We're going to fight for it.)

''Peripheral'': no threat to security or economic well-being and do not affect stability of the international system; damage has little impact on state's ability to protect populace. (Frank: Something less than Important.) (Shark: We're going to pay for it.)

From Don [[Neuchterlein]]

Todd: I've never heard of "Survival Interest." Frank: It depends on the political scientist. Some only use three. Vanya: you have heard of existential threat.






!!![[Levels of Strategy]]

-by [[Yarger]], [46] in [[TWS 01]]

*National Security Strategy (Grand Strategy or National Strategy)
*National Military Strategy
*Theater Strategy
*Operational
*Tactical






!!![[Liberalism]] as part of [[IR Theory]]

*International system presents opportunities for cooperation, integration
*States often wish to avoid conflict
*States see justice and domestic betterment, not just security
*Examples: Institutionalism, Democratic Peace
*Globalism matters; states are not the only central actors
*States can (and do) cede [[Sovereignty]]
*Power and force are not the only factors; world can be driven by ideas
*Economic liberals; war is bad for business
*Social (or democratic) liberals; spread democracy and contacts as a wy to reduce tensions
*Institutional liberals: UN, OSCE, EU, WTO, IMF, ICC World Bank, NGOs

{{Forms of Liberalism}}

{{Liberalism Video}}






!!![[Liberalism and World Politics]]
-by [[Doyle]] from [[TWS 07]]

	• Liberalism claim is that liberal states, founded on such individual rights as equality before the law, free speech, and other civil liberties, private property, and elected representation are fundamentally against war. [149] 
	• Liberal states are both peaceful and prone to making war. [150]
	• Schumpter argues that democratic capitalism leads to peace. [150].

!!!Basil H. [[Liddell Hart]]

{{Liddell Hart's Object of War}}






!!![[Liddell Hart's Object of War]]

>The object of war is to attain a better peace, even if only from your own point of view. [353]  You must conduct war with the constant regard for the peace you desire.
-from [[Fundamentals of Strategy and Grand Strategy]] by [[Liddell Hart]]

!!![[Logic of Reason, Logic of Force]], from George [[Kennan]]'s Long Telegram

>Soviet power, unlike that of Hitlerite Germany, is nither schematic or adventuristic. It does not work by fixed plans. It does not take unnecessary risks. ''Impervious to the logic of reason, it is highly sensitive to the logic of force.'' For this reason it can easily withdraw--and usually does when strong resistance is encountered at any point. Thus if the adversary has sufficient force and make clear his readiness to use it, he rarely has to do so. If situations are properly handled there need be no prestige-engaging showdowns.
-George [[Kennan]]

!!![[Makers of Modern Strategy]]
-by Peter [[Paret]] for [[TWS 06]], [[Clausewitz]]

{{Paret's Two Clausewitz Questions}}

{{Paret on Nature of War}}

"""
	· Clausewitz Background [188]
		○ First saw combat at age 12 in the campaign that drove the French out of the Rhineland in 1793. [188]
		○ Had an atypical career.  Saw early on irregular warfare, small unit tactics, raids, ambushes. [188]
		○ 1804 served as the adjutant to Prince August of Prussia. [189]
		○ Rejected Bulow's theories of geometric war... Flawed and unrealistic [190]
		○ After Napoleon's failure in Russia, Scharnhorst employed Clausewitz as a personal assistant. [192]
		○ Appointed to the staff of a new War College. [192]
		○ During war of 1812, served as a Russian Colonel, more like an observer. [195]
		○ Served as the Chief of Staff of the Prussian forces in the Rhineland.  In 1818, offered the directorship of the war college in Berlin. [196]







!!![[Manning Decision Options]] from [[DM 10 Slides]], slide 12

*The DoD has three choices of manpower when deciding how to man the force
**(1) Uniformed Military
**(2) Government Civilian
**(3) Contractor. Each has positives and negatives associated with its choosing. DoD must choose the right force mix based on function, effectiveness and cost.
 
*Within Uniformed Military manpower, there are 3 choices:
**(1) Active
**(2) National Guard
**(3) Reserve. Again there are tradeoffs when it comes to cost, availability, and effectiveness. How does DoD decide the right mix of Active and Reserve Component forces.
 
*Changes in the national and global labor markets affect the conditions in which the DoD recruits and retains its service members. We must understand the changes and anticipate the effects.

*The Manning Lifecycle is a framework to help us consider the strategic issues in maintaining a high quality, well trained, and affordable force.






!!![[Mao]] Tse-tung

{{Mao's General Principles}}

{{Mao's Steps in National Warfare}}

Who is Mao writing for? [[Frank]] The intelligentsia. He wanted to leverage their abilities after advancing through the stages.






!!![[Mao's General Principles]], from [[Mao]] in [[TWS 14]]

*Guerilla war is not a separate form of warfare
*One aspect of the revolutionary struggle
*Guerilla warfare is related to national policy
*Clash between oppressor and oppressed
*The weapon of the inferior to confront the superior
*Guerillas gradually develop into orthodox forces
*Political effects of guerilla action influence political goals
*Dependent against the masses
*Units must have political and military leadership
*Guerilla strategy based on: alertness, mobility, and attack






!!![[Mao's Steps in National Warfare]], from [[Mao]] in [[TWS 14]]

#Arousing and organizing the people
#Achieving internal unification politically
#Establishing bases
#Equipping forces
#Recovering national strength
#Destroying the enemy's strength
#Regaining lost territories






!!![[Marine Corps Force Structure]], specifically a change to incorporate [[Information]] as a Combat Function
-Presented by [[Bob]] for [[DM 07]] (Synopsis provided below and in Word Doc in [[Files|https://drive.google.com/drive/u/0/folders/1mRluR5pbTaWlD6035zfIoChiKs6IoXm8]])

''FOCUSED READING 3A''

<iframe src="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1a2cASYL8-GhQeiSBeILF0ViOnlXVFM6_/preview" width="840" height="680"></iframe>

FOCUS: This article focuses on the initial IW capability sought and specifically the implementation of the MIGS (MEF Information Groups). These changes include feasible structure offsets from within the Operating Forces and the Supporting Establishment to support some of our experimentation and force structure adjustments being executed in the near-term (1 to 2 years).

INTENT: Commandant’s intent to “change where it makes sense, adapt as quickly as possible, and constantly innovate to stay ahead of our adversaries.”

DIME IMPLICATIONS: Armed intervention is only one tool in an increasingly information-centric battlespace. Adversaries know the limits of coalitions and manage conflict just below the threshold of major war. Warfare will further extend into the information battlespace, including the cyber and space domains, exposing our platforms’ vulnerability to information and electronic warfare.

CALLOUT TO NMS: The gap between problems and resources is amplified by increasing competition between world powers that undercuts cooperative action, especially in the littorals and in the near-border areas of competing nations.

TECHNOLOGY TRENDS: will favor the tactical offensive, significantly enhancing an adversary’s ability to find and strike massed or high-value targets with precision, often enabled by sensing systems that cue from and target battlefield signatures.

ORDERS: In his FragO (Fragmentary Order) #1, the Commandant directed the DC CD&I to conduct a comprehensive review of our [Marine Corps] force structure and organization. Grow information warfare capabilities: In particular Information Operations, Electronic Warfare at the MARFOR and MEF levels to enhance the capabilities of forward deployed forces.

COMMAND ELEMENT (CE) CHANGES: a number of related initiatives are inherent to the MCF2025 (Marine Corps Force 2025) design for the CE, including the establishment of the MIG (MEF information group) and enhancing existing or creating new MSEs (major subordinate elements). These initiatives will be achieved incrementally for the most part, and they make accommodations for growth and maturation (e.g., MISO Company (Military Information Support Operations Company) resident at MCIOC (Marine Corps Information Operations Center) until the community is robust enough to support MISO companies at each MEF) of the IW community.

MEF INFORMATION GROUP: The recognition that a tactical command hierarchy at the MEF-level was required to “grow initial IW capabilities in the Marine Corps” came very early in the MCF2025 effort. While the envisioned colonel-level command took on various forms during the deliberations, the evolution of the MHG (MEF headquarters group) to the MIG proved the most practical. While the MHG has traditionally been focused on providing force in support of MAGTF Command Elements (e.g., MEU, SPMAGTF, MEB and MEF) and supporting the “care and feeding” of the MEF headquarters, the transition to the MIG allows for a colonel-level command, associated staff, and complementary MSEs to coordinate, integrate and employ IW capabilities in order to ensure the MAGTF Commander’s ability to facilitate friendly forces maneuver and deny the enemy freedom of action in the information environment while providing communications, intelligence, supporting arms liaison, and law enforcement capabilities ISO [in support of] MAGTF operations.

STRUCTURE CHANGE: Begin IWCC (Information Warfare Coordination Center) transition (to include initial flow of the 32 per MEF structure spaces approved in the MCF2025 design).

COMMAND LEVEL: Establish colonel-level command precepts for MIG.

TIMELINE FOR FOC: 5-7 YEARS

---
''FOCUSED READING 3B: Marine Corps Times (28 FEB 17)''

BLUF: Marine Corps Force 2025, a yearlong force structure review, has identified areas where the Corps needs to add Marines, regardless of whether the service gets bigger.

AREAS OF GROWTH: This may require further growth in areas such as operations in the information environment, indirect fires, anti-armor, counter UAS [unmanned aerial systems] and air defense, anti-ship and sea control capability, increased logistics capacity, and available training and manpower conducive to a 1:3 deployment–to-dwell ratio.

DESIRED NUMBERS: Assistant Commandant Gen. Glenn Walters has told Congress that the Marine Corps needs to expand from 182,000 to at least 194,000 active-duty Marines. The fiscal 2017 National Defense Authorization Act calls for adding 3,000 active-duty Marines by October, but Congress has not yet passed a spending bill that would fund the increase.


<iframe src="https://www.marinecorpstimes.com/news/your-marine-corps/2017/02/28/marine-corps-reveals-new-details-about-future-force-structure/" frameborder="0" width="960" height="675" allowfullscreen="true" mozallowfullscreen="true" webkitallowfullscreen="true"></iframe>

!!![[Mark on Gladwell vs. Schelling]] from [[SL 09]], Leading Organizational Change

>[[Gladwell]] is a great story teller and journalist. But he is not a [[Theorist]]. The science of most of what he is talking about is rooted in research by [[Schelling]]






!!![[Mark on Innovation Costs]]

From the noon time lecture for [[SL 11]]:

>The professor from Penn State said the first question to ask is whether you want to innovate or who in your organization or which sub-organizations you want to be innovative. Because there are opportunity costs. You can't have everyone in the organization be innovative, because nothing would work. So the full question is: "Who will not work so they can be innovative?"

See [[Todd on Enabling Innovation]]

!!!LTG H.R. [[McMaster]]

*Reading for [[NSPS 15]]
*VTC lecture: [[McMaster on NSS]] duing [[TSC 20]]
**[[McMaster's OJT]]
*[[SoD]] by [[Todd]] during [[TSC 02]]
*An example of Informal Guidance
**Todd: Would like to get your notes on this for inclusion here.
*One of [[Rich]]'s [[3 Leader Profiles]] for [[TSC 18]]


Key Phrase

{{POTUS as Realist}}

{{Frank on McMaster}}






!!![[McMaster on NSS]]
-see [[McMaster]], [[NSS]], [[Frank on McMaster]]

---
>This is not an aspirational document

---
What does the world look like?

*We're concerned about rogue regimes.
**They seek to 
*Transnational criminal networks
*Aggressive economic threats such as IP theft, etc.

{{4 C's of the NSS}}

LIst 1, 2... 3: Peace through strength. And size of armed forces matter. We are reversing the pattern from the last several years that the Force is overstructured. 4: We will not impose our values, but we will champion our values.

{{Scott vs McMaster}}

We do two things: we help POTUS make decisions and then assists him in implementing those decisions.

We allow hi to view the problems through the lens of the Cabinet. We have 15 or 16 national security challenges. And we are working on integrating those. And that starts with first principles and values. Part of that is doing what we in the military would call Mission Analysis where we need to frame the problem and get guidance from the decision maker. Nothing like that was in place. So we are bringing the problem framework to the [[PCC]], and we get their input early on so we have the right ideas. ... The framing sessions also allow us to bring in knowledgable members of Congress and their staff early on. Because there is no Presidential decision, there is no executive privledge. So what matters is a process that frames multiple options for the POTUS and we are not tryng to manipulate him into a narrow course of action.


[[McMaster]]: I've had the opportunity to talk to all the previous national security advisers, I asked Dr. Kissinger, 'How do you find time to read and reflect and stay up with what you need to know.
Kissinger: That is impossible. In this job you will create no new knowledge. You will consume the knowledge you have..

*So the first was to remove the artificial constraints of time. And the second is to remove the contradictions in our relationship with Pakistan.
*Our objective is to defeat the Taliban, and by that we mean that the Taliban knows there is no way that they are going to meet their objectives through violence.
*POTUS from a speech finished with something like: "...and only then, maybe at some point in the future we can move toward some kind of peace talks."
*And we have to work out our . .... We have working on the assumptions that Pakistan will not help against the Haqani network. I hope we are pleasantly surprised.

Regarding Syria:

*I'm not worried about the reputation of the United States. The ones who should be concernd about their reputations are Iran and Russia. And shame of all of us in the international community who do not call them out for what they have done and what they have fomented.

*What the Russians are doing now are putting forth a Potemkin peace plan offer in the talks of saying they will help curtail Iranian influence in exchange for guaranteeing their own interests. And no one ought to fall for that. Certainly Turkey should not.

Q: It feels more like a [[realistic|Realism]] and using hard power in the world. How does that impact alliances?

*Alliances are about cooperation with reciprocity. For countries that are 
*The United States tax payer, and this is important to the POTUS, should not have to pay for the defense of countries that are capable of defending themselves.
*We don't use the term soft power anywhere. We say that we are going to use all [[Elements of National Power]]. And we're going to work on solving 

>It is no secret that the President really really doesn't like the new NATO Headquarters.

[[Dex]] question:

*The Russians 
*People ask if I am concerned about out reputation. And I say "Hell, no."
*"We are exiting a period of self-flagellation."
*...how the new left interpretaton of history has become dominate. ...that all the problems prior to 1945 were a product of capitalism and colonialism. We shouldn't paper over our problems. We fought a civil war over the greatest contridiction in our society.
*We should be unabashed about what we have achieved since the WWII period. There have been no great power wars.

Book reommendation: Sebastian Younger's "Tribe"

*Regarding encouraging Pakistan to help more with the violence against Afghanistan: We have tried to hard in the past to disconnect the dots.

Regarding China and a breakdown in the nonproliferation regime.
>You know you can't ask a country to do you a favor that is against their interest. You know, 'do you a solid.' ... Denuclearization is the only accetable policy toward North Korea. .. China. China recognizes they do have tremendous economic coercive power.

>People ask about whether we are trying to encircle China with our allies. What we want is a free and open Indopacific. ... Instead of one belt one road, we think the people of the Indopacific should have many belts and many roads. .... So we will partner with any nation who wants an open Indopacific, including China.

>We already have many strong treaty allies in the region: Thailand, Philippines, Japan, South Korea, and Australia obviously. So we don't need more allies to pressure China.

---
On Russia, the POTUS has put out three goals:

*Confront Russia's destabilizing behavior.
*Deter conflict. (Second pillar of our strategy: peace through strength.)
*Finding areas of cooperation. For example, why would it be in Russia's interest to relieve the economic pressure on North Korea. ... Russia's own ability to grow is because of ther own kleptocracy and oligarchy, but economic sanctions also have an effect.

!!![[Mencken on Complex Problem Solutions]] from [[TSC 16]]

>For Every Complex Problem, There Is an Answer That Is Clear, Simple, and Wrong.
-... This is almost what H.L. Mencken said. The longer actual aphorism was:

>Explanations exist; they have existed for all time; there is always a well-known solution to every human problem — neat, plausible, and wrong.

It's one of the biggest things!'' See: the ship serves breakfast at like 0530. We don't get up that early. We get up at like 9 or 10. And we want eggs!!! But they don't want to cook egss. It's always a big deal.

!!![[National Interests and National Security]] by [[Sarkesian]] for [[NSPS 01]]

US national security: the ability of national institutions to prevent adversaries from using force to harm Americans or their national interests and the confidence of Americans in this capability. [2] 

Foreign policy: the policies of a nation that encompass all official relations with other countries. [2] 

National security is now seen by many to include the projection of US values abroad. [4] 

National security policy is primarily concerned with formulating and implementing national strategy involving the threat or use of force to create a favorable environment for US national interests. [4] 

US national interests are expressions of US values projected into the domestic and international arenas. The purpose of interests includes the creation and perpetuation of an international environment that is most favor able to the peaceful pursuit of US values. [6] 

National interests can be categorized in order of priorities as follows:  

First Order: vital interests. This requires protection of the homeland and areas and issues directly affecting this interest. [6] 

Second Order: critical interests. These are areas and issues that do not directly affect the survival of the United States or pose a threat to the home-land but in the long run have a high propensity for becoming First Order priorities. [7] 

Third Order: serious interests. These are issues that do not critically affect First and Second Order interests yet cast some shadow over them. [7] 


<iframe src="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1u6H5tGZF0TuUWA3Z5YbnI5D-z9hwQhIH/preview" width="840" height="680"></iframe>


<iframe src="https://web.kamihq.com/web/viewer.html?state=%7B%22ids%22:%5B%220Bx33V4OXisHbZlNqcDVtaEgzRnM%22%5D,%22action%22:%22open%22,%22userId%22:%22113069314279649196058%22%7D" width="840" height="680"></iframe>

!!![[NDS]]: [[National Defense Strategy]]

#Rebuild military readiness as we build a more lethal force
#Strengthening alliances as we attract new partners
#Reforming the Department's business practices

First paragraph of conclusion ties to National Interests (see [[NSS Interests]]):

*Protect the Nation
*Increase US Influence
*Preserve access to markets that will increase our standard of living
*Strengthen cohesion among allies and partners






>You can add a new domain to warfare, but iT only changes the character of war not the nature of war.
---
>But new technology, especially AI, may actually change the [[Nature of War]] as defined by [[Clausewitz]] as a contest of wills.

!!![[No harder to get out]] from [[NSPS 15]]
>If the decision to end a war were simply to spring from a rational calculation about gains and losses for the nation as a whole, it should be no harder to get out of war than to get into one.
-pg 16 of [[Every War Must End]] by [[Ikle]]






!!![[None Has Done More Harm]] from [[DM 02]]

>I retired from military service three months after sequestration took effect. Four years later, I returned to the Department and I have been shocked by what I’ve seen with our readiness to fight. For all the heartache caused by the loss of our troops during these wars, no enemy in the field has done more to harm the readiness of our military than sequestration.
-Sec [[Mattis]] in his [[SecDef Statement Jun 17]]






!!![[North Korea's Cybervandalism]]
-[[Scott]]'s presentation in [[TSC 13]]

*The Sony attack was on a private company.
*Question: Does the government have a responsibility to provide protection?
**Scott: What if a truck bomb had driven in a front gate with all the [[North Korean]] hallmarks? What if it caused $100m of damage (but not kill anyone)
*Harkens to [[GEN Dunford]] that we are in a state of [[Adversarial Competition]].
*What are the consequences of the U.S. involvement with STUXNET?
**There were consequenes: there were retributional attacks, etc.
---
How is this related to the [[Nature and Character of War]]?

>It used to be the Department of Blowing Up Things and Killing People. But what if it's not the Department that just does that anymore?
*These cyber attacks meet all ten criteria for a [[Wicked Problem]]
---
{{Dex on Private Company Cyberspace Norming}}

!!![[Not a ringing endorsement]]
-[[MG Ferrari]]

>"You go to war with the Army you have, not the Army you wish you had'"was not a ringing endorsement of how well we were prepared for war as an institution.
-[[MG Ferrari]] in the [[Lecture on Army Budget]]






!!![[Not Crazy]] from [[Gettysburg Staff Ride]]

{{What I need you to do is...}}

[[Dex]]: "Is his strategic end even possible?"

<iframe src="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1eei4q6Mk0-muQbKQMKw8IBv0xZHtzRJn/preview" width="940" height="350"></iframe>

In support of Not Crazy:

>After the battle, critics complained that Meade had focused too much on preparing his defences. This made it harder to launch a counter-attack later. However, our model estimated that if he had put even one less infantry brigade in his defensive line, the Confederate charge probably would have succeeded. This suggests Meade was correct to emphasize his defense.
-See [[this article which modeled the battle|http://theconversation.com/picketts-charge-what-modern-mathematics-teaches-us-about-civil-war-battle-78982]] (also discusses Ewell's decision






!!![[Not Fat]]

>They talk about being overfat or whatever. I'm not overfat. I'm well-marbled.
-[[Scott]] following the leader health assessment






Tag for [[Notes]]






!!![[NSA]]: National Security Advisor. [[NSPS 08]]






!!![[NSC]]: [[National Security Council]]






!!![[NSC vs HSC]]

*Homeland Security Council, [[HSC]], was created post September 11th. [[Frank]]: The ongoing issue became whether it had a speperate staff (or the degree of separateness) from the [[NSC]]. Neither the Bush nor Administration made two separate staffs work. So as of today, they share a staff.






!!![[NSC-68]], National Security Council Report 68, from Case Study I in [[NSPS 06]]

*Presented to Truman in 1950; Paul Nitze was the chair
*Intellectual predecessor was The Long Telegram by Kennan, followed by his Article X in //Foreign Affairs//
*Rejected mere containment and set conditions for aggressive military expansion including the development of the hydrogen bomb
*[[NSC-68 on Wikipedia|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NSC-68]]
*See also [[NSC-68 and Decision-Making Models]]






!!![[NSC-68 and Decision-Making Models]] from Case Study I in [[NSPS 06]]

(See also [[NSC 68]] and [[Decision-Making Models]])

*Homo Bureaucraticus
**Strength of the bureaucratic culture in the NSC
**Role of Service secretaries vs that of Secretary of Defense
**DOS vs DOD view on size of defense budget
*Homo Sociologicus
**Composition of the group that drafted [[NSC-68]]
**Q clearance
**Kennan's role
*Homo Psychologicus
**Truman's role
**Role of recent historical events

*Do not overdo the Background paragraph for the Decision Paper
*Decision paper: no endnotes
*Background paper: yes endnotes

__Background Paper__

Point 1: Objective:
Point 2: What are the national interests? Use the policies on hand.
Point 3:

Greg's example: US support of Europe against

"A policy statement is the statement of the state's postion and aim in carrying out its interests."

So: "The United States wil defend its allies from Russian aggression."

To get that, you have to look at speeches or testimony. Tillerson;  statements in front of the HASC or SASC, or presidential speeches. Not the SecDef probably.

Tie that to interests. Use the 2015 NSS for interests.

Policy objective (Ends): Prevent/Deter Russian aggression against NATO.

What are the Ways? (Think Instruments). Which instruments, what combinations, what resources.

What resources (Means)?

But I don't have any idea if this is any good unless I do [[SAF-R]].

Strategy Options: Give three options, likely [[DIME]] combinations of ways with associated resources.

*washigton examner: nov 1 us sticking with syrian fighrers
**tillerson said "these are not demarcation zones"
**see tillerson testimony to senate armed services committee on senate.gov

!!!Joseph S. [[Nye]]

*Wrote [[Understanding Global Conflict and Cooperation]] with David A. [[Welch]]
*Father of soft power

"A country may achieve its preferred outcomes in world politics because other countries..." see pg 40 of [[Understanding Global Conflict and Cooperation]]

*[[Nye]] coined the phrase soft power, so he had a very specific definition which is not always replicated by others.






!!![[Nye and Welch]]

*[[Understanding Global Conflict and Cooperation]]
*Good definitions for:
**[[Power]]
**[[Power Conversion]]
**[[Nation]]
**[[Nation State]]
**[[Hard Power vs Soft Power]]
*[[Nye and Welch: Four Dominant Paradigms]]
**[[Forms of Liberalism]]
*See also: [[Nye]]






!!![[Nye and Welch: Four Dominant Paradigms]] in the study of world politics
-[[Nye and Welch]], [[TWS 05]]

*[[Realism]]: States are the most important actors in the international system. Anarchy has a powerful effect on state behavior. All politics is power politics. [56]
*[[Liberalism]]: International system presents opportunities for cooperation, integration
**See 1:50 mark of first video in [[Melian Dialogue]]
{{Forms of Liberalism}}
*[[Constructivism]]:
**Agents and structures interact in a cyclical and reciprocal ways
**Identities and interests of agents are not given, but are instead the product of social interaction
**rules, norms, and legitimate expectations will change as a result of social interaction. [63]
*Marxism: predicts the death of capitalism and the rise of communism. [64]

*Ed: would like to get this article from you

-Follow up to presentation in [[DM 08]]

!!![[Observer Effects]]

>In physics, the observer effect is ...

ex: We may change the sample size by changing the policy or the observation methodology. For example, if police get out of their vehicles more there is likely to be an increase in __reported__ crime.






"""
Lecutre on Karl von [[Clausewitz]], 29 August 2017
Given by: 

Rival theorist was Adam von Bulow who attempted to use mathematic principles of geography to 

What is the spirit of modern war?

Hostility: use of violence to compel an opponent to do our will
Not geometry but "warlike" passions are what matters.

Insertion from [[Clausewitz's Trinity]]

{{Clausewitz's Trinity}}

Insertion Complete.

Is our model of ends ways and means more Clausewitz-like or Jomini-like?






!!![[On the other hand]] from [[TSC 06]]

>That is why we bring [[Deb]] in here for the year, so that we all learn we can actually talk to each other. One of the most valuable things of my year at National was the 45 minute ride I had every day with the State Department professional in my group. And she taught me the phrase: "On the other hand..."
-[[Dave]] on the value of bringing not only international students but also State Department pros to the war colleges






!!![[On War]]
-by Dead Karl von [[Clausewitz]], [[TWS 06]]

[[On War Book One]]

[[On War Book Two]]

[[On War Book Eight]]






!!![[On War Book Eight]]
-[[Clausewitz]], [[On War]], [[TWS 06]]

"""

''Chapter 1: Introduction'' (p. 577-578)

	• Theory cannot equip the mind with formulas for solving problems, nor can it mark the narrow path on which the sole solution is supposed to lie by planting a hedge of principles on either side.  But it can give the mind insight into the great mass of  phenomena and of their relationships, then leave it free to rise into the higher realms of action. [578]

''Chapter 2: Absolute War and Real War'' (p. 579-581)

	• No one should start a war without first being clear in his mind what he intends to achieve by that war and how he intends to conduct it. [579]
	• War is dependent on the interplay of possibilities and probabilities, of good and bad luck, conditions in which strictly logical reasoning often plays no part at all and is always apt to be a most unsuitable and awkward intellectual tool. 
	• Theory must concede all of this… it should approximate when he can and when he must.  

''Chapter 3a: Interdependence of the Elements of War'' (p. 582-584)
	• In every victory there is a culminating point beyond which lies the realm of losses and defeats. [582]  

''Chapter 3b: Scale of the Military Objective and of the Effort to be Made'' (p. 585-586)
	• The degree of force that must be used against the enemy depends on the scale of political demands on either side. [585]
	• What we must gauge: [586]
		1. The strength and situation of the opposing state. 
		2. The character and abilities of its government and people 
		3. The political sympathies of other states and the effect the war may have on them. [586]
	
''Chapter 6b: War is an Instrument of Policy'' (p. 605-608)
	•  War is only a branch of political activity; that it is in no sense autonomous. [605]
	• The probable character and general shape of any war should mainly be assessed in the light of political factors and conditions- and that war should often be conceived as an organic whole whose parts cannot be separated, so that each individual acts contributes to the whole and itself originates in the central concept… the point of view that determines its main lines of action, can only be that of policy. [607]







From [[On War]] by [[Clausewitz]]

---
{{Clausewitz Definitions of War}}

Three Paradoxes

* The Maximum Use of Force
* The Aim is to Disarm the Enemy
* The Maximum Exertion of Strength

---
---
{{Ideal vs Total War}}

---
{{The Political Object}}

---
{{Clausewitz's Trinity}}

---
{{Clausewitz Definition of Military Genius}}

---
---
"""
__''Jim's Notes''__ (Some redundancy)

*Chapter 3: On Military Genius (p. 100-112)	
*Chapter 4: On Danger in War (p. 113-114)	
*Chapter 5: Physical Effort in War (p. 115-116)
*Chapter 7: Friction in War (119-121)


''Chapter 1: What is War'' (p. 75-89)

	· The three extremes/paradoxes [77]
		1. Maximum use of force/violence
		2. Both sides will try to overthrow the enemy
		3. Use the total means at your disposal

	• War is thus an act of force to compel our enemy to do our will. [75]
	• Force is the means of war; to impose our will on the enemy is its object. [75]
	• Two motives make men fight one another: hostile feelings and hostile intentions. [76]
	→ I never hated or had hostile feelings about the Iraqis and Afghans that I was fighting. 
	· War is an act of force, and there is no logical limit to the application of force… this is the first extreme. [77]
	→ Disagree
	· The aim of warfare is always to overcome the enemy or to disarm him. [77]
	→ Disagree
	· If you want to overcome your enemy you must match your effort against his power of resistance, which can be expressed as the product of two inseparable factors: the total means at his disposal and the strength of his will. [77]
	→ Disagree: the Chinese at Red Cliffs 
	· War never breaks out wholly unexpected, nor can it be spread instantaneously. [78]
	→ Disagree. 
	· War is never an isolated act. [79]
	· The political object, which was the original motive, must become an essential factor in the equation. [80]
		○ Political object determines both the military objective to be reached and the amount of effort it requires. [81]
		○ Sometimes the political and military objective is the same. [81]
	· Only one consideration can suspend military action…. To wait for a better moment before acting. [82]
		→ Very Chinese 
	· Defense is a stronger form of fighting than attack. [84]
		→ Sun Tzu would say that the only thing better than defense is winning without fighting. 
	· War is no pastime;  it is no mere joy in daring and winning, no place for irresponsible enthusiasts.  It is a serious means to a serious end. [86]
	· War is not merely an act of policy but a true political instrument, a continuance of the political intercourse, carried on with other means. [87]
	· The political objective is the goal, war is the means of reaching it, and means can never be considered in isolation from their purpose. [87]
	· War should never be thought of as something autonomous but always as an instrument of policy; otherwise the entire history of war would contradict us. [88]
	· The Paradoxical Trinity: composed of: [89]
		1. Passion- primordial violence- hatred and enmity…blind natural force
		2. Chance and probability 
			→ Probability is things we can predict, probable consequences
		3. Purpose- Rationale, Reason, instrument of policy
	· These three things don't have to be in balance.

''Chapter 2: Purpose and Means in War'' (p. 91-94, 99)
	
	• Three Broad Objectives [90]
		○ The Armed Forces
		○ The Country
		○ The Enemy's Will  
	• The only means of war is combat. [95]  Combat is the only effective force in war; its aim is to destroy the enemy's forces means to a further end… it follows that the destruction of the enemy's force underlies all military actions;  all plans are ultimately based on it. [97]  When we speak of destroying the enemy's forces we must emphasize that nothing obliges us to limit this idea to physical forces: the moral element must also be considered… the two are inseparable. 
	→ Disagree in part. 






!!![[On War Book Two]]

{{Clausewitz on Theory}}

''Chapter 2: Theory Should be Study, Not Doctrine'' (p. 141)

*Theory need not be a positive doctrine, a sort of manual for action. [141]
*Theory will have fulfilled its main task when it is used to analyze the constituent elements of war, to distinguish precisely what at first sight seems fused, to explain in full the properties of the means employed and to show their probable effects, to define clearly the nature of the ends in view, and to illuminate in all phases of warfare in a thorough inquiry. [141]

''Chapter 3: Art of War or Science of War'' (p. 148-150)

*The object of science is knowledge.  The object of art is creative ability. [148]
*The term "art of war" is more suitable than "science of war" [149]
*War is an act of human intercourse. [149]  War is not arts and sciences but social existence. 
*War is a clash between major interests, which is resolved by bloodshed. [149]
*In war, the will is directed at inanimate objects that react. [149]

Clausewitz is the first [[complexity|Complex]] theorist.

*Deb: would like to get your material on this.

Author:
Thesis:

{{Frank on One Belt One Road}}

!!![[Opinion vs Best Military Advice]]

*Do you understand the questions?
*Take a couple of minutes to sketch out major thoughts
**relevant theory and doctrine
**historical examples
**Stake holders
**Perspecties
**Connections
**Implications
*9 Mar: dedicated student exam prep day
*12-22 Mar: student comps

__What faculty is looking for:__

*Does the student KNOW the topic, broadly defined?
*Does the student think throught the process?
*Is the student able to communicate?

__Preparation__

*Faculty is looking for the ability to ''synthesize'' the material
*5 core courses:SL, TWS, NSPS, TSC, and DM (but don't neglect ISS and Region if appropriate)
*Begin by studying by review course outcomes
**Look at lesson outcomes
*Review topics systematically
*Be able to realte your SRP topic to some aspect of the core curriculum

__General Tips from Dave, Frank, and Eric__

*Don't tell us everything you know.
*If you're going to talk, talk synthesis. Don't talk to lists.
*Don't talk to your notes. Use your notes as a prompt to to us.
*Be as brief as possible. Say what you need to say, but don't drag it out.
*Use The Massengill Approach: Frame the question (reinterpret the question) as a way of setting up how you are going to answer it.






!!![[Organizational Alignment]], presented by [[Trevor and Varcoe]] in Harvard Business Review

''Need: Slide''

*Enterprise Purpose
*Business Strategy
*Organizational Capability
*Resource Architecture
*Management Systems






!!![[Organizational Culture]]  defined by Edgar [[Schein]] in [[SL 10]]

3 definitions on Eric's slides






!!!Robert Endicott [[Osgood]]

Author of [[Book Limited War]]

What is Osgood saying about the [[Levels of Interest]], given he didn't use these terms?

Nuclear war is now synonymous with Survival of the state. So everything is now a discrimination between vital and important.

>War is not a delicate instrument.

Osgood draws heavily on [[Clausewitz]]. But he inverses the idea that war is a political instrument. (pg 13-16)

[[Osgood vs. Clausewitz]] regarding [[Limited War]]

[[Osgood Extends Clausewitz]]








!!![[Osgood Extends Clausewitz]], part of [[TWS 13]]

>For if war is not an end in itself, but only a means to some political objective, then military victory cannot rightly be a self-sufficient end. If war is a continuation of political intercourse, then success in war can be properly measured only in political terms and not purely in terms of crushing the enemy. To be sure, a measure of military success is the necessary condition for achieving the political objectives of war; but the most effective military measures for overcoming the enemy's resistance are not necessarily the most effective measures for securing the continuing ends of national policy in the aftermath of war.
- pg 22 of [[Book Limited War]], see also [[Sun Tzu's Acme of Skill]]






[[Clausewitz]]'s approach to [[Limited War]] involves having limited ends in accordance with the desired political endstate. [[Total War]] involved Napoleonic armies on the march.

[[Osgood]]'s approach to [[Limited War]] also involves limitation of the means, geographical extent, and the number/type of belligerents.








!!![[Osgood]]'s [[Limited War]]

> ...one in which the belligerents restrict the purposes for which they fight to concrete, well-defined objectives that do not demand the utmost military effort of which the belligerents are capable and that can be accommodated in a negotiated settlement.

*Other notable factors: only two or a few major belligerents involved, confined to a local geographical area, selected targets of principally military value. __In terms of resource demands, only a fraction of the belligerents' capacity is involved and for the most part, the existing social, political and economic patterns continue without disruption.






*Overdetermination: looking into the past, there are more explanations than we actually need to explain how we got here.
*Underdetermination: looking into the future, we don't have anything close to what we need to find out what will happen in the future.






!!![[Overview of the Defense Acquisition System]]
-by [[DAU]] for [[DM 08]]

<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/M1oHhsyDXws" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen style="width:100%;height:420px;"/>






!!![[PA&E]] - Program Analysis and Evaluation
-see [[MG Ferrari]]












*Brookings Russia study from early 2018






!!!Peter [[Paret]]
-Author of [[Makers of Modern Strategy]]






!!![[Paret on Nature of War]] 
-by [[Paret]] in [[Makers of Modern Strategy]], [[TWS 06]]

*Nature: 
**War is fundamentally a human thing… humans are ruled by several forces in friction. 
**War is dirty and causes human suffering. 
**War is more destructive than any other human activity. 
**Hatred and enmity are powerful motivators in war. 
**Lots of stuff happens that is out of our control.
*See [[Nature vs Character of War]]








!!![[Paret's Two Clausewitz Questions]]
-[[Makers of Modern Strategy]], [[TWS 06]]

Two fundamental questions that Clausewitz addresses in [[On War]]:

#How can we analyze war?  What is War? [186]
#Can war be understood and by implication intellectually mastered and controlled? How do we fight most effectively [186]






!!![[Patton on Planning]] ([[TSC 24]])

>A good plan, violently executed now, is better than a perfect plan next week.

!!![[Polarity vs Institutions]]

*Polarity:::realism/neo-realism:::power
*Insitutions refers to Liberal Order: Rules-based, Norms, Organizations, and Law


*[[Frank]]: So when we read "the order is unraveling" they are refering to the rules and norms based on the US-based order to one where China plays an increasing role
*Also this may refer to the Social Contract as defined by Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau. Hobbes comes from a Calvinist Protestant viewpoint






!!![[Policy Defined]] from [[NSPS 01]]

>Policy is what comes out of the process that defines the objective and what must be done.
- [[Frank]]: This can be approached from the top down- what is the vision and what is the method to achieve it. But it can also be looked at the other way, e.g. how is the military postured and is it in alignment with the new policy.

*Resistant
*Complicance
*Identification

*Programming

!!![[Priming]]

>Providing a stimulus that influences their near-term future thoughts and actions, even though they many not seem to be connected.












!!![[Principles]], one of [[Three Ethical Lenses]] from [[SL 05]]

*Principles (deontology): What is necessary and required by binding and agreed upon moral rules, laws, values and regulations? The answers determine the right action apart from any consequences that may result from action or inaction.
*Main Point: Ensure we are following binding rules which determine duty and right action, e.g., rules of engagement, moral laws, regulations, etc. Take the right action regardless of outcome. Is it an action required or prohibited by a law or principle? That is the question that guides the decision.
*Example: The acts of committing sexual assault and lying on a report are wrong because they break binding moral rules, irrespective of what the consequences might be. Rule based systems include the Geneva Convention, International Humanitarian Law, the UCMJ, the Golden Rule, and the Just War tradition.
*Caution: This position does not concern itself with consequences of an action. Knowing what the right action is doesn’t necessarily mean you have the internal character, fortitude or external resources needed to accomplish the action. Are there universal norms that apply to everyone and all situations? The pure deontologist would say that one should not lie is such a norm. The tension in deontology is apparent then when one examines the example of a Dutch citizen during WWII who violates that principle when he/she lies to a Nazi official when asked if he/she is harboring Jews in their home.  






!!![[Protected Communication]], part of [[Whistleblower Reprisal Conditions]] from [[Lecture from The IG]]

>A "protected communication" (PC) is any communication made to a Member of Congress, and IG (includes DoD IG), a member of law enforcement, or a member of the chain of command per DoDD 7050.06.

*What should Best military Advice consider?
*What are military options?
*See [[Dempsey's Syria Options]]

!!![[Queen Wilhelmina]], 1880-1962

*[[Wikipedia Article|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilhelmina_of_the_Netherlands]]
*Assumed the throne at the age of 18.
*She was at the height of her power during WWII. Big question: How was she able to rule the empire when the country was also a constitutional democracy.
*[[Frank]]: The Netherlands joined NATO in 1949. What was her opinion on NATO? A: Whe was transitioning power. But she was in support of the armed forces and understood the financial contraints. So she was in support.

>As you know, we have a policy of neutrality. But the Germans attacked us.

{{Churchill on Queen Wilhelmina}}

!!Ed: I need your slides for this!






!!![[International Order]] from [[NSPS 03]]

Compare and contrast with [[World Orders]]

*How does the world work? [[Hastedt]]
**[[IR Theory]] constructs
*How do we solve the policy "problems" we confront?
**Institutions
***"Institutions can be defined as societal norms. They are stable, recurring patterns of behavior that help define the choices that a society, and individuals within it make; and how those choices are executed. Institutions can be aodern or traditional, formal or informal."
***"Related but different are organizations... structures entities that operationalize institutions. They have clearly defined structures, functions, rules, regulations, procedures, and chains fo command."

Source: Harris M. Mule, "Institutions and their Impact in Addressing Rural Poverty in Africa"

International System: Evolutionary Trends... (Also [[Hastedt]]...)

''What is the takeaway from MG Rapp's article on [[Civil-Military Relations]]?''

"""
[[Dave]]: You cannot be one dimensional at this level. You have to be politically astute. This is not the same thing as being partisan. The second you lay out an option which is only one dimensional or if you can't explain it. you have just lived up to all the stereotypes.
[[Mark]]: The question is this: is like like [[Cohen]] says and it's an unequal dialog? Or is it [[Huntington]] where the civilian leadership is obligated to fix the objectives so that the military can do their job?
[[Todd]]: It is an unequal dialog. But before there is a first meeting, there needs to be a meeting zero where the President (maybe) says "Let's talk about how we are doing this. How does this work before we start talking about the main issue?"

-From [[National Interests and National Security]] in [[DM 01]], pg 3

!!![[Realism]] defined as part of [[IR Theory]]

*States will act in their interests; states are the central actors
*States see interest as power
*States seek/security and independence
*Force and war are primary tools of the international system
*Competition; world is a zero-sum game
*Hobbesian view of human nature
*States naturally seek allies and balance of power
*Interest, not ideology dominates
*States should make cost/benefit analyses; wars of choce usually not worth the cost
*See [[Realism vs Idealism]]
*See [[Hans Morgenthau]] and [[Kissinger]]

TWO PREMISES

#States in the international community act like people, and they're primarily acting in their self interest
#States are the primary power players on the world stage

{{Realism Video}}






!!![[Realism Video]], See [[Realism]]

<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/UnKEFSVAiNQ" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen style="width:100%;height:420px;"/>

!!![[Requirement for Exemplary Conduct]]
- 10 USC 3583, [[Lecture from The IG]]

#to show in themselves as a ''good example'' of virtue, honor, patriotism, and ''subordination''
#to be ''vigilant in inspecting'' the conduct of all persons who are placed under their command;
#to ''guard against and suppress all dissolute and immoral practices'', and to correct, according to the laws and regulations of the Army, all persons who are guilty of thej; and
#to take all necessary and proper measure, under the laws, regulations, and customs of the Army, to ''promote and safeguard the morale, the physical well-being, and the general welfare'' of the officers and enlisted persons under their command or charge.
