!!![[Scenario Based Forecasting]]

#Identify the Focal Issue or Question
#Identify the major Driving Forces andor Factors
#Identify outcomes for each Driver/Factor (polar opposites)
#Identify critical Drivers/Factors
#Create Scenario Matrix Using Top Two
#Deelop the details of each scenario
#Determine critical components
#Develop a potential strategy
#Identify signposts
#Assess the broader implications






!!!Edgar [[Schein]]

*[[SL 10]], [[Organizational Culture]]
*Author of  for 
*[[Embedding Mechanisms]] and [[Reinforcing Mechanisms]]






!!Thomas Schelling (1921-2016)

*Nobel Prize in Economics, 2005. Naturally a believer in rational actor theory
*Wrote [[The Diplomacy of Violence]], Ch 1 reading for [[TWS 08]]
*Schelling is all about the ability to [[Coerce]]
*Making a case that we're moving into a new [[era|Schelling's Eras]]
*All in on [[Deter]] and [[Compel]]
*Indirect policy entrepreneur
---
Schelling's Key Concepts

*[[Coercion]]
*The difference between [[Coercion]] and [[Brute Force]]
*The two elements of coercion: deterrence and compellence
* ...something

[[Schelling on Nuclear Strategy]]


[[Jervis vs. Schelling]]

What is he saying about the [[Character of War]]?

He is ''not'' a Clausewitzian. Nuclear weapons are not just for deterance. Nukes are "at the abyss of action" (Frank). 'I have them, and therefore I don't want to use them.' They are just there to allow me to bargain. Nuclear weapons allow for symmetry. 

Is there a new trinity?
[[Jim]]: Violence, Latent Violence, Bargaining

See also, [[Resistance Equation]]

See: [[Brute Force]], [[Coercion]]

{{Schelling on War}}

{{Schelling's Price of Admission}}

*Schelling saw the Cuban Missile Crisis as the new type of [[Limited War]] conducted between the great powers under the shadow of nuclear war. Example:
>To characterize the maneuvers and actions of limited war as a bargaining process is to emphasize that, in addition to the divergence of interest over the variables in dispute, there is a powerful common interest in reaching an outcome that is not enormously destructive of alues to both sides.

*This puts him somewhat closer to the school of [[Liberalism]] in that (without being naive) he sees that each side could/should be constrained toward a positive outcome.

*He says that even a tacit bargained agreement has a degree of authority. Example: Even in the middle of the Berlin crisis, the US did not use nuclear weapons to trump the situation. The 

[[Schelling's Purpose of Arms Control]]

>We believe that arms control is a promising, but still only dimly perceived, enlargement on the scope of military strategy. It rests essentially on the recognition that our military relation with potential enemies is not one of pure conflict and opposition, but involves strong elements of mutual interest in the avoidance of a war that neither side wants, in minimizing the costs and risks of the arms competition, and in curtailing the scope and violence of war in the event it occurs
-Thomas Schelling and Morton Halpering in [[Strategy and Arms Control]], 1961

Final thoughts:

*There is a substantial difference between [[Deterrence]] of nuclear weapons vs conventional weapons.
**Alexander George called nukes a Strategic Deterrence (vs. Operational Deterrence)
*The paradox of Munich: The logic behind the coercive use of force is that you can ratchet up the pain and instill fear. But if it's the universal truth that concessions like the Munich agreement only whet the appetite, aren't all coercive strategies doomed to fail?






!!![[Schelling on Balance]]

>There is a difference between a balance of terror in which either side can obliterate each other, and one in which both sides can do it no matter who strikes first. It is not the 'balance'--the sheer equality or symmetry in the situation--that constitutes mutual deterrence; it is the stability of the balance. The balance is stable only when nither, in striking first, can destroy the other's ability to strike back."






*Need to avert a surprise attack
*Transformed function of military force
**Intimidation, 
*






!![[Schelling on War]]

>War is no longer just a contest of strength.
- Thomas [[Schelling]], [[The Diplomacy of Violence]], pg --






!!!Thomas [[Schelling's Eras]], see also [[Schelling]]

*1648-1803: Age of the Monarchs
*1805-1945: Napoleon turns the system into the mobilization of the people
*1945==>    : Nuclear age. "Defeat" or a threat of defeat is just the entry into the coercion stage






!![[Schelling's Price of Admission]]

>Military victory was but the //price of admission//. The payoff depended on the successful threat of violence.
-Thomas [[Schelling]], [[The Diplomacy of Violence]], pg 13






!!!Kathryn [[Schulz]]
-Author of [[Being Wrong]]






!!!Moshe [[Schwartz]]

*[[DM 08]], [[How DOD Acquires Weapon Systems]]

!!![[Scott]]: What are American values?

Is it really just Life, Liberty, and the Pursuit of Happiness? We say that all the time. But there are a lot of other labels/words we use: humanitarian concerns, democracy, free trade, equality under the law, etc.

Random search for 10 American values (not exactly related to this topic, but interesting)

!!![[SecArmy Lecture]]
-Dr. Mark [[Esper|Sec Esper]]

{{Alternative to Military Service}}

{{3 SecArmy Priorities}}

>To get to modernization, I don't think we get there with the current acquisition system. And I'm talking about [[Big A Acquisition]].

"""
---
*Q: What about obesity and the health/recruitment challenges for the force?
*A: There is a)health issue, and b) an isolation issue where the American people have fewer connections with the military. What we're fighting is culture. "...beyond my ability to fix all of that." This is not a new problem. Pres Eisenhower took on the same challenges. I'm not sure Congress can fix this; there are too many interest groups trying to dictate this and that. It takes leadership, but not just political leaders.
---
*Q: What about the relationship between the Army and Congress regarding funding.
*A: The problem lies with the body politic. I told the Army staff that they shouldn't think in terms of Congress passing a budget according to the fiscal year. It hasn't happened in the last 8-9 years. And looking back about 30 years, it only happened half the time.
*A: We leave about $4-5B on the table every year, unexecuted. Out of a budget of about $180B. "Imagine what we could do with $4B.
*A: FY18 and 19 are going to be great. Budget is going up. But it's going to level off.
---
*Q: What about Futures Command? Risks? Trades?
*A: We're trying to mitigate the consequences as we realign organizations. But we don't know what we don't know, so we're actively monitoring for that.
*A: It's important to get the [[Culture]] right in that organization from the beginning.
*A: If we can't reform the system, we're going to continue to have erratic success and we won't get to the next generation of platforms.
---
*Q: How do you plan to embed the changes you talk about in Army [[Culture]] with respect to talent-based personnel management, etc.
*A: If the chief and I were in the private sector, we'd have about 8-12 years to create change. Industry can be nimble, but they can also afford to be very careful about making changes. So we have to move quickly. We have worked through the Army process to try to understand the second order effects (eg Futures Command). We've gotten the senior leaders 
*A: We have to be comfortable with change and comfortable with ambiguity. Whatever we think today, we will think differently about it a year from now. So we need to adapt as we learn. But Congress is on board, A lot of important stakeholders 
"""

{{SecArmy on Mandatory Training}}

{{SecArmy on TRiPS}}

{{Supplement not Substitute}}

>I am going to push the Army to go unmanned. ... It will force us to change how we deploy and employ forces on the battlefield. If you have two unmanned tanks in a platoon, then you don't have to have as much armor because you don't have to protect the crew. You can make them lighter and mobile. M

>If there is mandatory training that is being imposed on you by a higher headquarters that is not required by law, and most are not, and it is inhibiting your ability to train for readiness: Don't Do It.

!!![[Second Nuclear Age]], from [[TWS 13]]

>The second nuclear age is as much about the human factor as about missile flight profiles, the size of the inventories, warhead yields, and other numerical indices of nuclear capability. By zeroing in on strategy--again, defined for our purposes as the political and military use or nonuse of disruptive nuclear technology--this study breaks with the familiar mode of net assessment, with its emphasis on quantifiable fators like hardward and manpower.
-from Conclusion, pg 225 of [[Thinking about Strategy in the Second Nuclear Age]]

*A status of [[State]] power where the state's only option is to help yourself. No one is going to automatically take up issues that are important to you.
*From a [[Realist|Realism]] standpoint, the state is on its own.

!!![[SL 01]] - ''Introduction to Strategic Leadership'' for [[Strategic Leadership Course]]

Class Notes:

*[[Strategic Leadership Defined]]
*[[Culture vs. Climate]]
*[[Open Systems Model]]
*[[Socio-Technical Systems Model]]
*[[Scott on Organizational Effectiveness]]
*[[Organizational Alignment]]
*[[Reasons for Misalignment]]
*[[Mintzberg's Roles]]

Readings:

*[[Ziegenfuss]] --- [[Organization and Management Problem Solving|https://drive.google.com/open?id=0Bx33V4OXisHbY0FwVTRzUC1Id0k]]
*[[Waters]] on [[A Framework Approach for Understanding StrategicThinking and Developing Strategic Leaders|https://drive.google.com/open?id=0Bx33V4OXisHbNXluZk8zVDIzTDg]]
*W. Richard [[Scott]] --- [[Chapter 1|https://drive.google.com/open?id=0Bx33V4OXisHbTEpZYTItdWhRSGc]] of [[Organizations: Rational, Natural, and Open Systems]]
*Craig [[Bullis]], Andrew Hill, and Lou Yuengert --- article on [[Roles of a Strategic Leader: Mintzberg's Framework|https://drive.google.com/open?id=0Bx33V4OXisHbSnFjOC0zdlhqYmc]]
*Jonathon [[Trevor and Varcoe]], Barry --- article [[How Aligned is Your Organization|https://drive.google.com/open?id=0Bx33V4OXisHbOHl2elk3UkFXXzhOckVMUTFmOVQyZFhUS3dJ]]
*Horst W. J. [[Rittel and Webber]], Melvin M. --- Ch 2.3 in Development in Design Methodology, [[Planning Problems are Wicked Problems|https://drive.google.com/open?id=0Bx33V4OXisHbQmZhdE1KVDNodkU]], see presentation on [[Wicked Problem]]



21 September 2017 (0830-1130)
Dr. George Woods
Dr. Andrew Hill

INTRODUCTION TO STRATEGIC LEADERSHIP


Mode:  Seminar    SL-1-S

1.  Introduction.

<$button set="$:/state/SL01Reveal1" setTo="show">Read</$button>
<$button set="$:/state/SL01Reveal1" setTo="hide">Hide</$button>

<$reveal type="match" state="$:/state/SL01Reveal1" text="show">

    a.  This lesson introduces you to the course that will set the foundation for your study of strategic leadership throughout the academic year.  It begins with first understanding a bit about who you are and how cognitive requirements expand at the strategic level.  Our intent is not that you discard the leadership lessons you have learned in your career; instead think of those lessons as necessary but not sufficient for effective leadership at the strategic level.  The course introduces skills and competencies unique to or more often required at the strategic level. In the transition to strategic leadership, you will experience the complex interplay of the leader with internal and external organizational conditions and their distinctive opportunities and challenges.  Understanding the strategic context will help you comprehend the role of strategic leaders and their advisors in coordinating national strategy, plans, and operations. Crucially, strategic leaders work with forces from other countries, as well as with other federal agencies and nongovernmental organizations.  To provide a range of concepts from different sectors of society and multiple perspectives on leadership, the readings assigned throughout the course come from military, academic, and business resources.

    b.  The course is structured around two main themes.  The first centers on the individual skills needed to effectively discharge strategic leader responsibilities.  It also focuses on strategic thinking—knowing something about yourself and the cognitive skills required to render appropriate advice and apply effective leadership skills at the strategic level.  Although there are competing definitions for Strategic Thinking, we define it as:  “the ability to make a creative and holistic synthesis of key factors affecting an organization and its environment in order to obtain sustainable competitive advantage and long-term success.”

    c.  The second theme focuses on understanding the role leaders play in effectively leading large organizations and institutions, and some of the aspects unique to this effort.  Effective strategic leaders must understand the complexity of the strategic environment, balance the competing requirements of internal and external constituencies, and provide guidance (decisions) to move the organization forward.  Further, they must understand the interrelatedness of various subsystems that together compete and complement each other in achieving alignment with the current, and more importantly, the future environment.

    d.  To frame your understanding of these roles, this introductory lesson offers one way to organize your thinking about organizations.  We use an open systems model (input, transformation, output, and feedback) in general, and the socio-technical theory of organizations specifically, to appreciate the collection of subsystems that make up the whole.  Further, it may add to your appreciation of some of the complexities of aligning large organizations to maintain a sustainable competitive advantage vis-à-vis the organization’s external environment.  Finally, the organizations you will lead are professions—organizations that possess unique characteristics and that warrant special obligations of its professional corps.  Aspects of professions and obligations of professionals will be explored later in the course.

</$reveal>

2.  Learning Outcomes.

<$button set="$:/state/SL01Reveal2" setTo="show">Read</$button>
<$button set="$:/state/SL01Reveal2" setTo="hide">Hide</$button>

<$reveal type="match" state="$:/state/SL01Reveal2" text="show">

    a.  Comprehend the requirements for successful completion of the Strategic Leadership course.

    b.  Appreciate the complexities of issues dealt with at senior levels and the application of Strategic Thinking in advising leaders and practicing leadership at the strategic level.

    c.  Comprehend the socio-technical model of organizations as a framework to inform the practice of leadership at the strategic level and appreciate the complexities of achieving alignment with the external environment

    d.  Comprehend the roles and actions of leaders and advisors at the strategic level. 

</$reveal>

3.  Student Requirements.

__Tasks__

<$button set="$:/state/SL01Reveal3a" setTo="show">Read</$button>
<$button set="$:/state/SL01Reveal3a" setTo="hide">Hide</$button>

<$reveal type="match" state="$:/state/SL01Reveal3a" text="show">

Review the Strategic Leadership Primer from Introduction to Strategic
Studies Course Lesson 1.

</$reveal>

__Readings__

<$button set="$:/state/SL01Reveal3b" setTo="show">Read</$button>
<$button set="$:/state/SL01Reveal3b" setTo="hide">Hide</$button>

<$reveal type="match" state="$:/state/SL01Reveal3b" text="show">

    b.  Required Readings.

    (1)  DCLM, Academic Year 2018 Strategic Leadership Course Directive (Carlisle Barracks, PA: U.S. Army War College, July 2017). [Student Issue / Blackboard]  Read Sections I, II, and III.

    (2)  Douglas Waters, A Framework and Approach for Understanding Strategic Thinking and Developing Strategic Thinkers, Faculty Paper (Carlisle Barracks, PA: U.S. Army War College, May 2017). [Blackboard]

    (3)  W. Richard Scott, “The Subject is Organizations,” in Organizations: Rational, Natural, and Open Systems, 5th ed. (Upper Saddle River, NJ: Prentice-Hall, 2003), 
3-30. [Blackboard]
 
    (4)  James T. Ziegenfuss, Jr., “Organizational Systems Thinking and Problem Solving,” in Organization and Management Problems Solving: A Systems and Consulting Approach (Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Publications, 2002), 9-25. [Blackboard]

    (5)  Jonathan Trevor and Barry Varcoe, “How Aligned Is Your Organization?” Harvard Business Review, February 7, 2017. [Instructor Handout]

    (6)  Craig Bullis, Andrew Hill, and Lou Yuengert, The Roles of a Strategic Leader: Mintzberg’s Framework, Faculty Paper (Carlisle Barracks, PA: U.S. Army War College, July 2012). [Blackboard]

    (7)  Robert M. Gates, “The Agent of Change: ‘Mirror, Mirror on the Wall,’” in
A Passion for Leadership: Lessons on Change and Reform from Fifty Years of Public Service (New York: Alfred A. Knopf, 2016), 157-185. [Student Issue]

    c.  Focused Reading.

    Horst W. J. Rittel and Melvin M. Webber, “Planning Problems are Wicked Problems,” in Developments in Design Methodology, ed. Nigel Cross (Chichester, NY: 
John Wiley & Sons, 1984). 135-144. [Blackboard]

</$reveal>

4.  Points to Consider.

<$button set="$:/state/SL02Reveal4" setTo="show">Read</$button>
<$button set="$:/state/SL02Reveal4" setTo="hide">Hide</$button>

<$reveal type="match" state="$:/state/SL02Reveal4" text="show">

    a.  What initial thoughts do you have that differentiates leading at the strategic level from the leadership in other contexts?  What is NOT different?

    b.  To what extent does the Strategic Thinking Framework aid you in thinking about what lies ahead for you as an advisor and/or leader at the strategic level?  To what level do you think it assists you in identifying strengths or potential gaps that informs your study in this course and throughout the academic year?

    c.  What is organizational alignment, and how does the socio-technical systems model of organizations help you appreciate the complexities of the organizations you will lead and the challenges it presents in achieving a holistic and synchronized effort in aligning organizations with their environments?

    d.  How do former Secretary Gates’ reflections in leading large organizations provide evidence of the challenges in aligning large organizations?  What evidence do you see of strategic thinking in his reflections?  What new qualities does he add to your appreciation for the qualities required for effective leadership at the strategic level?

</$reveal>






!!![[SL 02]] - ''Self Awareness & [[Creative Thinking]]'' for [[Strategic Leadership Course]]


"""22 September 2017 (0830-1130)
Dr. Craig Bullis
Prof Charles Allen
Mode:  Seminar SL-2-S"""

Class Notes:

*[[Big Five Personality Domains]]
*[[Five Discovery Skills]]
*[[Dex on Creativity]]
*[[Changing Minds in the Army]]


1.  Introduction.

<$button set="$:/state/SL02Reveal1" setTo="show">Read</$button>
<$button set="$:/state/SL02Reveal1" setTo="hide">Hide</$button>

<$reveal type="match" state="$:/state/SL02Reveal1" text="show">

a.  Effective strategic leaders must be adept at understanding the complexity of the strategic environment, balancing the competing requirements of internal and external constituencies, and providing guidance (decisions) to move the organization forward.  Success in these challenging roles requires:  an understanding of one’s own perspectives and how they were developed; the willingness to consider the validity of another’s viewpoint; and the openness to consider new and different approaches to problem solving.  Consequently, this lesson introduces concepts of self-awareness and creative thinking to inform and enhance your success as a senior leader.

b.  Successes that senior leaders have experienced in previous assignments often create limitations for their creativity in new and unfamiliar circumstances.  The issue is not that earlier lessons learned were wrong, but they were incomplete in preparing individuals for the expanded challenges of strategic leadership.  Therefore, organizational research has identified self-understanding and a clear awareness of one's impact on others as two important qualities that successful leaders possess.  Many define self-awareness as knowing how you tend to think and act in different circumstances.  We will expand the definition, however, by including the personal knowledge of how others anticipate and interpret your behavior.  This lesson focuses on enhancing self-awareness to facilitate your developmental efforts during your attendance at the USAWC.

c.  One critical aspect of self-awareness is how you deal with change.  The strategic environment in which senior leaders operate is constantly changing.  Therefore, solutions to tough problems require creativity and innovation from members of an organization if it is to adapt and thrive in such a competitive landscape.  Thus, creativity is required of individuals, groups, and leaders within organizations.  The contemporary operational environment requires that our senior leadership be skilled in developing and applying creative strategies to new problems.  This lesson will present and ask you to apply various tools and techniques that you can use to develop your skills to generate new perspectives and novel solutions to problems.  You will also learn the various roles involved to take an idea from creativity to implementation.

d.  The USAWC’s Strategic Leadership Feedback Program (SLFP) provides you with a unique opportunity to further enhance your self-awareness, resulting in a fuller understanding of your leadership style and thinking skills as they relate to managing strategic-level problems and opportunities.  We contend that SLFP will accelerate the development of your strategic leadership abilities by increasing your understanding of the cognitive, behavioral, and dispositional characteristics required to lead effectively at the strategic level.  While the SLFP was introduced during zero-week activities, your FI can provide you with more information about this valuable program.

</$reveal>



2.  Learning Outcomes.

<$button set="$:/state/SL02Reveal2" setTo="show">Read</$button>
<$button set="$:/state/SL02Reveal2" setTo="hide">Hide</$button>

<$reveal type="match" state="$:/state/SL02Reveal2" text="show">

a.  Comprehend the importance of self-awareness for effective strategic leadership.

b.  Describe the concepts of creativity and what helps or hinders creativity at the individual level.

c.  Explain the roles and challenges with taking an idea from creative thought to implementation.


</$reveal>


3.  Student Requirements.

__Tasks__

<$button set="$:/state/SL02Reveal3a" setTo="show">Read</$button>
<$button set="$:/state/SL02Reveal3a" setTo="hide">Hide</$button>

<$reveal type="match" state="$:/state/SL02Reveal3a" text="show">

(1)  Complete the Self-Awareness Scale-II (SAS-II). (See the instructions provided by your DCLM FI). While survey completion is voluntary, we strongly encourage your participation. One of the distinguishing characteristics of effective strategic leaders is the ability to be open to new experiences and different perspectives. Your results can communicate how easy (or hard) such an expanded perspective might be for you, thereby helping to focus your personal developmental activities.  If you chose not to complete the survey during in- processing but now wish to participate, see your FI as soon as possible.

(2)  Complete the on-line Team Roles/Adaptability Portfolio.  Similar to the SAS-II measure discussed above, survey completion is voluntary. We encourage your participation, however, as the results enhance your awareness of preferred roles within a creative group.  In the short term, this knowledge can help the seminar to better understand internal group processes during the academic year.

(3)  Read your personal Adaptability Portfolio and SAS-II results and bring the reports to class.

</$reveal>

__Readings__

<$button set="$:/state/SL02Reveal3b" setTo="show">Read</$button>
<$button set="$:/state/SL02Reveal3b" setTo="hide">Hide</$button>

<$reveal type="match" state="$:/state/SL02Reveal3b" text="show">

{{SL 02 Readings}}

</$reveal>

4.  Points to Consider.

<$button set="$:/state/SL02Reveal4" setTo="show">Read</$button>
<$button set="$:/state/SL02Reveal4" setTo="hide">Hide</$button>

<$reveal type="match" state="$:/state/SL02Reveal4" text="show">

a.  In what meaningful way is self-awareness a prerequisite for effective strategic leadership?

b.  To what extent do you agree with assertions that people are “hard wired” in how they respond to leadership challenges?  What are the implications for your development as well as the development of your subordinates?

c.  What does the personality diversity reflected by the heterogeneity within your seminar mean for individual learning and seminar development?
d.  Under what conditions should you use the creative-thinking techniques?  When would it be inappropriate?

e.  What do my Openness and Adaptability Portfolio results tell me about my preferences with respect to creativity?  How do they limit my perceptions?

f.  To what extent have I been required to employ creative thinking strategies in past assignments?  Why was I successful in those contexts?  What might those lessons mean for my future?

</$reveal>









!!![[SL 02 Readings]] on Self Awareness and Creative Thinking

b.  Required Readings.

(1)  Daniel Goleman, “The Neuroanatomy of Leadership,” and “Self-Directed Learning,” in Primal Leadership: Learning to Lead with Emotional Intelligence (Boston: Harvard Business School Press, 2004), 33-52 and 109-112. [Student Issue]

(2)  Stephen J. [[Gerras]], The Big 5 Personality Traits: A Primer for Senior Leaders, Faculty Paper (Carlisle Barracks, PA: U.S. Army War College, December 2014). [[Open from Google Drive|https://drive.google.com/open?id=0Bx33V4OXisHbc2VNY0xHV2lLRkE]]

(3)  Charles D. Allen, Creative Thinking for Senior Leaders, Faculty Paper (Carlisle Barracks, PA: U.S. Army War College, June 2017). [[Open from Google Drive|https://drive.google.com/open?id=0Bx33V4OXisHbcHBGOUJoMlA1b1U]]

(4)  Diane F. Halpern and Heidi R. Riggio, “Review of Skills for Creative Thinking,” in Thinking Critically About Critical Thinking, 4th ed. (Mahwah, NJ: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates, 2003), 214. [[Open from Google Drive|https://drive.google.com/open?id=0Bx33V4OXisHbZXJCSllNT3A1Wk0]]

(5)  Jeffery H. Dyer, Hal B. Gregersen, and Clayton M. Christensen, “The Innovators’ DNA,” Harvard Business Review, December 2009, 61-67. [Instructor Handout]

(6)  Stephen J. Gerras and Leonard Wong, Changing Minds in the Army: Why It is so Difficult and What to Do About It (Carlisle Barracks, PA: U.S. Army War College Press, October 28, 2013). [[Open from Google Drive|https://drive.google.com/open?id=0Bx33V4OXisHbVFJUM05ZM1llNHM]] Read the Executive Summary and Scan the Monograph.

!!![[SL 03]] - ''[[Critical Thinking]]''  for [[Strategic Leadership Course]]

"""25 September 2017 (0830-1130)
Dr. Stephen J. Gerras
Mode:  Seminar SL-3-S"""

Class Notes:

*[[Critical Thinking]]
*[[Jim]]'s [[Logical Fallacy Graphic|https://drive.google.com/open?id=0Bx33V4OXisHbNlQ1ZzVhekRIeC1QUmE1aWtWU3dISjVIS1Zr]]
*[[Epistemology]]
*[[Error]]
*[[Brett on the F-18]]

1.  Introduction.

<$button set="$:/state/SL02Reveal1" setTo="show">Read</$button>
<$button set="$:/state/SL02Reveal1" setTo="hide">Hide</$button>

<$reveal type="match" state="$:/state/SL02Reveal1" text="show">

As leaders move to the strategic level issues increase in complexity and ambiguity and the consequences of decisions are more far-reaching and serious.  Therefore, the need exists to analyze issues in depth and in a more systematic manner.  In recognition of this requirement, both in the military environment and the civilian sector, many strategic leaders have asserted the need for a more intense focus on the development of critical thinking skills.  Unfortunately, this goal is much easier to espouse than to actually put into practice.  Critical thinking is not a spectator sport.  The skills of critical thinking must be practiced with a wide variety of issues in many different contexts in order to be learned and retained.  The purpose of this lesson is to provide students with a basic foundation and understanding of critical thinking concepts and skills that you should apply not only to your Army War College experience, but also in your future responsibilities in the strategic leadership environment.


</$reveal>



2.  Learning Outcomes.

<$button set="$:/state/SL02Reveal2" setTo="show">Read</$button>
<$button set="$:/state/SL02Reveal2" setTo="hide">Hide</$button>

<$reveal type="match" state="$:/state/SL02Reveal2" text="show">

a.  Comprehend the concepts and skills of critical-thinking relevant to strategic leaders.

b.  Comprehend the importance of reflection and self-awareness to identify the impact of biases, assumptions, and inferences on the decisions we make as strategic leaders.

c.  Apply the critical thinking model and skills to complex, ambiguous, real-world situations.

</$reveal>


3.  Student Requirements.

__Tasks__

<$button set="$:/state/SL02Reveal3a" setTo="show">Read</$button>
<$button set="$:/state/SL02Reveal3a" setTo="hide">Hide</$button>

<$reveal type="match" state="$:/state/SL02Reveal3a" text="show">

Read the assigned readings be prepared to evaluate the article and comments on immigration within the framework of the critical thinking model proposed.

</$reveal>

__Readings__

<$button set="$:/state/SL02Reveal3b" setTo="show">Read</$button>
<$button set="$:/state/SL02Reveal3b" setTo="hide">Hide</$button>

<$reveal type="match" state="$:/state/SL02Reveal3b" text="show">

{{SL 03 Readings}}

</$reveal>

4.  Points to Consider.

<$button set="$:/state/SL02Reveal4" setTo="show">Read</$button>
<$button set="$:/state/SL02Reveal4" setTo="hide">Hide</$button>

<$reveal type="match" state="$:/state/SL02Reveal4" text="show">

a.  To what extent do I attempt to appreciate the point of view of others?

b.  What mechanisms can I put in place to help make me more aware of the impact of my biases and assumptions as I develop and evaluate arguments?

c.  What mechanisms can an organization emplace to account for expected judgment biases of the senior leaders?

d.  To what extent does the military encourage critical thinking?  Why is it most crucial for senior leaders?

e.  What’s the best way to develop critical thinking skills?

f.  What are the biggest obstacles to critical thinking?

g.  To what extent do persistent strategic conflicts arise from unshakable feelings of rightness?

h.  Do you agree that we are more likely to entertain the possibility that we are wrong about insignificant matters than weighty ones?

</$reveal>









!!![[SL 03 Readings]] on [[Critical Thinking]]

b.  Required Readings.

(1)  Stephen J. Gerras, “Thinking Critically about Critical Thinking: A Fundamental Guide for Strategic Leaders,” in Planner’s Handbook for Operations Design, Version 1.0 (Suffolk, VA: Joint Staff, J-7, October 7, 2011), C-1 - C-27. [[Open from Google Drive|https://drive.google.com/open?id=0Bx33V4OXisHbVGxRc25pRUVILW8]]

(2)  Kathryn Schulz, “Wrongology,” in Being Wrong: Adventures in the Margin of Error (New York: Harper Collins, 2010), 3-24. [Student Issue]

!!![[SL 04]] - ''Systems Thinking'' for [[Strategic Leadership Course]]

"""26 September 2017 (0830-1130)
Dr. Andrew Hill
Mode: Lecture/Seminar SL-4-L/S"""

Class Notes:

*Lecture by Dr. Andrew [[Hill]] on [[Complex Adaptive Systems]]

1.  Introduction.

<$button set="$:/state/SL04Reveal1" setTo="show">Read</$button>
<$button set="$:/state/SL04Reveal1" setTo="hide">Hide</$button>

<$reveal type="match" state="$:/state/SL04Reveal1" text="show">

>As simple ideas are observed to exist in several combinations united together, so the mind has a power to consider several of them united together as one idea; and that not only as they are united in external objects, but as itself has joined them together.  Ideas thus made up of several simple ones put together, I call complex; such as are beauty, gratitude, a man, an army, the universe…
—John Locke; An Essay Concerning Human Understanding

a.  When we speak of “complex” systems, we mean systems that display causal complexity and adaptability.  Many fields refer to such systems as complex, adaptive systems (CAS, for short).  CAS are rife with interactions and interdependencies, and tend to have complex subsystems, as well as inputs and feedback due to their place in higher-level systems.  Generally, systems that include human agents are CAS, including systems that concern military strategy and national security strategy issues. Causal complexity is the reason why strategic leadership is difficult. It is the bane of all strategy, the reason why the term “unintended consequences” is so common, and why “Murphy’s Law” exists.  Causal complexity arises from the fundamental character of complex systems—from their structural complexity (size, multitude of interactions, openness, etc.).

b.  Systems are everywhere.  Systems thinking is the process of understanding how the elements of a system influence one another within a whole, and how the system as a whole behaves and evolves.  In nature, systems examples include ecosystems in which various elements such as air, water, movement, plants, and animals work together to survive or perish.  In organizations, systems consist of people, structures, and processes that work together to make an organization "healthy" or "unhealthy."  Systems may be vertical (like a system of production that moves from raw material to finished product) or horizontal (like the various departments and activities of a city government).  They may be wholly contained within a single entity, or they may embrace large groups of organizations.  Systems can be defined as the “inters” of the environment: the components of the environment that are interactive, interrelated, and/or interdependent.  Systems also exist within broader hierarchies.  The components of a system may be sub-systems, as the circulatory system is a sub-system of the body.  Even very large, complex systems may be a sub-system of a larger system; think of the U.S. mortgage market and its place in the global financial markets.
 
c.  CAS are challenging to manage, and have some or all of the following characteristics:

• the number of elements is large enough that conventional descriptions are not only impractical, but cease to assist in understanding the system;
• elements also interact and the interactions are dynamic;
• interactions are rich, i.e., any element in the system is affected by and affects several other systems;
• interactions are non-linear--small causes can have large results, and vice versa;
• any interaction can feed back onto itself directly or after a number of intervening stages, and such feedback can vary in quality (that is, it can be reinforcing/amplifying or balancing/dampening);
• as open systems, it may be difficult or impossible to define system boundaries;
• lacking a single, permanent equilibrium, CAS can remain stable for an indeterminate period under more than one equilibrium condition, or they can operate under far from equilibrium conditions;
• they require a constant flow of energy to maintain the organization of the system;
• all complex systems have a history, they evolve and their past is co-responsible for their present behavior; and
• elements in the system tend to be ignorant of the behavior of the system as a whole, responding only to what is available to it locally.

d.  The purpose of this lesson is to examine systems complexity as an element of the strategic environment.  What are complex, adaptive systems?  How do strategic leaders make sense of such systems, and how does an understanding of CAS help leaders develop and implement successful strategies?  A holistic understanding of the system in which a problem arises aids understanding of the problem itself.  An understanding of the problem in turn helps the leader develop appropriate strategies to solve it. Understanding the characteristics of CAS also helps leaders discern the ways in which the security environment may evolve, and to understand that strategy and the organization that executes it must evolve, as well.

e.  In this lesson, you will read two articles that describe key characteristics of complex systems. You will then read one of three “backgrounders” (gangs in Central America, Islamic State, or malaria eradication, assigned by your instructor) on a complex strategic issue, applying concepts from complex adaptive systems to examine the nature of the problem and potential successful interventions. Your task is to examine this issue in light of your understanding of complex systems.

</$reveal>

2.  Learning Outcomes.

<$button set="$:/state/SL04Reveal2" setTo="show">Read</$button>
<$button set="$:/state/SL04Reveal2" setTo="hide">Hide</$button>

<$reveal type="match" state="$:/state/SL04Reveal2" text="show">

a.  Comprehend the characteristics of complex, adaptive systems (CAS).

b.  Comprehend the four types of causal explanations described in the reading and their utility for strategic leaders.

c.  Analyze the application of the instruments of power to change a complex adaptive system in the current security environment and develop an approach to achieving favorable change in that system.
</$reveal>

3.  Student Requirements.

__Tasks__

<$button set="$:/state/SL04Reveal3a" setTo="show">Read</$button>
<$button set="$:/state/SL04Reveal3a" setTo="hide">Hide</$button>

<$reveal type="match" state="$:/state/SL04Reveal3a" text="show">

Read the assigned readings and be prepared to discuss in seminar.
</$reveal>

__Readings__

<$button set="$:/state/SL04Reveal3b" setTo="show">Read</$button>
<$button set="$:/state/SL04Reveal3b" setTo="hide">Hide</$button>

<$reveal type="match" state="$:/state/SL04Reveal3b" text="show">

{{SL 04 Readings}}

</$reveal>

4.  Points to Consider.

<$button set="$:/state/SL04Reveal4" setTo="show">Read</$button>
<$button set="$:/state/SL04Reveal4" setTo="hide">Hide</$button>

<$reveal type="match" state="$:/state/SL04Reveal4" text="show">

a.  Thinking about Systems and Causes (Hill and the Hill and Gerras readings).

(1)  What are the characteristics of complex adaptive systems (CAS)?  What are the strategic implications of CAS?

(2)  Why is systems thinking difficult?  What is it about CAS that make comprehension of the system challenging?

(3)  What is a cause?  How can various causal perspectives help leaders intervene more effectively in complex systems?
 
(4)  What organizational tools help leaders understand and apply the various causal perspectives?

b.  Strategic Challenges of Complex Adaptive Systems (Backgrounder readings).

(1)  Consider the attributes of complex adaptive systems.  In what way is the issue described in the backgrounder a CAS?

(2)  What is the current condition of this issue?  Is it in an equilibrium?  That is, how acceptable is the current condition, and what is the likely consequence of strategic inaction?  How have governmental and international policies affected the development of this issue?  Put differently, how did we reach the current condition?

(3)  What are the possible future conditions for this issue?  How do those conditions compare to the status quo?  What are some acceptable future conditions?  What are the most desirable conditions?  What strategic interventions are necessary to provoke change? What are the risks associated with those interventions?

</$reveal>







!!![[SL 04 Readings]] for [[SL 04]] on [[Systems Thinking]]

b.  Required Readings.

(1)  Andrew Hill, The Devil You Know: Strategic Thinking in Complex Adaptive Systems, Faculty Paper (Carlisle Barracks, PA: U.S. Army War College, August 2017). [Blackboard]

(2)  Andrew Hill and Stephen Gerras, Stuff Happens: The Art and Science of Causation in Policy and Strategy, Working Paper (Carlisle Barracks, PA: U.S. Army War College, August 2016). [Blackboard]

(3)  Council on Foreign Relations Backgrounders (assigned to one of three groups in seminar):

(a)  Danielle Renwick, “Central America’s Violent Northern Triangle,” January 19, 2016, linked from the Council on Foreign Relations Backgrounders Home Page, http://www.cfr.org/transnational-crime/central-americas-violent-northern-triangle/p37286 (accessed June 6, 2017). [Online]

(b)  Zachary Laub, “The Islamic State,” August 10, 2016, linked from the Council on Foreign Relations Backgrounders Home Page, http://www.cfr.org/iraq/islamic-state/p14811 (accessed June 6, 2017). [Online]

(c)  Danielle Renwick, “Can Malaria Be Eradicated?” October 5, 2016, linked from the Council on Foreign Relations Backgrounders Home Page, http://www.cfr.org/public-health-threats-and-pandemics/can-malaria-eradicated/p38243 (accessed June 6, 2017). [Online]






!!![[SL 05]] - ''Ethical Reasoning'' for [[Strategic Leadership Course]]

"""27 September 2017 (0830-1130)
Chaplain (COL) Peter R. Sniffin
Mode:  Seminar SL-5-S"""

''Class Notes''

*[[Definitions for Ethical Reasoning]]
*[[Dowd on Values vs Interests]]
*[[Three Ethical Lenses]]

''Comments and Quotes''

*[[Todd on Employing the Lenses]]

1.  Introduction.

<$button set="$:/state/SL05.1" setTo="show">Read</$button>
<$button set="$:/state/SL05.1" setTo="hide">Hide</$button>

<$reveal type="match" state="$:/state/SL05.1" text="show">

a.  The profession of arms is a fundamentally moral endeavor based on trust and certified through character, competence, and commitment.  This lesson is designed to assist senior leaders and their advisors in comprehending moral challenges and applying ethical reasoning at the strategic level to empower virtuous service, wise decisionmaking, and stewardship of the profession of arms according to its values and traditions.  As part of the enduring theme of professional ethics, lessons throughout the overall curriculum examine and evaluate:  1) the importance of the character of the strategic leader; 2) discretionary moral judgment within the profession; 3) moral aspects of strategic choices; 4) the just war tradition in the exercise of Landpower; 5) moral complexities in leading organizations at the strategic level; 6) and other areas.

b.  This lesson introduces ethical terms, employs an applied ethical framework for moral reasoning, and evaluates moral tensions that exist in decisionmaking at the strategic level.  The lesson focuses primarily on the individual strategic leader, on his or her moral understanding, and on the use of an applied ethical framework.

c.  Part one of this lesson introduces important ethical terms and concepts for leaders serving at the strategic level.  How does morality as a social institution relate to ethics as an intellectual discipline?  How should the strategic leader think about moral challenges that are black-and-white versus those that are morally gray?  How does the ethical decisionmaking relate to noble decisiveness by strategic leaders?  This lesson provides one example of an ethical reasoning framework that uses three ethical lenses to offer varying moral perspectives to help you think through moral/ethical dilemmas.

d.  Part two of this lesson applies one example of an ethical reasoning framework to strategic decisionmaking within a case study that involve significant moral and ethical challenges.  To help you resolve moral challenges in the profession of arms, this lesson affords you the opportunity to use the three ethical framework to offer varying moral perspectives to increase your self-awareness (acknowledging your own preference in resolving ethical dilemmas) and to enhance your critical analysis of others’ points of view.

</$reveal>

2.  Learning Outcomes.

<$button set="$:/state/SL05Reveal2" setTo="show">Read</$button>
<$button set="$:/state/SL05Reveal2" setTo="hide">Hide</$button>

<$reveal type="match" state="$:/state/SL05Reveal2" text="show">

a.  Comprehend important ethical terms and lenses, and related moral judgments that form an applied ethical framework for moral reasoning and worthy decisions within the profession of arms.

b.  Analyze moral challenges for resolution using an ethical reasoning process that includes: consequences (teleological), principles (deontological and utilitarian), and the actor’s moral agency (character).

c.  Analyze individual preferences and tendencies in ethical decision making for particular ethical lens in light of the preferences and tendencies in ethical thought of fellow leaders.
</$reveal>

3.  Student Requirements.

__Tasks__

<$button set="$:/state/SL05Reveal3a" setTo="show">Read</$button>
<$button set="$:/state/SL05Reveal3a" setTo="hide">Hide</$button>

<$reveal type="match" state="$:/state/SL05Reveal3a" text="show">

Read all assigned materials to prepare for seminar dialogue.  Read the assigned case study, using the applied ethical framework, to take a position and recommend an action.

</$reveal>

__Readings__

<$button set="$:/state/SL05Reveal3b" setTo="show">Read</$button>
<$button set="$:/state/SL05Reveal3b" setTo="hide">Hide</$button>

<$reveal type="match" state="$:/state/SL05Reveal3b" text="show">

{{SL 05 Readings}}

</$reveal>

4.  Points to Consider.

<$button set="$:/state/SL05Reveal4" setTo="show">Read</$button>
<$button set="$:/state/SL05Reveal4" setTo="hide">Hide</$button>

<$reveal type="match" state="$:/state/SL05Reveal4" text="show">

a.  In what ways are strategic leader responsibilities and competencies moral in nature?

b.  What are the strengths and limitations of each of the three ethical lenses discussed, and how do these lenses together assist the strategic leader in resolving moral challenges?

c.  How can strategic leaders on a staff with preferences for particular ethical lenses work collaboratively with peers to analyze ethical dilemmas and advise a strategic leader as to available ethical courses of action?

d.  How can a senior leader judiciously guide the ethical decisionmaking process in a joint, interagency, intergovernmental, and multinational environment?

e.  How would you evaluate your own preferences for making ethical decisions?  How would you critically evaluate others’ decisions?

</$reveal>








!!![[SL 05 Readings]]

(1)  John L. Kallerson, A Basic Primer on Ethics and Ethical Reasoning for War College Students, Faculty Paper (Carlisle Barracks, PA: U.S. Army War College, May 2017). [[[Get from Google Drive|https://drive.google.com/open?id=0Bx33V4OXisHbZGt2YlZzbVRfLUE]]]

(2)  John L. Kallerson, Joint Staff Case Study—Student Sheet, Faculty Paper (Carlisle Barracks, PA: U.S. Army War College, May 2017). [[[Get from Google Drive|https://drive.google.com/open?id=0Bx33V4OXisHbS2ZnUEJkQzMzTDQ]]]






!!![[SL 06]] - ''The Profession'' for [[Strategic Leadership Course]]

"""PASTE HEADER"""

Class Notes:

*[[Lecture on Professional Ethics]] by Leonard [[Wong]]
*[[What Professions Do]]

1.  Introduction.

<$button set="$:/state/SL06-1" setTo="show">Read</$button>
<$button set="$:/state/SL06-1" setTo="hide">Hide</$button>

<$reveal type="match" state="$:/state/SL06-1" text="show">

a.  The study of professions is a relatively recent phenomenon, especially for the profession of arms (post-World War II).  Therefore, understanding the historical beginnings of military profession theory and the emergence of recent theoretical interpretations and its implications for today’s professionals is the focus of this lesson.

b.  In the current Army Doctrine Reference Publication No. 1 (ADRP 1), professions are trusted, disciplined, and relatively autonomous vocations whose members:

• Provide a unique and vital service to society, without which it could not flourish.
• Provide this service by developing and applying expert knowledge.
• Earn the trust of society through ethical, effective, and efficient practice.
• Establish and uphold the discipline and standards of their art and science including the responsibility for professional development and certification.
• Are granted significant autonomy and discretion in the practice of their profession on behalf of society.

c.  Organizations exist for a purpose and must coordinate activities and sustain them over time.  To do so, they behave like bureaucracies.  At the same time, certain organizations, like military services, possess unique characteristics that set them apart from other organizations and are therefore deemed professions.

d.  As professions and functioning bureaucracies, military departments may fight for greater control to be more efficient (especially in fiscally constrained environments) and operate or behave like bureaucracies, therefore putting at risk their professional status.  They may subsequently lose the trust of the client they serve and cease to exist.  Therefore, it is incumbent upon the strategic level professionals to assess the state of the profession and take appropriate action to keep the tension in balance.

e.  Professional practices are entirely human endeavors.  Professions certify professionals and, based on trust between the profession and the society it serves, professionals are granted autonomy (a high degree of discretion) to practice their expert knowledge.  Professionals routinely make discretionary judgments and take appropriate action.  Like surgeons, lawyers, clergyman, and other professionals, who are trained, educated, and certified, military leaders in combat zones or civilian experts running the institution are entrusted to make discretionary decisions and apply their expert knowledge in the public’s best interest.

f.  The Clark reading summarizes two of the most renowned theorists on military professions, Samuel Huntington and Morris Janowitz.  Published in two eras of the Cold War, the theories form the basis that the majority of officers and civilian leaders were taught and may still inform understandings of what a profession is and how professionals should act.  Both argue for a separation between military and civilian leader functions yet arrive at different conclusions.  Many view them as timeless classics.  However, theoretical study of professions has advanced and new concepts have emerged.

g.  The Snider reading describes the theoretical underpinnings of his research using Andrew Abbott’s theoretical construct of professions found in his book “System of Professions.”  Unlike his predecessors, Abbott’s open systems model differs.  He argues that professions must compete to survive.  They must adapt or lose their professional status.  They operate in a dynamic environment and must compete for jurisdiction among other professions and organizations to apply their expert knowledge.  They are held accountable for the expert practice of their knowledge and given the autonomy to apply their expert knowledge based on the trust earned or lost by the public (client) they serve. Burke’s reading explores these concepts in more depth.

</$reveal>

2.  Learning Outcomes.

<$button set="$:/state/SL06Reveal2" setTo="show">Read</$button>
<$button set="$:/state/SL06Reveal2" setTo="hide">Hide</$button>

<$reveal type="match" state="$:/state/SL06Reveal2" text="show">

a.  Comprehend the evolution of U.S. military profession theory and the obligations of senior professionals the theories present.

b.  Analyze current military profession theory, including basic concepts of professions and the tensions inherent in the dual nature of the profession as both a hierarchal bureaucracy and a vocational profession.

</$reveal>

3.  Student Requirements.

__Tasks__

<$button set="$:/state/SL06Reveal3a" setTo="show">Read</$button>
<$button set="$:/state/SL06Reveal3a" setTo="hide">Hide</$button>

<$reveal type="match" state="$:/state/SL06Reveal3a" text="show">

Read the assigned materials carefully and be prepared to discuss them in seminar in light of the Learning Outcomes above.

</$reveal>

__Readings__

<$button set="$:/state/SL06Reveal3b" setTo="show">Read</$button>
<$button set="$:/state/SL06Reveal3b" setTo="hide">Hide</$button>

<$reveal type="match" state="$:/state/SL06Reveal3b" text="show">

{{SL 06 Readings}}

</$reveal>

4.  Points to Consider.

<$button set="$:/state/SL06Reveal4" setTo="show">Read</$button>
<$button set="$:/state/SL06Reveal4" setTo="hide">Hide</$button>

<$reveal type="match" state="$:/state/SL06Reveal4" text="show">

a.  Why is reestablishing America’s military as a profession so important now?  Is this applicable only to America’s military or are our Allies and Interagency colleagues facing similar challenges?

b.  What unique characteristics differentiate “professions” from other forms of work or employment?  Does the military profession meet all the requirements to be considered alongside major professions such as physician, lawyer, or clergyman?  How does it differ?  How is it unique?  Do you consider all ranks to be included in the “profession” or just officers or senior officers?  What about senior service civilians?  Are they professionals too?

c.  What are the critical tasks that society needs the military to accomplish, that cannot be accomplished by other professions or organizations?  What unique kinds of expertise does the military profession absolutely need to cultivate?

d.  How does the military profession promote trust or lose it?

e.  How does the strategic leader of the profession lead the profession?  What are the leader’s critical tasks?  What indicators trigger strategic decision-making and action?

</$reveal>








!!![[SL 06]] Readings

b.  Required Readings.

(1)  Review Required Readings (3) and (4) from SL-1-S.

(2)  Murf Clark, Officership and Civil-Military Relations: A Brief Summary of Huntington and Janowitz, Faculty Paper (Carlisle Barracks, PA: U.S. Army War College, September 2010). [[[Get from Google Drive|https://drive.google.com/open?id=0Bx33V4OXisHbVGNmekR1V1ZyVGc]]]

(3)  Don M. Snider, “The U.S. Army as a Profession,” in The Future of the Army Profession, 2nd ed., ed. Lloyd J. Matthews (New York: McGraw-Hill, 2005), 1-28. [Student Issue]

(4)  James Burk, “Expertise, Jurisdiction, and Legitimacy of the Military Profession,” in The Future of the Army Profession, 2nd ed., ed. Lloyd J. Matthews (New York: McGraw-Hill, 2005), 39-44, 48-56. [Student Issue]

c.  Focused Reading.  For Army students (military and civilian).

 U.S. Department of the Army, The Army Profession, ADRP 1 (Washington, DC: Department of the Army, June 14, 2015), http://www.apd.army.mil/epubs/DR_pubs/DR_a/pdf/web/adrp1.pdf (accessed June 14, 2017). [Blackboard]

!!![[State]], [[TWS 05]]: Two characteristics: Territoriality and [[Sovereignty]]

*See [[Understanding Global Conflict and Cooperation]] pg 34
*See [[State Explained by Nye and Welch]]






!!![[State Explained by Nye and Welch]], [[TWS 05]]

* 	• [[State]]: a particular type of political unit that has two crucial characteristics: territoriality and sovereignty.  [34]
** 		○ Territoriality: the state governs a specific, identifiable portion of the earth's surface. 
**		○ Sovereignty: the absolute right to govern. [34]
** 		○ To be a state, one must be recognized as a state by other states. [36]
** 		○ How to decide to recognize a new sovereign state:
*** 			§ Is there a government with de facto control over a certain territory?
*** 			§ Do other states claim the territory?  If so, how strong is their claim?
*** 			§ Are the people seeking to establish control historically oppressed?
*** 			§ Do the people consider the government to be legitimate?
*** 			§ Will recognizing the state as sovereign affect their own claims and interests? [36]
**		○ States have the capacity to control the flow of people, goods, and money across borders. [38]
**		○ States are the only actors that wield significant armies. 
**		○ States have the power to tax and spend significant amounts. [38]
**		○ States promulgate and enforce laws. 







!!!Alan [[Stolberg]]

*[[Crafting National Interests]]






!!![[Strangelove's Definition of Deterrence]] in Discussion of The Doomsday Machine

>Deterrence is the art of producing in the mind of the enemy the fear to attack.
-Stragelove at 1:50

{{Dr. Strangelove and the Doomsday Machine}}






!!!Robert B. [[Strassler]]

*Editor of [[The Landmark Thucydides]].












!!![[Strategic Leadership Defined]]

>Traditional: The process used by a leader to affect the achievement of a desirable and clearly understood vision by influencing the organizational culture, allocating resources, directing through policy and directive, and building consensus within a volatile, uncertain, complex, and ambiguous global environment which is marked by opportunities and threats.
<br>

>Casey, 2008: Strategic leaders guide the achievement of their organization vision within a larger enterprise by directing ''policy and strateg'', building ''consensus'', acquiring and allocating ''resources'', influencing organizational ''culture'', and ''shaping'' complex and ambiguous external environments. They lead by example to build effective organizations, ''grow'' the next generation of leaders, ''energize'' subordinates, ''seek opportunities'' to advance organizational goals, and ''balance'' personal and professional demands.






!!![[Strategist of the Day]] from [[TSC]]

*[[TSC 02]]: [[Todd]] on "[[McMaster]]'s "American First Doesn't Mean America Alone"; Informal Guidance












!!![[Strategy (Book)]] by [[Liddell Hart]]

*We read: [[Fundamentals of Strategy and Grand Strategy]]






!!![[Strategy and Grand Strategy]] from [[NSPS 01]]

Strategy and Grand Strategy: What Students and Practitioners Need to Know (p. 1-10 and 43-64) 

By Tami Davis [[Biddle]] 

 

Tactics: describe how small units (platoons, companies, ships, squadrons) are to be employed in a battle space. [5] 

Operations (and “operational art”): concern the movement of larger military units, including army divisions, naval task forces, and wings of aircraft. [5] 

Theater strategy: concerns the direction of the largest military units in a battle space, including armies and army groups, naval fleets, and numbered air forces. [5] 

Grand strategy: identifies and articulates a given political actor’s security objectives at a particular point in time, and describes how they will be achieved using a combination of  instruments of power -- including military, diplomatic, and economic instruments.  

Eliot [[Cohen]] explained, “Strategy is the art of choice that binds means with objectives.”  He added that it involves “priorities, sequencing, and a theory of victory.” 

Steven Metz has observed that grand strategy “attempts to impose coherence and predictability on an inherently disorderly environment composed of thinking, reacting, competing, and conflicting entities. [44] 

Politicians often conflate strategy with policy objectives (focusing on what the desired outcome should be, simply assuming that force will move the adversary toward it), while soldiers often conflate strategy with operations (focusing on how to destroy targets or defeat enemies tactically, assuming that positive military effects mean positive policy effects). [49] 

The military will seek to carry a campaign through to success in order to justify the human losses sustained in the midst of it. [52] 

There is a bias in the way that the military reads metrics, and attempts to assess progress in an operation/campaign/war that is underway.  And this is exacerbated by a “can do” culture that will be inclined to dismiss or downplay evidence indicating that a military mission is failing to meet its objectives.  [53] 

The trust that is so essential to sound civil-military decision-making must be built, in part, on education, and on the belief that a general will not use his/her power and influence to meddle in the realm of democratic politics. [55] 

At all levels, officers must be willing and able to see and understand the political, cultural, historical and social contexts that shape the foreign environment they are operating in. [56] 

“Opportunism” posits that an actor may change, shift, or evolve in order to take advantage of possibilities as they present themselves. [58] 

Strategy always will demand clear and honest interaction and cooperation between two very distinct tribes—civilian and military—who have different priorities, cultures, and modes of operating.  At the end of the day, neither structural tensions nor inherent problems of communication and implementation should prohibit strategic decision-makers from striving towards an ideal, and working to make their choices as intelligent and informed as possible. [59] 

<iframe src="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1t4FQHIhQzBIn4O3wtiCH57R5SxhPr_7z/preview" width="640" height="480"></iframe>






!!![[Strategy Defined]] from [[NSPS 01]]

>A prudent idea or set of ideas for employing the instruments of national power in a synchronized and integrated fashion to achieve theater, national, and/or multinational objectives.”				
		 - US DOD Dictionary of Military and Associated Terms

>A calculated relationship among ends, ways and means, with an assessment of risk.
   - USAWC [[Strategy Formulation Framework]]






!!![[Strategy Drives Budget]]
-by [[Todd]] for [[DM 05]]

*Big deal: There are ALL kinds of examples here of language that we would not have recognized or appreciated earlier in the year. There are examples here of strategic messaging acknowledging stakeholders and other key actors (incl, per Frank, "policy elite") that will shape the understanding and acceptance of whether the strategy and resourcing are in alignment.

<iframe src="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1ZvoVVWtZrA8TC35BBsx6dKEdeEcvv2Rc/preview" width="840" height="680"></iframe>

*Objectives:
**Couter Air and meritime threats at a safe disttance. ...land components?
**Prevent terrorist attacks on the Homeland, through support of law enofrcement'
*Mission 2: **Provide [[Defense Suppot of Civil Authorities]]
**Maintain defense preparedness for domestic CBRN
**Develop plans and procedures to ensure [[DSCA]] during complex catastrophes
*Core Competencies

!!![[Stress Testing Grand Stragey]] by Hal [[Brands]] for JIMasssssssaaaaaaaaaaaaaa

*[[Grand Strategy]] is something we don't spend enough time thinking about
*The nature is an assumption

7 Assumptions that are coming tested

# The US will continue to enjoy uncontested military primacy both globally and within every region
## What is the status today? It will probably be dominant for several decades, but it's com

#The growning interweaving of the US emiososaas will lead to a lessend 

# A war between the Great Powers is not possible.

#History is always moving in the right direction

#Globalization is irresistable and will lead to good things all around

#Democracy will continue to spread inexorabl

#Techonolgy is nothing but great things for all players

Q: What role does climate change play in US Grand Strategy

A: Less and less today.






By [[Mazarr]] for [[TWS 16]]

!!![[Sun Tzu's Acme of Skill]] from [[TWS 09]]

> For to win one hundred victories in one hundred battles is not the acme of skill. To subdue the enemy without fighting is the acme of skill.

-[[Sun Tzu]], [[The Art of War]] pg 77, Opening page of Ch III






!!![[Sun Tzu's Estimate]] from [[TWS 09]]

>Therefore I say: 'Know they enemy and know yourself; in a hundred battles you will never be in peril. When you are ignorant of the enemy but know yourself, your chances of winning or losing are equal. If ignorant both of your enemy and of yourself, you are certain in every battle to be in peril.
-[[Sun Tzu]] in [[The Art of War]]  pg 84 at the end of Ch III






!!![[Supplement not Substitute]]

>In my mind, online training is a supplement not a substitute for NCOs and unit leaders to create and maintain the standards for their Soldiers.
-from [[SecArmy Lecture]]






!!!Cease resistance to an enemy or opponent or submit to an authority.






!!![[Survey of Geopolitics]]
-Saul B. [[Cohen]] for [[TWS 05]]

"""
	• Stage 1: The Race for Imperial Hegemony:
		○ [[Geopolitics]] analyzes the geographical factors underlying international relations and guiding political interactions.[11]
		○ It is a combined study of international relations from a spacial or geographic perspective. [11]
		○ [[Mackinder]]: Geographical realities lay in the advantages of centrality of place and efficient movement of ideas, goods, and people. [12]  The world is a closed system, and nothing can be altered without changing the balance of all. [16]
		○ [[Mahan]]: Blue water strategy: control the international trade choke points. [19]
	• Stage 2: German Geopolitik [20]
	• Stage 3: Geopolitics in the US
	• Stage 4: The Cold War-State-Centered vs Universalistic Approaches
		○ Americans embraced geopolitics as a basis for a national policy aimed at confronting the Soviet Union and international communism. [24]
	• Stage 5; Post-Cold War Era: Competition or Accommodation? [27]

<iframe src="https://drive.google.com/file/d/0Bx33V4OXisHbMmN4ZjlaYUdTaFk/preview" width="840" height="680"></iframe>







[[GEN Thomas]]:

"""
Defeat ISIS
Avoid war with Russia
Avoid...
Prevent Iraq/Turkiish conflict

"But that is not a strategy."

"The effect has been this Shia crescent. ... You are gonna see AQ 3.0 or ISIS 2.0."

"So what's the way ahead." "I hope our leverage with our surrogate forces will help us."

"Right now, [[Assad]] is in the driver seat."







#a set of interacting entities and,
#the physical, procedural, or temporal context of their interaction

See also [[Complex]]

#Kill the messenger
#This doesn't apply to us
#Change the rules

>It is one thing to [not react] to what we can't see. It's another thing to not react to what's in front of us.
- pg ??






>Systems Thinking helps us to understand causal relationships in the [[Complex Adaptive Systems]] that characterize the strategic environment.
-[[Hill]]






!!!Thomas S. [[Szayna]], et. al
- [[The Democratic Peace Idea]], in book: The Emergence of Peer Competitors, [[TWS 07]]

!!![[Tabletop Exercises]] from [[TSC 16]]
"""
[[Scott]]: You'd think strategic level tabletop exercises would be more like Risk. But it's really more like speed dating.
[[Todd]]: And there's minions that meet both before and after the tabletop. So that is where the meaningful relationship develop happens for follow on coordinations.






(This was an exercise for NSPS XX, Need to connect)
Headline: Successful Coup in Taiwan by Pro-Chinese Political Party Calls for Reunification with China.

W4C Party (We Wish We Were Chinese) head Lee-Kim convinced the Taiwanese Supreme Court to issue an arrest warrant of President Zi Wen who was fighting on going allegations of corruption. Gen Kong-lin, the head of the Taiwanese armed forces and sympathetic to the W4C, dispatched troops to conduct the arrest. Gen Kong-lin has declared martial law in Taipei where protests and counterprotests have turned violent. Gen Kong-lin has allowed W4C head Lee-Kim to assume interim duties as President subject to a reunification referendum to be held within 30 days. Supporters of the ousted regime have called for US peace keeping presense in the Capitol. 

Lee Kim is additionally calling for a resolution to abolish the Constitution. The the UN Security Council, China has submitted a resolution to back the new government. Predictably, Russia is supporting China while UK, France, and US oppose.

Strategy:

*D: PolMil is engaged with US ambassador to china and taiwan. I
*I: Messaging in Taiwan and UN is that the coup is illegal, govt not legit; No vote to change or abolish the constitution.
*M: Aircraft Carrier strike group to the straights of Taiwain. 1st MEF is on standby to assist with security in Taipei.
*E: Ensure freedom of navigation and commerce.; potential sactions against the W4C.

Todd

*Knowing when to monitor and when to take action

Discussing Sustainment vs Logistics, considering the [[Joint Functions]]:

>This slide says Functions, which are like the Ends of what you have to acheive. And within sustainment, logistics, personnel, and health services are the Ways that you're gong to achieve that. ....whoa!! That was pretty deep. You guys tell [[Frank]] I said that.
-[[Brett]]

!!![[The 'War on Terrorism': What Does It Mean To Win?]]

*Article by Audrey Kurth [[Cronin]] for [[TWS 15]]






!!![[The 10 B's]]
-from [[Vice CJCS Lecture]], [[GEN Selva]]

#Be accessible.
#Be approachable. (See also [[Why People Talk to You]].) They 
##If your reaction to bad news is "What the...", "How the...", or "Shut the..."
##The good news you won't have any more
#Be reasonable. Be gentle on those with bad ideas.
#Be honorable. You have to deliver on the things you say you're  going to devliver.
#Be humble. You're not any smarter or any more attractive than the day before you took the leadership position your getting ready to take. But everyone will laugh at your jokes.
#Be positive ("If you wake up Gumpy do not bring him or her to work.")
#Be persistent. You must be passionate to achieve the objedtive.
#Be proactive. Try to figure out what's going to happen tomorrow and the day after that and the week after that.
#Be professional. Build that network. "When you question whether or not you can do the right thing, your classmates can help you.
#Balance. You cannot bring everything you have unless you take care of yourself physcially, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually.






!!![[The Anatomy of Friendship]]
-[[LtGen Sanders]] in the [[Kermit Roosevelt Lecture]]

[img[https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/vxQkdZdD-4ghMnFAICYGhKlPHDHGdpLa2S3oKU9ayYx60Cc9lnoPxOviUUQnb984Alf6Z6QrLI_ueVHbnbxV2gXoyMsYGObWj_cRgkYlyeuJ5yvGTj3HhYfNO2wisWzs8AI9AhecMJY=w2400]]






!!![[The Art of War]] from [[TWS 09]] by [[Sun Tzu]]

{{Sun Tzu's Acme of Skill}}

!!![[The Causes of War and the Conditions of Peace]]
-by [[Garnett]] for [[TWS 07]]

"""
	• Is war endemic in the human condition? [21]
	• Wars are not caused by human nature; they are caused by human behavior, and while it may be possible to change human nature, it is certainly possible to modify human behavior- by offering rewards, making threats, by education programs, or by propaganda. [22]
	• Deterrent strategists hardly care at all about why wars occur.  Their policy is simply to make consequences of war so bad that nobody will dare fight even if they want to. [22]
	• Immediate cause: the events that trigger war [24]
	• Proximate cause: the root cause of the war. 
	• Efficient causes: connected to the particular circumstances surrounding individual wars. 
	• Permissive causes: are those features of the international system, which while not actively promoting war, nonetheless allow it to happen. [26]
	• Necessary condition: is one that must be present if war is to occur.  In other words, if war cannot break out without that condition existing, then it is a necessary condition. [27]
	• Sufficient cause: is one that, if present guarantees the occurrence of war. [27]
	• Explanations for war:
		○ Human Nature: We are genetically programmed for war.  The arguments for war is a condition of human nature are limited. If human nature causes war, then it follows that human nature causes everything else that humans do, including making and keeping peace. [30]
		○ Aggression: Aggression is the result of frustration.  The psychological process of transferring aggression to a secondary group is called "displacement."  Frustration/aggression hypothesis emphasizes the connection between violence and the failure of human beings to achieve their objectives. [30]
		○ Misperceptions/Misunderstandings: Decisions to go to war are often the result of misperceptions, misunderstandings, miscalculation, and errors of judgment. [30]  People who believe this view war as a mistake, a tragic consequence of failing to appreciate things as they are. Examples: bad intel, bad risk assessment. 
			§ If war is caused by misperceptions and misunderstandings created by cognitive biases, then conditions of peace include more clear thinking, better communications between countries, etc. [32]
		○ Conscious and unconscious motives for war: Wars result from conscious 
			§ Wars have both rational and irrational motives.  They result from conscious decisions and unconscious drives and weakness in the human psyche. [33]
		○ Group Explanations: Something about human collectives that encourages violence. Human beings are corrupted by the social structures in which they live. [34]
			§ Starts when people make a distinction between us and them… discriminatory sociability.  
Interstate violence now is less of a problem than it used to be. [36]  Globalization may be a contributing factor. 

<iframe src="https://drive.google.com/file/d/0Bx33V4OXisHbdmhjS1Q5TG9wX3c/preview" width="840" height="880"></iframe>






!!!!Reading by Carson and Plummer from [[DM 01]]

Presented by [[Mark]] (need notes)

Thesis: The Pentagon's inability to agree upon the objective of "Readiness" has left military readiness a notion more mystical than scientific.

Three distinct meanings:

#Things that contribute to a healthy and effective force (used by most pax and med/safety professional)
#Strategic readiness. Ability of the military to meet the [[NMS]]. (Used by Congress)
# Force readiness. Resource ratings of units and ability to perform combat tasks as laid out by COCOM. (used to reflect resourcing by force providers and OPLAN response.)

<iframe src="https://drive.google.com/file/d/172huO8aM6hchXSA1Daej6BAL_h6BS2-L/preview" width="640" height="880"></iframe>






!!![[The Coolest Part of a Video Game]]
-from [[Vice CJCS Lecture]]

*It turns out if you take a handful of those GPUs and stack them, you get an incredibly powerful  computer that is capable of employing AI
*We have reams and reams of data. But we don't aggregate it in a way
*If we were able to run simulations for that data, we might make some sense of strategy.
*It wouldn't give us answers, but it would give us trends. And strategists go off of trends.
---
>Strategy is about uncertainty.
---
*We need to get comfortable in an environment that has thousands of variables, not just a handful.






!!![[The Decision Point]], by David P. [[Houghton]], reading from [[NSPS 05]]

{{Decision-Making Models}}






!!![[The Democratic Peace Idea]]
-by [[Szayna]] in [[TWS 07]]

"""
	• Democratic states are less likely to fight wars against each other, the Democratic Peace. [147]
	→ Thomas Freedman, The Lexus and the Olive Tree, No two states with a MacDonald's have ever fought war. (US Invasion of Panama, India Pakistan in Kashmir, Israel and Lebanon, South Ossetia and Georgia, Ukraine and Russia. 
	· Democratic peace claims [148]
		○ Democracies tend to win when they fight with non-democracies
		○ In wars they initiate, democracies suffer fewer casualties and fight shorter wars than non-democracies. 
		○ Democratic states locked in disputes with each other choose more peaceful means of resolution than other pairing of states. [148]
		○ Democratic great powers do not initiate preventative wars. 
	· Why do democracies fight few wars between each other?
		○ Democratic institutions place constraints on the ability of leaders to fight other democracies or make them reluctant to choose war
		○ Norms shared by democratic states cause them to view each other as pacific and unthreatening
		○ Democracies tend to foster economic interdependence which reduce the likelihood of war. [149]
	· Other arguments for the democratic peace:
		○ Constitutional and legal restraints on executive actions [149]
		○ Democratic elites want to be reelected. 
		○ Democracies believe other democracies to be reasonable and trustworthy. [150]
		○ Free market economies
	· Caveats
		○ Democratic states have security cooperation arrangements with non-democracies that could put them in conflict with us. 
		○ Democratizing states are more war-prone.
		○ Economic and security competition change perceptions between democracies
		○ Democracies fight proxy wars or covert action
		○ Democratic reversals happen [153]
	· Democracies are involved with hostile competition with each other. [153]
		

<iframe src="https://drive.google.com/file/d/10R-mz2YtT_J2bCxaNx29udVH6toQNEE4/preview" width="840" height="880"></iframe>






!!![[The Diplomacy of Violence]]

*The Contrast of [[Brute Force]] with [[Coercion]]
*Coercive violence in warfare
*The Strategic Role of Pain and Damage
*The nuclear contribution to terror and violence
*From battlefield warfare to the "Diplomacy of Violence"

Thomas C. [[Schelling]], “The Diplomacy of Violence,” in Arms and Influence (New Haven, CT: Yale University Press, 1966).
