[[TWSDir10]]








[[TWSDir11]]








[[TWSDir12]]








[[TWSDir13]]








[[TWSDir14]]








[[TWSDir15]]








[[TWSDir16]]

Dr. Bill Johnsen	18 Sep 2017
245-3293	0830-1130
Mode: Seminar	TWS-16-S
CONTINUITY AND CHANGE: THE FUTURE CHARACTER OF WAR AND STRATEGY

E.3.i.1. Introduction.

E.3.i.1.a. Assessing continuity and change within war and warfare has been a centuries-long task.  Indeed, attempting to discern the truly new from the simply unfamiliar to the contemporary observer has been a recurring tension throughout the Theory of War and Strategy Course.  Thus, it is only fitting that the final lesson of TWS should focus on the question of the degree of continuity or change some might envisage in the future of warfare and strategy.

E.3.i.1.b. Such analysis hinges, of course, on what the future may hold.  Here the strategist rarely is on firm ground.  As one senior leader once observed in Bliss Hall, “the foreseeable future isn’t really foreseeable.”  In a more critical vein, former Secretary of Defense, Dr. Robert Gates oftentimes remarked that when it comes to predicting the future with precision, we have 100 percent accuracy—we have gotten zero right.  Nor are contemporary observers alone in this regard.  Throughout history, people failed to foresee significant historical events, such as the French Revolution, World War I, the Great Depression, or, in our own times, the events of September 11, 2001.

E.3.i.1.c. Despite the challenges of doing so, strategists and policymakers still must learn to think about the future in order to plan and prepare.  While we are unlikely to get the future completely “right,” that should not be our goal.  Instead, to paraphrase the historian Sir Michael Howard’s comment about doctrine, we just should not be too far wrong. 

E.3.i.1.d. To that end, this lesson will help you think about how (and how not) to conceptualize the future. One way is to look backwards. As the expression goes, new things are only old things happening to new people. Put slightly differently, if a pattern has been true since the time of Thucydides, it is likely to remain true for the near term.  This does not infer that nothing changes.  However, it does mean placing the burden of proof on those individuals predicting that some technology or political movement will cause radical change to the nature and character of war and strategy.  The first reading, a short essay from Colin Gray, a prolific and oftentimes controversial, contemporary strategist, offers some observations on continuity and change in contemporary strategy. 

E.3.i.1.e. Another way to think about the future is to look forward.  Thus, this lesson offers for your consideration several emerging theories, concepts, doctrines, and practices that hold potential to alter the future character of war:  the so-called “gray zone” phenomenon, Russia’s “new type war,” China’s military strategy, the differing uses of terrorism by Al Qaida and ISIL, and, potentially the most disrupting influence of all, cyber warfare. 

E.3.i.1.f. Whether looking backward or forward, assess how these ideas might influence the character of war and strategy in the near-, mid-, and long-term.  Examine critically, the question of continuity versus change.  As you do so, draw upon insights from throughout the TWS course, particularly, your study of the fundamental principles of strategy.  Where possible, clearly discriminate between the truly new, and “old wine in new bottles.”

E.3.i.2. Learning Outcomes.  By the end of the lesson, the student should be able to:

E.3.i.2.a. Assess the challenges that strategists face when trying to develop plans for the future.

E.3.i.2.b. Evaluate the utility of the theorists and strategists we have studied so far (Thucydides, Clausewitz, etc.) in helping strategists determine the enduring nature of strategy.

E.3.i.2.c. Evaluate the usefulness of emerging concepts and theories on the future character of war and strategy. 

E.3.i.3. Student Requirements

E.3.i.3.a. Tasks. None

E.3.i.3.b. Required Readings.

E.3.i.3.b.1. Colin Gray, “War—Continuity in Change, and Change in Continuity,” Parameters, (Summer 2010): 5-13.                                                                                                                    [Blackboard]

E.3.i.3.b.2. Adam Elkus, “50 Shades of Gray: Why the Gray War Concept Makes No Sense,” War on the Rocks, 15 December 2015.                                                                                              [Blackboard]

E.3.i.3.b.3. Michael J. Mazarr, “Struggle in the Gray Zone and World Order,” War on the Rocks, December 22, 2015.                                                                                                        [Blackboard]

E.3.i.3.b.4. Timothy L. Thomas, Russia Military Strategy:  Impacting 21st Century Reform and Geopolitics (Ft. Leavenworth, KS: Foreign Military Studies Office, 2016), 100-106.                [Blackboard]

E.3.i.3.b.5. “Document: China’s Military Strategy,” USNI News, Sections III-V, 8-19.                                                                                                                              [Blackboard]

E.3.i.3.b.6. Celine Marie I. Navenario, “Differentiating Al Qaeda and the Islamic State through Strategies Publicized in Jihadist Magazine,” Studies in Conflict & Terrorism 39, No. 11, 953-964.                                                                                                                         [Blackboard]

E.3.i.3.b.7. Antulio Echevarria, Jr., “Cyberpower and Military Strategy “in Military Strategy: A Very Short Introduction (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2017), 98-108.                                              [Blackboard]

E.3.i.3.c. Suggested Readings.

E.3.i.3.c.1. Hew Strachan, The Direction of War: Contemporary Strategy in Historical Perspective (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2013.

E.3.i.3.c.2. Thomas X. Hammes, The Sling and The Stone: On War in the 21st Century (St. Paul MN: Zenith Press, 2004).

E.3.i.3.c.3. Frank G. Hoffman, Conflict in the 21st Century: The Rise of Hybrid Wars (Arlington, VA:  Potomac Institute for Policy Studies, 2007).

E.3.i.3.c.4. Peter Singer, Wired for War: The Robotics Revolution and Conflict in the 21st Century (New York: Penguin Press, 2009).

E.3.i.3.c.5. Shawn Brimley, Ben FitzGerald and Kelly Sayler, Game Changers: Disruptive Technology and U.S. Defense Strategy (Washington D.C.: Center for New American Security, September 2013) https://www.cnas.org/publications/reports/game-changers-disruptive-technology-and-u-s-defense-strategy (accessed April 6, 2017).

E.3.i.3.c.6. Robert O. Work and Shawn Brimley, 20YY: Preparing for War in the Robotic Age (Washington DC: Center for New American Security, 2014) https://www.cnas.org/publications/reports/20yy-preparing-for-war-in-the-robotic-age (accessed 6 April 2017).

E.3.i.3.c.7. Colin Gray, The Future of Strategy (Malden, MA: Polity Press, 2015).

E.3.i.3.c.8. Martin van Creveld, More on War (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2017).

E.3.i.4. Points to Consider.

E.3.i.4.a. Colin Gray asserts “... that enormous changes in the tactical and operational grammar of strategy matter not at all for the nature and function of war and strategy.” Do you agree with his contention?  Why or why not?

E.3.i.4.b. How can strategists prepare for an uncertain future? How can they prepare for a variety of threats? What are the potential consequences for strategy of more intra-state rather than inter-state wars? How might strategies of conflict affect the application of military power?

E.3.i.4.c. Has warfare remained primarily Clausewitzian (determined by the interplay of violence, chance, and reason) or has it become non-Clausewitzian as critics claim?  Or, is it something else entirely?

E.3.i.4.d. What is the relationship between technology/science and warfare? How might changes in this relationship affect the nature, character, or characteristics of war?

E.3.i.4.e. Is strategy an art, a science, or does it contain elements of both? How does one’s understanding of the nature of strategy influence how wars are fought and won?

!!!“[[War—Continuity in Change, and Change in Continuity]],” Parameters (p. 5-13)
By Colin [[Gray]]

"""
	• [[Clausewitz]]: "But in war more than in any other subject we must begin by looking at the nature of the whole; for here more than elsewhere the part and the whole must always be thought of together." [5]
	• How does one attempt to improve guesswork for the future concerning war, warfare, and strategy? The most basic answer is that one can only educate in the hope that judgment will be improved so that good, as op-posed to poor, strategic choices will be made. [6]
	→ You have to make a bet because the lead time in S&T, RDTE and the lag of a 5-year PPBE cycle. You can't build a future Army one year at a time. [6]
	· 9 Claims about War:
		1. War has a constant nature, but an ever-changing character. [6]
		2. Every war is distinctive and typically waged in several styles. [7]
		3. War has persisting and universal contexts that explain and drive it with historical specificity. [7]
		4. War is eternally and universally possible because human beings in politically organized societies can always be sufficiently motivated by some mixture of “fear, honor, and interest” to choose to fight. [8]
		5. Clausewitz explained well enough the enduring nature of war in terms of two unstable trinities: passion, chance, and reason, which he primarily associated with the people, the army and its commander, and the government or policy, respectively. [8]
		6. The general theory of strategy so educates strategists that they are intellectually enabled to invent, design, and execute historically specific strategies that may succeed. [8]
		7. Strategy is very difficult for many reasons, one of which is that it is neither a question of politics nor fighting power, but rather the conversion of military effort into political reward. [9]
		8. Strategy is very difficult for many reasons, one of which is that it is neither a question of politics nor fighting power, but rather the conversion of military effort into political reward. [9]
		9. There is a “conceptual carousel,” a fairground-like roundabout of strategic ideas, good, bad, and both. [10]
	· There is nothing of fundamental importance that is genuinely new about war and strategy in the twenty-first century (not even nuclear weapons). [11]
	→ Disagree… 5 dimensions of war, fully formed/complex artificially intelligence
	· Particular styles in warfare wax and wane, and wax again, endlessly.  Irregular warfare is dominant for now, but that says nothing of much predictive value regarding 21st century beyond today. [12]
	· Every new set of technological marvels brings with it specific novel challenges. [12]
	· War/warfare is a duel and a dynamic, unique, and unpredictable product of interaction between friendly and unfriendly forces, together with friction and chance.  One thing that wont change is a self-willed adversary. [13]
"""

!!![[50 Shades of Gray: Why the Gray War Concept Makes No Sense]],” [[War on the Rocks]]
By Adam Elkus

"""
	· Gray Wars: Wars in which groups or entities (combatants) seek to secure their objectives while minimizing the scope and scale of actual combat. [1]
	· The gray wars concept grossly over-exaggerates its own transgressions from the norm. Beneath the hype is something rather ooh-la-lame rather than ooh-la-la. [1]
	· Gray zone wars seem to be a composite of two very well known ideas in military strategy and political science: limited wars and compellence. [1]
	· We do not need any new and exotic terminology for this kind of activity. Things such as proxy warfare, salami-slicing, coercive strategies, escalation dominance, and above all else compellence come to mind. To compel a foe is to forcibly make them do as you wish by hurting them — and raising the threat of future harms — until they cry uncle. [2]
	· The real problem is not really that our adversaries have changed. It is that we have refused to change. We continue to be shocked and surprised when our adversaries do the same things they always have: creatively apply force and other coercive means to realize their political objectives. [3]
"""

!!!“[[Struggle in the Gray Zone and World Order]],” [[War on the Rocks]]
By Michael J. [[Mazarr]]

"""
	· I conclude that something like the gray zone is real: Revisionist states, constrained by risks of escalation and economic interdependence, do appear to be in the market for subtle ways to achieve their objectives. The most important finding, though, was that the rise of the gray zone is symptomatic of bigger trends in world politics. [1]
	· To me, the biggest differences relate to the coherence, intentionality, and urgency of these campaigns, which is why it makes sense to discuss the gray zone as a distinct approach to strategy. [1]
	· Gray zone strategies pursue political objectives through calculated and integrated campaigns to achieve specific and often quite ambitious goals within a certain period of time. [1]
	· This definition distinguishes the gray zone both from asymmetric violence like terrorism and insurgency, and from hybrid campaigns that combine classic military operations with asymmetric techniques, as in Lebanon in 2006. [1]
	· These facts point to a second lesson: The most important answer to gray zone tactics is not to build a whole suite of counter-capabilities — fishing fleets, battalions of “little green men,” propaganda campaigns. [2]
"""

!!!Russia Military Strategy:  Impacting 21st Century Reform and Geopolitics (p. 100-106)
By Timothy L. Thomas

"""
	· Further, the terms “asymmetrical approach” or “asymmetrical actions” are close in substance to the concepts of indirect actions and indirect action strategy, according to the authors. [100]
	· He begins by noting that aggressor states, such as the U.S., pressure victim states with various measures in order to increase America’s volume of natural resources and thereby enable it to stay at the top of the world as an economic power. [100]
	· To maintain its world hegemony, the U.S. has conducted “systemic” deterrence operations against Russia. the U.S. has demonized opponents, disrupted communications, formed ideological coalitions, advanced NATO’s infrastructure to Russia’s border, imposed an arms race on other nations, manipulated energy markets, and drug Russia and others into regional conflicts. [101]
	· The “color revolution” information effect primarily uses the Internet to affect the consciousness of people. [102]
	· Kartapalov stated that America’s basing systems abroad, its global missile defense architecture and instantaneous global strike concept, and its precision electronic information strikes and technical development of a reconnaissance-strike system have all been created or improved. These actions can undermine global stability, disrupt the correlation of forces in the nuclear missile sphere, and create a real threat in the mid-term to the security of the Russian Federation. [103]
	· Kartapalov: A very important condition for conducting asymmetric operations is the precise determination of the enemy’s most vulnerable and weakest areas, action against which will provide the maximum effect with minimal expenditure of one’s own forces and resources. [104]
	· Kartapalov noted that asymmetric actions are conducted with the aim of eliminating (neutralizing) advantages the enemy has and delivering against him (subjecting him to) damage using minimal expenditures. [104]
"""

!!!“Document: China’s Military Strategy,” USNI News (p. 8-19)

"""
	→ Should we take this at face value?  Is this what they are doing or is this what they want us to think they are doing?
	· From the long-term practice of revolutionary wars, the people's armed forces have developed a complete set of strategic concepts of active defense, which boils down to:· adherence to the unity of strategic defense and operational and tactical offense; adherence to the principles of defense. self-defense and post-emptive strike; and adherence to the stance that "We will not attack unless we are attacked, but we will surely counterattack if attacked." [8-9]
	· China's Goals:
		○ To foster a strategic posture favorable to China's peaceful development, adhere to the national defense policy that is defensive in nature, persevere in close coordination of political, military, economic and diplomatic work, and positively cope with comprehensive security threats the country possibly encounters [10]
		○ To endeavor to seize the strategic initiative in military struggle, proactively plan for military struggle in all directions and domains, and grasp the opportunities to accelerate military building, reform and development. [11]
		○ To give full play to the overall power of the concept of people's war, persist in employing it as an ace weapon to triumph over the enemy, enrich the contents, ways and means of the concept of people's war, and press forward with the shift of the focus of war mobilization from human resources to science and technology. [11]
		→ We shouldn't fall for this bullshit propaganda.
	· In line with the strategic requirement of mobile operations and multi-dimensional offense and defense, the PLA Army (PLAA) will continue to reorient from theater defense to trans-theater mobility. [12]
	· In line with the strategic requirement of offshore waters defense and open seas protection, the PLA Navy (PLAN) will gradually shift its focus from "offshore waters defense" to the combination of "offshore waters defense" with "open seas protection. [12]
	· PLA Air Force (PLAAF) will endeavor to shift its focus from territorial air defense to both defense and offense, and build an air­space defense force structure that can meet the requirements of informationized operations. The PLAAF will boost its capabilities for strategic early warning, air strike, air and missile defense, information countermeasures, airborne operations, strategic projection and comprehensive support. [12]
	· PLA Second Artillery Force (PLASAF) will strive to transform itself in the direction of informationization, press forward with independent innovations in weaponry and equipment by reliance on science and technology, enhance the safety, reliability and effectiveness of missile systems, and improve the force structure featuring a combination of both nuclear and conventional capabilities. [13]
	· Outer space has become a commanding height in international strategic competition. [13]
	· China will expedite the development of a cyber force, and enhance its capabilities of cyberspace situation awareness, cyber defense. support for the country's endeavors in cyberspace and participation in international cyber cooperation, so as to stem major cyber crises, ensure national network and information security, and maintain national security and social stability. [14]
	· Developing advanced weaponry and equipment. Persevering in information dominance, systems building, independent innovation, sustainable development, overall planning, and emphasis on priorities, China's armed forces will speed up to upgrade weaponry and equipment, and work to develop a weaponry and equipment system which can effectively respond to informationized warfare and help fulfill the missions and tasks.[15] 
	· Innovating military theories. Under the guidance of the CPC's innovative theories, China's armed forces will intensify their studies of military operations, probe into the mechanisms of winning modern wars, innovate strategies and tactics featuring mobility and flexibility, and develop theories on military building in the new situation, so as to bring into place a system of advanced military theories commensurate with the requirement of winning future wars. [16]
	· Pushing ahead with PMS in all directions and domains. Due to its complex geostrategic environment, China faces various threats and challenges in all its strategic directions and security domains. Therefore, PMS must be carried out in a well-planned, prioritized, comprehensive and coordinated way, so as to maintain the balance and stability of the overall strategic situation. [18]
"""

!!!“Differentiating Al Qaeda and the Islamic State through Strategies Publicized in Jihadist Magazine,” Studies in Conflict & Terrorism (p. 953-964)
By Celine Marie I. Navenario

"""
	· The ﬁve strategic logics employed in terrorism identiﬁed by Kydd and Walter: attrition, intimidation, provocation, spoiling, and outbidding. [954]
	· The distinct threats posed by Al Qaeda and the Islamic State are often conﬂated into one, presuming that both groups are primarily focused on a war of attrition with the West. Doing so overlooks the distinct differences between Al Qaeda’s and the Islamic State’s respective visions. 
		○ For Al Qaeda, the task at hand is attacking the far enemy; building the Caliphate would come later. 
		○ The Islamic State, however, believes that the Caliphate is here; the end-of-days encounter with the far enemy comes next. [955]
	· 5 Strategic Logics [957]
		○ Attrition: refers to strategies targeted at convincing the enemy that the terrorists are able and willing to inﬂict a high cost if a speciﬁc policy continues to be enforced. Includes articles highlighting terror attacks, which are justiﬁed as a reaction to aggression, and threats for future attacks unless egregious actions are halted. 
			§ The majority of Al Qaeda’s messages are dedicated to forcing a change in policy and behavior from America and its allies through the threat of lone jihad.  
			§ The Islamic State’s use of attrition differs in that it is employed to further its goal of Caliphate-building
		○ Intimidation: Refers to strategies aimed at demonstrating the terrorist’s strength and the government’s weakness to a population, thus inducing the population to act according to the terrorists’ wishes. 
			§ Al Qaeda scarcely uses intimidation as a strategic logic, appearing in only 5 percent of the articles surveyed.  
			§ Intimidation has been a key strategy employed by the Islamic State from the outset
		○ Provocation: Refers to strategies intended to goad the enemy toward a disproportionate response to terrorism, thereby radicalizing and causing the population to align with terrorists. 
			§ Provocation is used sparingly by the two groups in their propaganda
		○ Spoiling: Refers to strategies designed to demonstrate the weakness of the moderate thereby derailing attempts at peaceful resolutions. 
		○ Outbidding: Refers to strategies designed to demonstrate a terrorist group’s greater commitment to ﬁght an enemy in order to draw supporters to its cause and away from its rivals. 
			§ Outbidding is a key strategic logic employed by both groups and exceedingly by the Islamic State. 
"""

!!!“Cyberpower and Military Strategy “in Military Strategy: A Very Short Introduction (p. 98-108)
By Antulio [[Echevarria]], Jr. 

"""
	• Cyber Power: The ability to operate with relative security within cyberspace.
	• Cyber War or Warfare: Using digital code to inflict material or psychological harm on another party and thereby to coerce that party into doing what we want. [98]
	• Like the advent of nuclear weapons, the invention of cyberspace has caused us to take another look at our basic conception of military strategy and to consider whether we might need to revise it. [99]
	• The true source of America's cyber vulnerability was its trust in the security of online infrastructures coupled with the rapid migration of essential government functions, industry and commerce, healthcare, social communication, and personal information to digital networks [99]
	• What is loosely referred to as "cyber war" is really a 3-way competition between:
		○ The rapid migration of essential data and functions to online networks
		○ The ongoing efforts of cybersecurity systems which struggle to protect those networks. 
		○ The persistent attempts of cyber attacks who find ways to defeat those security measures. [100]
	• Some believe that cyber war is more about the potential cyberspace offers for the manipulation of information.  Such manipulation shapes political opinions, consumer biases and habits, social norms, group identities, and cultural values. Cyber war is about "the political economy of the Internet." [101]
	• Debating whether cyber war is real war misses a critical point: the essential issue is not war but power. Cyber power is the ability to move data and perform functions in cyberspace with relative security and this ability can serve as an instrument of policy just as traditional military power can. [102]
	• Grey Zone wars: those conflicts that take place under other parties' response thresholds. [103]
	• Cyberspace consists of physical and virtual components. The former includes terminals, nodes, and conduits; the latter involves the access, manipulation, and representation of data. [103]
	• Unlike other types of military power, cyber power has the political advantage of rarely causing human casualties though it can produce extensive collateral damage by unintentionally infecting nontargeted systems. [104]
	• Thus, collectively, cyber power does not lend itself to easy analogies with other types of power. Moreover, use of such analogies is likely to misinform the crafting of cyber strategies. [104]
	• Cyber Capabilities:
		○ Denial: refusing access to critical information or activities, such as financial transactions energy production and transfer, intell gathering, etc. [105]
		○ Intervention: Penetrating cyber traffic and data storage to eavesdrop and collect intelligence.
		○ Manipulation: Sabotoging or disrupting a system to crash it, or to make it yield an outcome different from the one it was intended to produce. [106]
		







!!![[TWSReads01]]

''Required Readings''

"""
D.3.a.9.b.1. U.S. Army War College, Department of National Security and Strategy. Theory of War and Strategy Directive (Carlisle Barracks: U.S. Army War College, 2018), 1-9 and Appendices I and II.                                                                                                                        [Blackboard]           
                                                                                           
D.3.a.9.b.2. Basil H. [[Liddell Hart]], Part IV, “[[Fundamentals of Strategy and Grand Strategy]],” in [[Strategy|Strategy (Book)]], 2nd ed. (New York: Penguin, 1991), 319-323 and 338-339; 353-360.          [Student Issue]
                                                                                                                        
D.3.a.9.b.3. H. Richard [[Yarger]], “[[Toward a Theory of Strategy: Art Lykke and the U.S. Army War College Strategy Model]],” in U.S. Army War College Guide to National Security Issues, 5th ed., Vol. I: Theory of War and Strategy (Carlisle Barracks, PA: Strategic Studies Institute, U.S. Army War College, 2012), 45-51.                                                                                                 [Blackboard]    
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  
D.3.a.9.b.4.  J. Boone [[Bartholomees]], Jr., “[[A Survey of the Theory of Strategy]],” in The U.S. Army War College Guide to National Security Issues, 5th ed., Vol. I: Theory of War and Strategy (Carlisle Barracks, PA: U.S. Army War College, Strategic Studies Institute, July 2012): READ 13-28, SKIM rest of chapter.                                                                                                      [Blackboard]                     







!!![[TWSReads02]]

''Required Readings''

"""
D.3.b.3.b.1. Robert [[Strassler]], ed., [[The Landmark Thucydides]]: A Comprehensive Guide to the Peloponnesian War (New York: The Free Press, 1996).                                                                                                          [Student Issue]
Thucydides’ history is conventionally divided into eight books. We list passages by book number and corresponding passage number—for example, “1.66” indicates Book One, passage 1.66. This is clearly indicated in the Strassler text.  Pay attention to the useful summaries provided in the page margins.
READ
[[Book One: Thucydides]]
  1.1 introduction (page 3)
  1.22-1.54 Corcyra (pages 15-33)
  1.65-1.87 speech of Archidamus (pages 37-49)
  1.119-1.127 speech of Corinthians (pages 65-70)
  1.139-1.146 Spartan emissaries; Pericles’ speech on war and war aims (pages 79-85)
[[Book Two: Thucydides]]
  2.7-2.25 Sparta’s first campaign (pages 93-107)
  2.34-2.48 Pericles’ funeral oration (pages 110-118)
  2.55-2.65 Sparta’s second campaign, Athens’ plague, Pericles’ death (pages 122-128)







!!![[TWSReads03]]

''Required Readings''

"""
D.3.c.3.b.1. Robert [[Strassler]], ed., [[The Landmark Thucydides]]: A Comprehensive Guide to the Peloponnesian War (New York: The Free Press, 1996).                                                            [Student Issue]
Thucydides’ history is conventionally divided into eight books. We list passages by book number and corresponding passage number—for example, “1.66” indicates Book One, passage 1.66. This is clearly indicated in the Strassler text. Pay attention to the useful summaries provided in the page margins.

READ

  3.25-3.50 revolt of the Mytilenes, pt. II; Cleon, Diodotus (pages 171-184)
  3.70-3.86 Corcyraean revolt; Sicily, pt. I (pages 194-202)

''Required Readings''

"""
D.3.d.3.b.1. Robert [[Strassler]], ed., [[The Landmark Thucydides]]: A Comprehensive Guide to the Peloponnesian War (New York: The Free Press, 1996).                                                                                                   [Student Issue]
Thucydides’ history is conventionally divided into eight books. We list passages by book number and corresponding passage number—for example, “1.66” indicates Book One, passage 1.66. This is clearly indicated in the Strassler text. Pay attention to the useful summaries provided in the page margins

READ

[[Book Six: Thucydides]]
  6.1; 6.6-6.34  Sicily, pt. IV: Athens debates an expedition (page 361 and pages 365-379)

  6.61 (Alcibiades recalled pages 395-396)

  7.48-7.76  Sicily, pt. VIII: Athens’ defeat (pages 455-472)

  8.18-8.37 Alliance between Sparta and Persia; revolts throughout the Athenian Empire; Persia buys a Spartan navy (pages 492-502)

[[Epilogue: Thucydides]]
  549-554 Athens’ defeat; Persian ascendancy; Philip of Macedon
REVIEW 2.65 Pericles’ original strategy for Athens

"""

READ (in order):
Book Two, Chapter 2, “Theory Should be Study, Not Doctrine,” 141.
[[On War Book One]]:
  Chapter 1, "What is War?," 75-89.
  Chapter 2, “Purpose and Means in War,” 91-94, 99.
[[On War Book Two]], Chapter 3, “Art of War or Science of War,” 148-150.
[[On War Book Eight]]
  Chapter 1, “Introduction, “577-578.
  Chapter 2, “Absolute War and Real War,” 579-581.
  Chapter 3a, “Interdependence of the Elements of War,” 582-584.

  Chapter 3, "On Military Genius," 100-112.
  Chapter 4, "On Danger in War," 113-114.

  Chapter 7, "Friction in War," 119-121.

!!![[Understanding Global Conflict and Cooperation]]: An Introduction to Theory and History, [[TWS 05]]

by Joseph S. [[Nye]] and David A. [[Welch]]

{{State Explained by Nye and Welch}}

*	• [[Nation]]: a group of people who have some combination of common language, culture, religion, history, mythology, identity, or sense of destiny.  [35]
*	• [[Nation State]]: a whose citizens are overwhelmingly members of a single nation. [36]
*	• Supranatural Integration: Example is the EU. 
*	• [[Power]] is the ability to achieve one's purposes or goals. [38]
*	• [[Power Conversion]]: the capacity to convert potential power, as measured by resources, to realized power, as measured by the change behavior of others. [39]
*	• Hard Power: coercing other states to change.  Carrots and sticks. 
*	• Soft Power: getting others to want what you want, also called attractive power. [40]
* Breakout: [[Hard Power vs Soft Power]]
*	• Authority is a moral, normative, or juridical concept.  Authority involves legitimacy. [42]
*	• What makes a system stable?  The quality of the social fabric of international society. [44]
*	• A state's position in the international system determines its national interests and predicts its foreign policies. [45]
*	→ Chaos Theory:
**		○ Co-evolution: the system changes in response to changes in the environment, and the environment changes in response to the changes in the system
**		○ Disequilibrium: adaptive, evolving, changing… dynamic
**		○ Transformation/emergence: reorganization of complexity
**		○ Peturbance: a change in a system's environment that causes disequilibrium
**		○ Self-Organization: systems that evolve themselves. 
*[[Geopolitics]]: Holds that location and proximity will tell a great deal about how states will behave. 

{{Levels of Causation of War}}

{{Nye and Welch: Four Dominant Paradigms}}

!!![[Unified Action]] (See [[TSC 16]]): The synchronization, coordination, and/or integration of the activities of governmental and nongovernmantal entities with military operations to achieve unity of effort.

!!![[United Nations]] discussion in [[NSPS 02]]

*Charter of the UN--signed June 1945; exresses values, and military, economic, and social goals
*Security Council: 15 members (5 permanent: US, UK, France, Russia, China; and 10 non-permanent). UNSCR has force of law.
*General Assembly: 193 members
*Secretariat: Secretary General and admin
*Chapter VI vs. Chapter VII operations
*Chapter VII permits "regional arrangements"
*See [[United Nations in Wikipedia|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Nations]]






!!![[Unlocking the Hidden Value in Organizations]]
*[[Book]] by Charles O'Reilly III and Jeffrey Pfeffer
*Brief by [[Phil]] for [[SL 10]] Organizational Culture

Thesis: The most important factor in today's knowledge based economy is to attract and retain great people.

Assumptions of employees:

*They will not expend effort unless they are paid or supervised
*They pursue their own interests
*Goals of managers and employees are not in alignment

Six factors to align human resource levers:

*Strong culture
*Hiring to fit
*Investing in people
*Widespread information sharing
*Team based systems
*Rewards and recognition






Logo

-A panel member making a wee tiny bit of conjecture

!!![[US National Interests]] from [[NSPS 01]]

>US national interests are expressions of US values projected into the domestic and international arenas. The purpose of interests includes the creation and perpetuation of an international environment that is most favor able to the peaceful pursuit of US values.
-[[Sarkesian]], [6] 

__From the Obama Administration__

*The __security__ of the United States, its citizens, and US allies and partners
*A strong, innovative, and growing US __economy__ in an open international economic system that promotes opportunity and prosperity
*Respect for __universal values__ at home and around the world
*A rules-based __international order__ advanced by US leadership that promotes peace, security, and opportunity through stronger cooperation to meet global challenges
....

!!![[Vice on Swarming]]
-from [[Vice CJCS Lecture]]

Q: When people show resistance to giving up "these Starship Enterprises" (like F22s and subs) in the face of swarms, do you see a cultural or technical challenge?

A: Both. Swarms are real. We have to use them on both sides. ... "It is cultural. How many of you want a machine to make the decision to take a human life? I don't. ... We have to determine how to operate in that environment."

*I think we need to figure out how to pair humans with machines.
*If I gave you all the data, you'd spend 90% of your time just going through the data, 8-9% pondering what to do, and 1% of the time making the decision.
*We need a way of letting the machines sort the data for you. They are really good at that.






!!![[Vice on the JCIDS Process]]
-from [[Vice CJCS Lecture]]

>If I had a nickel for every time someone had asked me that question, we wouldn't have a budget problem

>80% of the requirements validation happens is inside the separate services. So if we're going to make any changes it has to be inside

*Most of what we do is making sure that the requirements the services bring to us are hooking in to the Joint Force design.
*By the way, if the answer is "no" it doesn't mean that it won't be purchased. It just means the service has to go it alone.

!!![[VUCA]]: Volatility, Uncertainty, [[Complexity|Complex]], Ambiguity

*Explained in [[Gerras]]'s [[Leadership Primer]] from [[TWS]]
*re-introduced by [[Ed]] in [[TSC 14]]






!!![[War and Misperception]]
-by [[Jervis]] for [[TWS 07]]

"""
	• Areas of misperception: 
		○ Misperceiving the intentions of potential adversaries [195]
		○ Capabilities/Military Optimism or Pessimism
		○ Anticipated consequences of events. 
	• We may need to distinguish between misperceptions of a state's predispositions (motives and goals)- and misperceptions of the realities of the state [196]
	• War without misperception: the losing side went to war knowingly due to honor, domestic politics, or international reputation. [196]
	• Should misperceptions be judged in terms of outcomes or processes. Should be compare them to what later revealed to have been reality or whether we should ask how reasonable were the statesmen's inferences given the information available at the time. [198]
	• We are more likely to study war than to study peace. [198]
	• Its hard to determine what a leader's or a country's perceptions are. 
	• Wars can occur if aggressors underestimate the willingness of status quo powers to fight (WWII).  Wars can also result if two states exaggerate each other's hostility when their differences are in fact bridgeable. [202]
	• States can either under or overestimate the aggressiveness of their adversaries and that either error can lead to war. [203]
	• Even if the initial conflict of interest does not justify a war and it is the process of conflict itself which generates the impulse to fight, misperception may not be the crucial factor.  To retreat after having expended prestige, treasure, and blood, is physiologically more painful than retreating at the start. [204]
	• States are more likely to overestimate the hostility of others than to underestimate it [205]
	• People also tend to over-perceive hostility because they pay closest attention to dramatic events. [206]
	• The state sending the message of commitment is likely to assume that it has been received. [207]
	• People and states become committed to policies not only by staking their bargaining reputations on them, but by coming to believe that their polices are morally justified and politically necessary. [207]
	• Commitment can also create misperceptions.  As the decision maker comes to see his policy as necessary, he is likely to believe that the policy can succeed, even if such a conclusion requires the distortion of information about what others will do. [207]


<iframe src="https://drive.google.com/file/d/0Bx33V4OXisHbSXg2QnJNQlRZVXM/preview" width="840" height="880"></iframe>

!!![[What Can Airpower Do]]?
From [[TWS 12]]

*Transport personnel/materiel
*Intel, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance
*Close Air Support
*Combat Air Patrol
*Ensure Air Superiority/Supremacy
*Interdiction
*[[Deterrence]]
*Global strike
*Communication, support COIN, homeland defense, space

!!![[What if Competition becomes Conflict?]]

The problem is that between the minimum economic ordering point and getting to the 



*We have 221 C-17s in the air mobility fleet. We've built them at a rate of 20 a year.
*We're having an argument about whether to buy the last two Ford class carriers. "If you buy two they're cheaper!" I'll leave that answer for you to watch

>We don't build 

>Right now if you're wounded in Afghanistan, you're likely to be in Walter Reed in 72 hours and you have a 95% chance of survival.
---
>The other question if we go to Great Power Conflict is who comes out as Great Powers on the other side. We know what happened in WWII.

*When Germany invaded Poland. 1 Sep 1939.
*Invasion of Manchuria. 7 July 1937.
*11 Nov 1918. (Blah blah blah....)
*7 Dec 1941.
*Bulgaria: 1 March 1941.
*Netherlands: 10 May 1940. (...or 1870. Puts the military profession above the politics in Prussians.)

!!![[Whistleblower Reprisal]], from [[Lecture from The IG]]

''10 USC 1034: Must Meet These Four Conditions''

#Did the military member make or prepare a communication protected (PC) by statue?
#Was an Unfavorable Peronnel Action taken or threated, or was a favorable action withheld or threatened to be withheld following the PC?
#Did the official responsible for taking, withholding, or threatening the personnel actions know about the PC?
#Did the evidence establish that teh personnel actions would have been taken if the PC had not been made?

{{Protected Communication}}

!!![[Why not to put nukes back in South Korea]]

http://foreignpolicy.com/2017/10/11/putting-u-s-nukes-back-in-south-korea-is-a-terrible-idea/

*[[Dex]]'s [[presentation|Presentations]] for [[NSPS 02]]
*Sen [[McCain]] and others have argued for the redeployment of tactical nuclear weapons back to South Korea.
*The authors Jon [[Wolfsthal and Dalton]], Toby, offer seven counterarguments

#We already have capable nuclear deterance.
#They make US conventional weapons seem less credible.
#The US does not have spare nuclear weapons to redeploy.
#There is no place to put them. Infrastructure
#Why make legitimize nK's posture of needing a nuclear deterrence.
#Why enable South Korea's dependence on nuclear weapons.
#There are better options.

{{Shipmate}}

-LTG [[Quantock]]

>Why would I eat fruit? Fruit is what food eats.
-[[Scott]]






>You don't join the Army to be different.
-Lennie [[Wong]] in [[Lecture on Generational Culture]]






!!![[Wicked Problem]], [[SoD]] presentation by [[Bob]] for [[TSC 03]]

*We studied this during [[SL 01]] in a reading by Rittel and Weber
**[[Planning Problems are Wicked Problems|https://drive.google.com/open?id=0Bx33V4OXisHbQmZhdE1KVDNodkU]]
*Lecture on [[Complex Adaptive Systems]] by Andrew [[Hill]]
*Thought's on [[Uncertainty]] from Bob's [[SRP]] research

*DA Pam 525-5-500 that presents this extremely well
**differentiates between well-structured, medium structured, and ill-structured or wicked problems
**differentiates between structural complexity (many parts) and interactivie complexity (interactions that make the system unpredictable)

''4 Aspects that confound conventional thinking and problem solving process from Armed Forces Journal Article''

*No defnitive way to formulate an ill-structured problem
**Dave mentioned: "Give me options", "Well what do you want to do?"
**This is the empirical observation that occurs between civilian leadership and military planners that indicates a wicked problem
*Wicked problems are Interactively Complex
**Uncertainly: 1) Complex, 2) Non-linear, 3) Adaptive
*Wicked problems have no stopping-rule
*We cannot understand a wicked problem without proposing a solution

''Additional aspects from the DA Pam''

*Every solution is a 'one-shot opporutunity.' Becuase there is no stopping rule, once some sort of fix goes in you are stuck with the new situation indefinitely
*Adaptive iteration required

!!!Analysis of the Missle Launch and Nuclear Proliferation on the Penninsula

''Major Dimensions of the Problem''

*Each analyzed for the type of variable: binary, discrete (multiple options), continuous

#Nuclear Technological Development (continuos)
##Cannot understand a problem without proposing a solutions
##Every test or launch provides additional evidence of development
##This dimension is more of a puzzle than a mystery
#Willingness to use Nuclear weapons against opponents (binary, adapative)
#Status of the regime: Strong, teetering, losing control (continuous, adaptive)
##Interactive complexity here has to do with the populace
#Effectiveness of sanctions (continuous, complex, non-linear)
##Non-linear: At what point to sanctions have an impact? And to what? Strength of the regime? Technological development? Willingness to use nukes?
#Willingness of non-proliferation partners to intervene beyond sanctions (binary, adaptive)
##Acceptance of risks of escalation ==> civilian deaths
#Willingness of China to intercede diplomatically (continuous, adaptive)
#Willingness of China to intercede militarily (binary, complex, adaptive)
#In the event of conflict, what would the new status look like? (discrete, complex, non-linear, adaptive)
##There is no stopping rule. Allied occupation? Chinese occupation? New regime? Democracy?
#Willingness for allied partners to change the status quo thinking on a nuclear penninsula (discrete, adaptive)
##No stopping rule: nuclear Japan? Other new nuclear actors in the region? Implications for our policy towards Iran.

''Implications for risk analysis''

*Risk of what?
*What would the probabilities be with so many continuous and adaptive variables?
